questions.text:
A woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents with bleeding per vaginum. Sonography reveals elevated peak systolic velocity in fetal MCA and velamentous attachment of the cord. CTG was done to reveal the following pattern with absent accelerations. What should be done?

MCA - Middle cerebral artery

CTG- Cardiotocography

choices.text: Wait and watch for the labor to begin as the fetal heart rate is stable
Administer tocolytics and wait for 1 week
Reassure the mother as these maybe a normal finding near term

questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is vasa previa and CTG given shows a sinusoidal pattern. An emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes is done.

The sinusoidal pattern is associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis. Sonography points towards fetal anemia as the peak systolic velocity is raised in the middle cerebral artery and the presence of velamentous cord attachment supports the diagnosis of vasa pevia. Prompt action needs to be taken as this may signify impending fetal death. Delivery is done promptly, in case the bleeding is identified to be from the fetus. 

Causes of sinusoidal pattern on CTG are :

  • Fetal intracranial hemorrhage
  • Fetal asphyxia
  • Fetal anemia due to:
    • Anti-D alloimmunization,
    • Fetomaternal hemorrhage,
    • Twin-Twin transfusion syndrome,
    • Fetal parvoviral infection, or
    • Vasa previa with bleeding.
 Features of the sinusoidal wave pattern in CTG
  • Stable baseline fetal heart rate of 120-160 bpm
  • Amplitude of 5-15 bpm
  • The sinusoidal waveform above and below the baseline FHR persisting for 20 minutes or more
  • Absent acceleration
  • Absent or fixed short term variability

A transient intrapartum sine wavelike baseline varia­tion with periods of acceleration is known as a pseudo sinusoidal wave pattern. This is seen with the administration of meperidine, epidural analgesia, fetal sucking, umbilical cord compression, etc.

Vasa previa is a condition that occurs due to tearing of vessels either spontaneously or during rupture of the membrane in velamentous cord insertion. It is associated with high fetal mortality. Diagnosis can be made by color-flow Doppler (TVS), Singer’s alkali denaturation test, Apt test. CTG shows a sinusoidal wave pattern.

Management:

  • For bleeding vasa previa, delivery should be done by category-1 emergency cesarean section within 30 minutes.
  • A case of confirmed vasa previa at term (37 weeks) should be delivered by elective cesarean section prior to the onset of labor.
  • A neonatal blood transfusion may be needed.
  • Admit at 28–32 weeks of gestation. Antenatal corticosteroids should be given for fetal lung maturity.

The CTG given below shows early decelerations which are seen in fetal head compression due to uterine contraction.

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

The below given CTG shows late decelerations. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Given below is an image of the velamentous attachment of the umbilical cord:

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are seen in?
questions.solution:
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies are characteristic of malakoplakia.

It appears as laminated, basophilic concretions containing calcium deposits within the macrophages. The macrophages are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive.

Malakoplakia is a chronic inflammatory reaction resulting from acquired defects in phagocyte function affecting the urinary bladder. It can also be seen in other organ systems like the gastrointestinal tract, female genital tract, and central nervous system. It is seen in chronic bacterial infection, mostly by Escherichia coli or occasionally Proteus species. Grossly, malakoplakia takes the form of soft, yellow, slightly raised mucosal plaques. 

On microscopy, large, foamy macrophages with multinucleated giant cells and lymphocytes are observed. The macrophages have granular cytoplasm due to undigested bacterial products. Intracellular deposition of calcium within enlarged lysosomes form laminated basophilic concretions, known as Michaelis–Gutmann bodies.

Image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies seen as concentric basophilic inclusions within macrophages.

Other options:

Option A - Chronic pyelonephritis is a chronic condition characterized by tubulointerstitial inflammation and scarring. On microscopy, thyroidization of cortical tubules is seen with dilated tubules, flattened epithelium, and colloid casts within them as shown below.

Option C - Urothelial carcinomas are seen commonly in the urinary bladder. On microscopy, various grades of disorganized urothelium are seen with enlarged and pleomorphic nuclei as shown below:

Option D - Myeloma kidney is also known as light chain cast nephropathy occurring in patients suffering from multiple myeloma. On microscopy, the light chain casts appear as pink masses, often fractured, and surrounded by macrophages and multinucleated cells as shown below:

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with raised violaceous purple plaques on his buccal mucosa. He gave a history of undergoing a transplantation surgery a few months back and a provisional diagnosis of transplant-associated Kaposi sarcoma was considered. Which of the following statement is false regarding the same?
questions.solution:
The false statement about transplant-related Kaposi sarcoma is decreased risk in immunocompromised patients. 

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) and is very common in patients suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). KS is considered to be an AIDS-defining disease. 

Transplant-associated KS is more common after solid organ transplant patients receive immunosuppression as compared to the marrow or stem-cell transplant patients. There is a 100-fold greater risk in immunocompromised patients and has an aggressive course involving lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera. Cutaneous lesions may be absent. Lesions decrease as immunosuppression is reduced and rapamycin can also be used for management.

The other forms of KS are:

  • Classic Kaposi sarcoma: This occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent and has the following three clinical stages:
    • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
    • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
    • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.
  • Endemic African KS: It is common in Central Africa. This occurs in HIV-seronegative individuals, usually aged below 40 years. Lymph node involvement is more common than in classic variant and is very aggressive in prepubertal children with 100% mortality in 3 years.
  • AIDS-associated KS: KS is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. AIDS-associated KS often involves lymph nodes and disseminates widely to the viscera early in its course; most patients eventually die of opportunistic infections rather than KS.

The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

Related Pearl: Classification of Kaposi sarcoma

Endemic African

  • Seen in HIV seronegative individuals
  • Predominant lymph node and visceral involvement

Transplant associated

  • Solid organ transplant recipients
  • Involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera
  • Cutaneous lesions may be absent

AIDS-associated epidemic KS

  • HIV infected individuals
  • Involves lymph nodes

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with vomiting. He was prescribed metoclopramide, following which he developed spasms of facial muscles, difficulty in speech, and torticollis. Which of the following drugs is indicated for the treatment of these symptoms?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has developed symptoms of dystonia due to metoclopramide. Diphenhydramine is used in drug-induced dystonia.

Metoclopramide has dopamine receptor antagonist, 5HT4 agonist, and 5HT3 antagonist properties. It is indicated in patients with gastroparesis and is also used in reducing nausea and vomiting that often accompany GI dysmotility syndromes.

Dopamine receptor antagonist property is responsible for extrapyramidal symptoms. The dystonic reaction is one of the extrapyramidal symptoms. Features include spasms of muscles of the tongue, face, neck, and back. It can be treated with diphenhydramine or benztropine.

Other extrapyramidal symptoms include parkinsonian-like symptoms that may occur several weeks after initiation of therapy. It responds to treatment with anticholinergic or antihistaminic drugs and reverses on discontinuation of metoclopramide. Tardive dyskinesia can develop in patients treated for a prolonged period with metoclopramide.

Other options:

Option A: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor. It inhibits MAOA and MAOB to prevent the breakdown of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin. It is used in the treatment of major depression. The major adverse effects include weight gain, sexual dysfunction, and hypertensive crisis if taken along with tyramine-containing foods/ beverages.

Option C: Chlorpromazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist and is classified under typical antipsychotics. They are noted to improve the positive symptoms of schizophrenia and acute mania. The major adverse effects are extrapyramidal side effects, sedation, weight gain, hypotension, metabolic adverse effects, and photosensitivity.

Option D: Prochlorperazine is a dopamine receptor antagonist which is used as an anti-emetic. It is mainly used in motion sickness. The main adverse events are extrapyramidal symptoms including dystonia, cardiac effects, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient who is on oral contraceptive pills presents with fever, headache, and double vision. On doing a contrast-enhanced CT scan, the following image was seen. Identify the sign seen in this image.
questions.solution:
The empty delta sign is seen in the given image. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cerebral venous thrombosis.

In this patient, cerebral venous thrombosis is most likely to have occurred due to oral contraceptive pills. Cerebral infection, local trauma, dehydration, pregnancy, smoking, and vasculitis are some other common reasons for cerebral venous thrombosis.

The 'empty delta' sign is a CT sign of dural venous sinus thrombosis of the superior sagittal sinus, where the thrombus becomes less dense and the contrast outlines a triangular filling defect (clot) within the sinus lumen. It is only described with contrast-enhanced CT-scan or MRI, not with non-contrast CT(NCCT) or non-contrast MRI.

On doing an NCCT scan, an acutely thrombosed sinus appears hyperdense and expanded. This is called the 'delta sign'. It also gives a cordlike hyper-attenuation within a dural venous sinus giving the 'cord sign' of cerebral venous thrombosis.

Other options: 

Option B: Pseudo-delta sign is a hyperdense extra-axial triangular image surrounding the low density of superior sagittal sinus on an NCCT scan. This is seen in subarachnoid hemorrhage. 

Option D: Double delta sign is seen on an MRI in a bucket-handle meniscal tear when the inner meniscal fragment is flipped anteriorly adjacent to the anterior horn of the donor site.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was admitted for evaluation of fever. However, there were inconsistencies in the mother's reporting of medical information. Further exploration revealed that she had taken her child to multiple hospitals giving varying histories of lupus, asthma, etc that prompted excessive testing. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the inaccurate histories given by the mother to prompt excessive testing on the child, point towards a diagnosis of factitious disorder by proxy (DSM-5 diagnosis of "Factitious Disorder Imposed on Another").

The most common case of factitious disorder by proxy involves a mother who deceives medical personnel into believing that her child is ill. Here, the affected person intentionally produces physical signs or symptoms in another person who is under his own care. One apparent purpose of the behavior is for the caretaker to indirectly assume the sick role.

questions.text: The ultrasound findings in a monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy are indicative of poly-oli syndrome. What is the pathology seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
In poly - oli or polyhydramnios - oligohydramnios syndrome, the basic pathology is the presence of a deep artery-vein anastomosis.

TTTS can present as poly-oli syndrome or twin oligohydramnios polyhydramnios syndrome (TOPS). This is usually seen in mid-pregnancy. In this syndrome, there is decreased donor renal perfusion, causing oliguria and oligohydramnios. Because of the anastomosis, the recipient twin has increased renal perfusion and increased urine production causing polyhydramnios.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man likes a female television anchor and follows her on all her social media accounts. He tries to speak to her several times while she goes for a morning jog and messages her multiple times on social media. She warns him to stop following her, but he ignores it and continues with such behavior. Under which IPC section can the female anchor lodge a complaint?

IPC - Indian penal code
questions.solution:
The anchor lodges a complaint under the IPC section 354-D. This section deals with stalking.

Under this section, stalking is defined as whoever follows a woman and contacts or tries to contact such woman to make personal interaction repeatedly, despite the woman showing clear disinterest or monitors the internet usage, e-mail or any other electronic mode of communication of that woman.

Section 354 IPC- Lays down punishment for assault or criminal force to a woman with intent to outrage her modesty. Punishment includes imprisonment of 1-5 years and a fine.

The subsections include:

  • 354A– Sexual harassment in the form of physical contact or sexual gestures, request or demand for sexual favours, making sexual remarks, and showing pornography. Punishment includes imprisonment of 1-5 years or fine or both
  • 354B– Assault or criminal force on a female with intent to disrobe her. Punishment includes imprisonment of 3-7 years and a fine.
  • 354C– Voyeurism: One who observes an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity in order to attain sexual gratification. Punishment for the first offence is imprisonment of 1-3 years and a fine. Punishment for subsequent offences includes imprisonment of 3-7 years.
  • 354D– Stalking. Punishment includes imprisonment up to 3 years and a fine.

questions.text: Accidental ingestion of the insect shown below is associated with which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
The insect is identified as the Spanish fly. Accidental consumption is associated with priapism.

Spanish fly is a winged insect with a length of 2 cm and a breadth of 0.6 cm with greenish-black color and shiny wings. It contains the toxic active principle cantharidin.

The active principle can be absorbed through the skin and all mucosa. On local application to the skin or mucosa, it is associated with redness of skin, and burning pain followed by vesication of the skin. The sequela of cantharides ingestion involves priapism. Features of this poisoning are severe thirst, dysphagia, priapism, genital pain, tenesmus, and convulsions resulting in coma and death. Abortion can occur if the woman is pregnant.

Treatment is symptomatic and if ingested, stomach wash needs to be done along with the administration of demulcents.

Other Options: 

Option A: Acrodynia is seen in chronic mercury poisoning, in which there is pain and pink discoloration of the hands and feet.

Option C: Raindrop pigmentation is a finely mottled brown change on skin flexures, temples, eyelids, and necks seen in arsenic poisoning.

Option D: Magnan’s sign is seen in cocaine addicts where they experience and interpret paraesthesia as the constant movement of a foreign body or bugs under their skin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a persistent cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, chest pain, and dyspnea. He is a chronic smoker. On evaluation, a chest x-ray revealed a mass in his right lung and a biopsy of the mass revealed the following picture. Blood examination revealed leukocytosis with no tumor markers. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is large cell carcinoma of the lung.

The given clinical features, with the absence of tumor markers, leukocytosis, and the histopathological image showing large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate cytoplasm point to the diagnosis of large cell carcinoma of the lung. 

Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor. Typical cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer are absent. This type of lung cancer does not express any of the tumor markers associated with adenocarcinoma (TTF-1, napsin A) or squamous cell carcinoma (p40, p63). On microscopy, the features described above are observed.

Tumor-related leukocytosis is commonly seen as a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with large cell carcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option A - Adenocarcinoma is an invasive malignant epithelial tumor. Histopathological examination shows various patterns, including acinar, papillary, lepidic, micropapillary, and solid. A histopathological image of adenocarcinoma of the lung showing glandular differentiation is given below:


Option B - Small cell carcinomas are highly malignant tumors with a strong association with cigarette smoking. Histopathological examination shows relatively small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin in a salt-and-pepper pattern, and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli.

Azzopardi effect is the basophilic staining of vessel walls due to DNA residue deposited from necrotic tumor cells, as seen below:


Option D - Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant tumor associated with smoking. Histopathological examination is characterized by the presence of keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization is seen as squamous pearls or individual cells with markedly eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is a high mitotic activity in poorly differentiated tumors.

The image given below shows squamous pearls seen in squamous cell carcinomas.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presented with shortness of breath, easy fatiguability, and swelling of lower limbs. On auscultation, a loud S1 without a fixed S2 split, a high pitched sound after S2, and a diastolic murmur were heard. On obtaining an X-ray, the following image is seen. Which of the following can cause the radiological finding given in the image?
questions.solution:
Mitral stenosis causes the above radiological finding i.e., enlargement of the left atrial appendage.

The auscultatory findings of mitral stenosis include an accentuated S1 with a closely split S2. After the S2, a high-pitched sound called the opening snap is heard most readily in expiration. Following the opening snap, a low-pitched, diastolic murmur is best heard at the apex when the patient is in the left lateral recumbent position. 

Left atrial enlargement occurs due to some underlying conditions. They are:

  • Acquired conditions
    • Mitral stenosis
    • Mitral regurgitation
    • Atrial fibrillation 
    • Left atrial myxoma
    • Left ventricular failure
  • Congenital conditions
    • Ventricular septal defect
    • Patent ductus arteriosus

Some of the radiographical signs seen in left atrial enlargement are:

  • Enlargement of the left atrial appendage is seen and as it is the only portion of the left atrium that makes up the left heart border, it results in a straight left border (as shown below)
  • Double density sign or double atrial shadow is the enlarged left atrium extending towards the right cardiac border. Hence, both right atrium and left atrium borders can be seen distinctly over the right heart border (as shown below)
  • Widening of the angle of the carina and upward deviation of the left main bronchus
  • Posterior displacement of the esophagus - seen on the lateral view of barium swallow study

The below X-ray shows the double density sign and widening of the carina:

 

Other options:

Option A- Atrial septal defect has a loud S1 with wide fixed S2 split on auscultation. It has an ejection systolic murmur. It causes enlargement of the right side of the heart and not the left atrium.

Option C- Pulmonary stenosis has a mid-systolic murmur and causes enlargement of the right side of the heart.

Option D- Tricuspid stenosis has a diastolic murmur like mitral stenosis but causes enlargement of the right atrium.

questions.text: According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, what is the recommended dose limit for occupational radiation workers?
questions.solution:
The recommended dose limit of occupational radiation workers according to AERB of India is 30mSv in any year with an average of 100mSv in 5 consecutive years.

According to the International Commission on Radiological Protection(ICRP), the recommended dose limit of occupational radiation workers is 20mSv per year averaged over 5 consecutive years with no single year exceeding 50mSv.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have acute interstitial nephritis. Which of the following urinalysis findings is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
In acute interstitial nephritis (AIN), white blood cell casts and hematuria are most likely to be seen on urine analysis. 

AIN usually occurs as an allergic response to certain medications. Offending agents include beta-lactam antibiotics like methicillin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, proton pump inhibitors, sulfonamide derivatives, diuretics, antiepileptic (phenytoin, valproate), and sulfasalazine. 

Individuals with AIN are usually asymptomatic and are incidentally found to have elevated creatinine. However, in some instances, they can develop fever and rash. In severe cases, renal failure with proteinuria can occur. 

Laboratory studies may show peripheral eosinophilia and urinary eosinophilia. However, these are not specific or sensitive enough to serve as diagnostic criteria. 

Treatment depends on how severe AIN is. Milder cases can be treated by stopping the offending drug. More severe cases require hospitalization and follow-up. 

Other options: 

Option A- Muddy granular casts are seen in acute tubular necrosis. This occurs as a result of direct tubular epithelial injury ischemia or toxins. 

Option B - Hyaline casts are seen in prerenal azotemia. This occurs as a result of decreased renal blood flow to the kidneys. 

Option D - Red blood cell casts are seen in acute glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Urinary Casts and Their Significance

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman underwent hysterectomy 3 weeks back. She now presents with constant dribbling of urine. The tampon test was positive. A genitourinary fistula was suspected and cystourethroscopy showed that the fistulous opening was 1.7 cm away from the external urinary meatus. What type of fistula is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of a fistulous opening 1.7 cm away from the external urinary meatus is classified as a Type III genitourinary fistula.

A genitourinary fistula (GUF) is defined as an abnormal communication between the urinary (ureters, bladder, urethra) and the genital (uterus, cervix, vagina) systems. Obstetric trauma such as prolonged or obstructed labor accounts for the majority of cases of GUF in developing countries, whereas iatrogenic injury during surgeries such as hysterectomy is the most common cause of GUFs in developed countries.

Although GUFs can be classified in many ways, a comprehensive and standardized classification system has been developed as follows:

Based on fistula distance from the external urethral meatus:

  • Type 1: Distal edge of fistula > 3.5 cm from the external urinary meatus
  • Type 2: Distal edge of fistula 2.5–3.5 cm from the external urinary meatus
  • Type 3: Distal edge of fistula 1.5 to < 2.5 cm from the external urinary meatus
  • Type 4: Distal edge of fistula < 1.5 cm from the external urinary meatus

Based on the size/largest diameter:

  1. Size < 1.5 cm
  2. Size 1.5-3 cm
  3. Size > 3 cm 

Based on degree of fibrosis:

  1. None or only mild fibrosis (around fistula and/or vagina) and/or vaginal length > 6 cm
  2. Moderate or severe fibrosis (around fistula and/or vagina) and/or reduced vaginal length 
  3. Special consideration, e.g., post-radiation, ureteric involvement, circumferential fistula, or previous repair.

Clinical presentation:

  • Unexplained continuous urinary leakage from the vagina after a recent operation.
  • A vesicovaginal fistula may present days to weeks after the initial inciting surgery, and those following hysterectomy typically present after 1 to 3 weeks.
  • Unusual symptoms are fever, pain, ileus, and bladder irritability.

Diagnosis:

  • History and physical examination are suggestive of the diagnosis in most of the cases.
  • Tampon test / 3-swab test - In this test a solution of methylene blue is instilled into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After routine activity for about 20 minutes, the tampon is removed and inspected. Blue discoloration at the top suggests a high lying fistula whereas blue discoloration at the bottom suggests a low-lying fistula.
  • Cystourethroscopy - This is very useful to localize fistulas, determine proximity to the urethral meatus, number and sites of fistulae, and visualize bladder mucosa.
  • Urine culture is mandatory before surgery
  • USG - Kidney ureter and bladder
  • Intravenous pyelography (IVP)
  • Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) can help confirm the presence, location, and the number of fistulous tracts.

The image given below shows the 3-swab test:

Management:

  • Conservative management using an indwelling catheter
  • Surgical management if indicated should be carried out in the first 24-48 hours following inciting surgery. In cases of extensive inflammation, surgery should be carried out after 6 weeks. The various surgical approaches used are:
    • Lazko's vaginal approach
    • Abdominal approach
    • Chassar Moir technique for vescicovaginal fistula.
    • Interpositional flaps - Omental J-flap in abdominal approach and Martius bulbocavernosus fat pad flap in vaginal approach
    • Ureteric reimplantation to the sigmoid colon, creating an ileal loop bladder or a rectal bladder

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false with respect to the inverse stretch reflex?
questions.solution:
Option D is a false statement as the inverse stretch reflex can be stimulated by a passive stretch as well as an active contraction.

When the tension in the muscle increases and surpasses a limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex.

The receptor involved in this reflex is the Golgi tendon organ (Option B). The Golgi tendon organ consists of a net-like collection of nerve endings that are arranged in series (Option C) within the muscle fibers. This arrangement allows for Golgi tendon organs to be stimulated by both active contraction and passive stretch of the muscle, unlike muscle spindles. One Golgi tendon organ innervates 3-25 muscle fibers. 

The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex (Option A).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with ptosis of his right eye. His levator function is estimated to be 7 mm. Which of the following would be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Levator advancement would be done in a patient with a residual levator function of 7 mm.

In this procedure, the levator complex is shortened either anteriorly (skin) or posteriorly (conjunctival approach). The indication is that the levator function has to be at least 5mm. 

Ptosis is described as congenital or acquired drooping of the eyelid. 

Causes of ptosis include:

  • Neurogenic: Third cranial nerve palsy, Horner's syndrome
  • Myogenic: Myasthenia gravis, myotonic dystrophy, neuromuscular junction transmission issues
  • Aponeurotic: Occurs due to a defect in the levator aponeurosis
  • Mechanical: Due to a mass or scarring. 

The degree of ptosis is measured by the palpebral fissure height. This is the distance between the upper and lower eyelids. Normally, it is 7-10 mm in males and 8-12 mm in females. 

Degree Opening (compared to normal eye)
Mild 2mm
Moderate 3mm
Severe 4mm

Levator function can also be used to determine ptosis. Here, the examiner places their thumb against the patient's brow while the patient is looking down. This stops the action of the frontalis muscle. Then the patient looks up as far as possible. The movement is measured. It is considered normal if it moved 15 mm or more, good if it moves 12-14 mm, fair if it moves 5-11 mm, and poor if it moves 4 mm or less. 

Other options:

Option A - Conjunctiva-Muller resection is performed by excising the Muller muscle and the conjunctiva that overlies it. It can only improve levator function by 2-3 mm so it can only be used if the levator function is at least 10 mm. 

Option C - Frontalis suspension or brown suspension is done in severe ptosis where levator function is less than 4 mm. Here, the tarsal plate is suspended by a sling from the frontalis muscle. 

Option D - Eyelid crutches keep the eyelid open. They are a nonsurgical option. However, they interfere with the blinking mechanism and looks unnatural.

questions.text: A 4-year-old female child is currently under evaluation for supra-valvular aortic stenosis and mental retardation. A characteristic facies is present as shown in the image below. Her karyotype reveals 46XX and her blood investigations reveal hypercalcemia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of mental retardation, elfin facies, hypercalcemia, and supravalvular aortic stenosis is strongly suggestive of Williams' syndrome.

The image shows a young girl with an elfin face with a round face, full cheeks, broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, thick lips, and a large mouth that is usually left open. They also have short palpebral fissures, prominent ears, and a small mandible. 

It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple congenital development defects, including supra-valvular aortic stenosis, mental retardation, and an elfin facies, in association with hypercalcemia due to abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D with elevated levels of 1,25(OH)2D ranging from 150 to 500 pg/mL.

Williams' syndrome is caused due to genetic mutations involving microdeletions at the elastin locus on chromosome 7. 

Other options-

Option A: DiGeorge syndrome is caused due to deletion of chromosome 22q11.2. The characteristic features are (Mnemonic CATCH-22) Cardiac abnormality, abnormal facies, thymic aplasia, cleft palate, hypocalcemia, deletion 22q11.2.

The following image shows a child with DiGeorge syndrome:

 

Option C: Down syndrome occurs due to trisomy of chromosome 21 leading to multisystem manifestations. There is a wide range of presentations. A few key features include characteristic facies such as flat face, epicanthal folds, small head, flat nasal bridge, upward slanting palpebral fissues, brushfield spots, small nose, protruding tongue, small and lowset ears. Congenital heart defects can also be present. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Down syndrome:

 

Option D: Edward syndrome is a trisomy of chromosome 18. It is characterized by microcephaly, microphthalmia, prominent nasal bridge, coloboma of iris, microretrognathia, cleft lip, cleft palate, clenched fist with overlapping fingers, and severe growth retardation. This patient has a normal karyotype.

The following image shows a child with Edward syndrome, note the clenched fist with overlapping fingers:

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

questions.text: Which among the following would you use for the measurement of intraocular pressure in a patient with a scarred cornea?
questions.solution:
Tonopen is used for measuring intraocular pressure (IOP) in a scarred cornea.

It is a hand-held electronic contact tonometer (a modified version of the older Mackay–Marg tonometer). Besides portability, its main advantage is the ability to measure IOP reasonably accurately in eyes with distorted or edematous corneas and through a soft contact lens.

Types of tonometry:

  • Indentation tonometry- Reading depends on scleral rigidity, e.g., Schiotz tonometer  
  • Applanation tonometry- Based on the amount of force needed to flatten or applanate a known area of the cornea, Imbert–Fick principle. This is further divided into two types -
    • Fixed force: IOP is proportional to the area, e.g., Maklakov, Barraquer
    • Fixed area and variable force: IOP is proportional to force. The most reliable is Goldmann.
  • Self-measurement: Rebound
  • Non-contact type: Pulse Air, Air-Puff
  • Irregular cornea: Tonopen, MacKay–Marg

Recent tonometers:

  • Pascals tonometer (dynamic contour tonometry [DCT]): Contact; used for post-LASIK IOP measurement.
  • Reichert Ocular Response Analyzer®: Non-contact

Note: Tonography is a non-invasive technique for determining the facility of aqueous outflow.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms are not involved in the silencing of potentially autoreactive T cells in the peripheral circulation?
questions.solution:
Receptor editing is not involved in the silencing of potentially autoreactive T cells in the peripheral circulation.

Immunologic tolerance is defined as the property of unresponsiveness to an antigen, which is induced by the exposure of lymphocytes to that antigen. This is broadly classified into two mechanisms:

  1. Central tolerance
  2. Peripheral tolerance

Central tolerance: In this mechanism, immature self-reactive T and B lymphocyte cells are killed during their maturation in the central lymphoid organs (the thymus for T cells and the bone marrow for B cells). The mechanism by which this takes place is:

  • Negative selection or clonal deletion - Immature T cells express T-cell receptors for self-antigens. When these cells come in contact with such antigens in the thymus, signals are produced that mediate the killing of such T-cells by apoptosis. A protein called AIRE (autoimmune regulator) is involved in this process. Germline loss-of-function mutations in the AIRE gene cause autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome. 
  • Receptor editing - Developing B cells recognize antigens in the bone marrow. When such cells recognize self-antigens, it reactivates antigen receptor gene rearrangement mechanism and expresses a new antigen receptor that is not specific to the self-antigen.

Peripheral tolerance: This mechanism is involved in silencing potentially autoreactive T and B cells in peripheral tissue. It involves the following mechanisms:

  • Anergy - The phenomenon of rendering self-reacting lymphocytes functionally unresponsive is known as anergy. This is due to the absence or weak exposure of costimulatory signals when antigens are presented to the T cells. CD28 binding to its ligands B7-1 and B7-2 are examples of costimulatory signals. Anergy also affects mature B cells.
  • Suppression by regulatory T cells - The regulatory CD4+ T cells express high levels of CD25, the α chain of the IL-2 receptor, and FOXP3, a transcription factor. The inhibitory activity of these cells is due to the secretion of immunosuppressive cytokines such as IL-10 and TGF-β. Mutations in FOXP3 result in an autoimmune disease called IPEX (an acronym for immune dysregulation, polyendocrinopathy, enteropathy, X-linked).
  • Deletion by apoptosis - T cell apoptosis in the periphery is by two main mechanisms:
    • Mitochondrial pathway - By the expression of pro-apoptotic factor Bim without anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 and Bcl-6.
    • Death receptor pathway - By Fas-Fas ligand interaction.

questions.text:
An alleged female convict is arrested for a crime she did not commit. She was tortured by the investigating officer and was raped by him in police custody. Under which section will the inquest be done in this scenario?

IPC - Indian Penal Code

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of custodial rape. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

Custodial rape is defined as the offence committed by persons who are in supervisory positions indulging in sexual intercourse with women in their custody by inducing or seducing the woman by taking advantage of his official position.

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Custodial rape
  • Death in police custody or police interrogation
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Dowry death
  • Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A- BNS Section 63 (Section 375 IPC)deals with the definition of rape. In BNS 63, the Age of Consent of 15 years is replaced by 18 years in BNS. Exception 2 of Section 63 states that “sexual intercourse or acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under 18 years of age, is not rape”.

Option B- BNS Section 68 (Section 376 IPC) deals with the punishment of rape by a person in authority. It is termed custodial rape.

Option D- BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy complains of bony pain and swelling in his left upper arm for 3 months. On plain X-ray, the following findings were seen. What is the most likely gene mutation involved in this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray findings of sunray appearance are suggestive of osteosarcoma.  The most likely gene mutation is p53 mutation.

p53 and RB gene mutations are involved in osteosarcoma and sporadic cases have also been associated with mutations in the CHEK2 gene.

RAS, APC, PTEN gene mutations do not have a strong association with osteosarcoma.

Osteosarcoma is a primary malignant bone tumor, osteosarcoma has a bimodal age distribution, in adolescence (10–14 years) and again in the seventh decade. Osteosarcoma typically metaphyseal or metadiaphyseal, the majority present at the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus
Radiological features of osteosarcoma:

  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone
  • Lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumor centrifugally gives rise to ‘sunburst appearance’ 
  • Other forms of periosteal reaction commonly seen are Codman’s triangle.

Limb salvage surgeries are preferred over amputation. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgical resection and adjuvant chemotherapy is the preferred treatment. The principal first-line chemotherapeutic agents used in osteosarcoma are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presented with purulent discharge from an opening located in the perianal region. The patient is placed in a lithotomy position, and the external opening is found to be located at the 11 o'clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. What will be the likely position of the internal opening?
questions.solution:
The likely location of the internal opening is the 6'O clock position, which is the posterior midline of the anal canal.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fistula-in-ano, with the external opening located at the 11’O clock position, 4 cm from the anal margin. This means that the anal margin is located anterior to the coronal midsection. The location of the internal opening of the fistula can be identified using Goodsall's rule.

Goodsall’s rule:

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly tract in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur. Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

Thus, according to the exception to Goodsall's rule, this patient likely has an internal opening at the 6'O clock position as the external opening is located more than 3 cm from the anal margin track. 

A fistula-in-ano is a chronic abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue. It has a primary internal opening in the anorectal lumen and a secondary external opening in the perianal skin. An anal fistula may be present if the patient has Crohn's disease, tuberculosis, malignancy, foreign body, lymphogranuloma venereum, or actinomycosis. Patients usually present with intermittent discharge and pain. 

Intersphincteric fistulas are the most common type. Other types of anal fistulae are transsphincteric fistula, suprasphincteric fistula, and extrasphincteric fistula.

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight woman presents with the complaint that she compulsively eats large amounts of food, sometimes even when she is not hungry. Following such episodes, she feels very guilty and uncomfortably full. Most of these episodes occur when she's alone at night. She does not induce vomiting after the episodes.  Which of the following will help reduce such episodes in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to be suffering from bingeeating disorder. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) will help reduce binge-eating episodes. 

CBT has been shown to decrease binge eating episodes as well as the anxiety and depression that accompany this disorder. CBT cannot be used alone in treatment as it does not help with weight loss. Combining CBT with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) has shown good results. 

DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for Binge-eating disorder:

A. Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both of the following:

1. Eating, in a discrete period, an amount of food that is larger than what most people would eat in a similar period under similar circumstances.

2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

B. The binge-eating episodes are associated with

1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.

2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.

3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.

4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.

5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

C. Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.

D. The binge eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

E. binge eating is not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

Binge eating disorder can be classified into mild, moderate, severe, and extreme based on the number of episodes per week:

Severity Episodes/week
Mild 1-3/week
Moderate 4-7/week
Severe 8-13/week
Extreme >14/week

Other options:

Option A - Increased physical activity is a useful way to lose weight because of the increased caloric expenditure. However, it would not reduce the number of binge eating episodes. 

Option B - Hospitalization is the treatment for those with severe anorexia nervosa. This is done to restore nutritional, fluid, and electrolyte status as well as determine a long-term plan of management. 

Option D - Calorie restriction is done in patients who are overweight. However, calorie restriction will not reduce the number of episodes of binge eating.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the percentage of disease-free people being correctly identified as healthy by a test?
questions.solution:
Specificity represents the percentage of disease-free people being correctly identified as healthy by a test.

It is given by the formula:

Specificity = (Number testing positive who do not have the disease / total number tested who do not have the disease ) ×100 

  Specificity Negative predictive value
Given by    TN     
FP + TN		    TN     
FN + TN
Numerator

TN- The number of healthy people correctly identified by the given test

TN- The number of healthy people correctly identified by the given test
Denominator FP+TN= The actual number of healthy people (as identified by the gold standard test) FN+TN= The total number of people tested negative by the given test
  Compares the number of true negatives detected by the test among the people who actually do not have the disease. Compares the actual number of true negatives among the people who tested negative according to the given test 

Other options: 

Option A - Sensitivity of test is the percentage of people with a disease who are correctly detected or classified.

Option C - Positive predictive value of a test is the proportion of positive results that are true positives, that is, the likelihood that a person with a positive test result truly has the disease.

Option D - Negative predictive value is the proportion of negative results that are true negatives.

The negative predictive value of a test compares the actual number of disease-free people (obtained from gold standard test) to the number of people who tested disease-free by the given test.

It represents the likelihood that a person with a negative result truly does not have the disease. It reflects the number of tests that have correctly identified a person to be free of the disease.

Note: True positives and true negatives are identified based on the gold standard test for the given condition.

Related Pearl: Evaluation of diagnostic tests

Different ways of asking the following parameters:

Sensitivity (True positive rate) 

  • Percentage of diseased individuals who are correctly identified (as diseased).
  • Proportion of all people with the disease who test positive.
  • Probability that when the disease is present, the test is positive.

Specificity (True negative rate) 

  • Percentage of healthy individuals who are correctly identified (as healthy).
  • Proportion of all people without the disease who test negative.
  • Probability that when the disease is absent, the test is negative.

Positive predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a positive test result actually has the disease.
  • If the test is positive, what is the probability that the patient has the disease?

Negative predictive value 

  • Probability that a person who has a negative test result actually does not have the disease.
  • If the test is negative, what is the probability that the patient does not have the disease?

questions.text: A 36-year-old female patient was undergoing diagnostic dilatation and curettage. The instrument given below is used to expose the cervix prior to cervical dilatation. Identify the given instrument.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Sims' speculum.

The Sims’ vaginal speculum with an anterior vaginal wall retractor can be used for examination of the cervix. This is used to expose the cervix prior to cervical dilatation. It is used for the assessment of the vaginal wall for cystocele and rectocele. 

Option B - Cusco's speculum is a bivalve self-retaining speculum, ideal for an office examination. It allows satisfactory inspection of the cervix, obtaining a Pap smear, and collection of the vaginal discharge from the posterior fornix. An image of Cusco's speculum is given below

Option C - Auvard speculum is a heavy retractor provided with a heavy metal ball and is self-retaining. It is used in vaginal hysterectomy to retract the posterior vaginal wall. A channel is provided in the handle to collect the blood and drain it. An image of the Auvard speculum is given below.

Doyen's retractor is used to retract the abdominal wall as well as the bladder to facilitate better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarian operation. It is also used to pull back the soft tissues to widen the surgical field during laparotomy.

The image below shows Doyen's retractor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old rice farmer presented with a high-grade fever, diarrhea, seizures, tremors, and vomiting. The physician suspects an illness transmitted by the mosquito shown below.  Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Wings are unspotted in adult stage
Siphon tube is present in larval stage
Rests parallel to the water surface in larval stage

questions.solution:
The image shown is of the Culex species of mosquito due to unspotted wings and hunched back. The false statement about the Culex mosquito is - rests parallel to the water surface in the larval stage.

The rice farmer presents with features of acute encephalitis and non-specific features like fever, cough, and diarrhea, the most likely diagnosis is Japanese encephalitis. 

The Culex mosquitoes are vectors or carriers for Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, and viral arthritis. 

In the larval stage, they are suspended with head downwards at an angle, a siphon tube is present, and there is absence of palmate hairs. They lay the eggs in clusters, and adult mosquitoes have their wings unspotted with hunched back.

Various mosquito larvae are shown in the image below. Siphon tube is present in Aedes and Culex, whereas, it is absent in Anopheles.

 

Japanese encephalitis (JE) is the most prevalent cause of viral encephalitis in Asia. It is a mosquito-borne zoonotic disease caused by Flavivirus. It is transmitted mainly by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India) species.

JE is a zoonotic disease primarily affecting animals like pigs and ardeid birds. Pigs are considered the major vertebrate hosts and amplifiers for the JE virus. Humans are the dead-end hosts for this virus. When a mosquito bites an infected pig, the virus is transmitted to the mosquito. The virus, in turn, is transferred to other pigs or humans due to mosquito bites and this cycle continues. Horses are the only known domestic animals that present with signs of JE infection.

The control measures include mosquito control by areal or ground fogging with ultra-low-volume insecticides such as malathion and fenitrothion, locating piggeries away from the human dwellings, and vaccinating pigs. Ultra-low-volume fogging is a method of insecticide application where a small volume (<500 ml/hectare) of liquid insecticide is applied to provide maximum killing of disease vectors.

JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunisation Schedule.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 2.5 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications is less likely to be associated with this placental variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bilobed placenta, also known as placenta bilobate or bipartite placenta or placenta duplex. Fetal growth restriction is not a complication likely to be associated with this placental variant.

A bilobed placenta is described as the presence of two, almost equally sized placental lobes separated by a membrane, without significant vasculature present in between them. The umbilical cord may be inserted between the two placental lobes into the chorionic bridge, or into the intervening membranes, or in a velamentous fashion. The presence of more than two lobes is termed as multilobate placenta and is rare.

The complications associated with this placental variant:

  • First-trimester bleeding
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Abruption
  • Retained placenta

The types of placental variants:

  • Placenta succenturiata: One or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes. It is associated with complications like vasa previa, postpartum uterine atony, postpartum hemorrhage, and endometritis. An image of this variant is given below where L1,2,3 depicts smaller lobes, UC is the umbilical cord, and M is the intervening membrane. 
  • Placenta membranacea: Unduly large and thin placenta that develops from both the chorionic frondosum and the chorion leave. It is associated with an increased risk of placenta previa or accreta and retained placenta and its complications.
  • Ring-shaped placenta: This is a variant of placenta membranacea where a partial or complete ring of the placenta is present. This variant is associated with an increased risk of antepartum and postpartum bleeding and fetal-growth restric­tion.
  • Placenta fenestrata: In this, the central portion of a placental disc is missing.
  • Battledore placenta: In this, the umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than at the center. When inserted 2 cm away it is known as velamentous cord insertion. A specimen of battledore placenta is given below:
  • Extrachorial placentation: the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:
    • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.
    • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion. Complications associated with circumvallate placenta are preterm delivery, abortions, growth retardation, antepartum hemorrhage, retained placenta, and hydrorrhea gravidarum. questions.text:
A 1-week-old infant with ambiguous genitalia presents with hypertension. The infant is diagnosed with congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Which of the following findings will you see in this infant?

(ACTH- Adrenocorticotrophic hormone)
questions.solution:
Decreased androgen levels are seen in congenital adrenal hyperplasia with 17α-hydroxylase enzyme deficiency.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is an autosomal recessive disorder where adrenal steroid hormone synthesis is affected. There are many variants of CAH depending on enzyme deficiency. The most common enzyme deficiency is the 21-hydroxylase enzyme. 

Given below is the pathway and enzymes involved in adrenal steroid synthesis:

In the above image, we understand that 17 alpha-hydroxylase is required for the conversion of pregnenolone to 17 hydroxy pregnenolone and progesterone to 17 hydroxy progesterone. Pregnenolone and progesterone are further converted to cortisol and androgens. Therefore deficiency of this enzyme will lead to reduced levels of cortisol and androgens. The accumulated pregnenolone and progesterone lead to increased synthesis of aldosterone.

Patience will present with ambiguous genitalia due to a deficiency of androgens. Excessive aldosterone will lead to increased sodium retention, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Cortisol deficiency stimulates the pituitary and increases ACTH secretion, leading to adrenocortical hyperplasia. The ability to synthesize corticosterone from its precursor deoxycorticosterone is preserved in these patients.

Treatment:

  • It includes glucocorticoid replacement with hydrocortisone to control hypertension by suppressing deoxycorticosterone synthesis. 
  • Removal of intra-abdominal testes or orchidopexy to prevent malignant transformation and appropriate sex hormone replacement therapy at puberty depends on the sex of rearing.

questions.text:
A bedridden hemiplegic patient was brought to the hospital with å lesion over the back, as shown in the image. All of the following are true about the diagnosis, except _______.

VAC- Vacuum-assisted closure

choices.text: The most common site is the ischium.

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is bedsore or pressure sore. All of the above statements are true about pressure sores except stage 2 is full-thickness skin loss up.

Stage 2 corresponds to partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis.

Pressure sores, also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers, are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.

Staging system for the description of pressure sores:

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Below is the image showing the stages of pressure sore.

Management:

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. They can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Fecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases.

The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

questions.text: A 16 week pregnant female with a known history of seizures is found to have renal angiomyolipoma. On physical examination, white depigmented patches were seen on the back. Prenatal testing was done for the fetus that came positive for the TSC1 gene. The child is at risk of developing all of the complications except.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tuberous sclerosis and the child is not at risk of developing cerebellar hemangioblastoma. 

Cerebellar hemangioblastoma is found in Von-Hippel Lindau syndrome.

Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome 9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.

Skin lesions in tuberous sclerosis:

  • Hypomelanotic ash leaf–type macules 
  • Facial angiofibromas
  • Periungual fibromas are small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails or toenails
  • Shagreen patch consists of a roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, located primarily in the lumbosacral region
  • Confetti skin lesions are seen less commonly as a minor feature of tuberous sclerosis.

Other system involvement:

  • Epilepsy, intellectual disability, autism spectrum, subependymal giant cell astrocytomas
  • Cardiac rhabdomyoma
  • Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosis
  • Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese female patient is brought to the emergency room in a dehydrated state. She complains of loose stools for one week. On examination, there is a tender mass in the neck that she says has been present for one year. There are purple striae on her abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. 

The above clinical features of painful neck mass, diarrhea, and purplish striae on the abdomen indicating cushingoid habitus are suggestive of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of the MTC are sporadic but they may also be associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B. All the inherited variants are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50-60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), prostaglandins E2 and F2α, histaminadases, serotonin, and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Metastasis is blood-borne
  • Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma

Diagnosis is by careful family history, physical examination, raised calcitonin, CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass.

Total thyroidectomy with bilateral central neck node dissection is the treatment of choice in MTC patients. External beam radiotherapy can be used in patients with unresectable tumors. Targeted therapy against RET kinase can be considered using vandetanib, sorafenib, sunitinib, and cabozantinib.

For children with MEN 2A mutations, prophylactic total thyroidectomy should be considered before they turn five years old. For children with MEN 2B mutations, the same should be considered before they turn one. 

Other options:

Option A- Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is the most common thyroid malignancy. Metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread. Many patients are euthyroid and are associated with painless slow-growing mass in the neck. Dysphagia, dyspnea, and dysphonia are seen in locally advanced disease.

Option C- Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid is more commonly seen in iodine-deficient areas. They present as solitary thyroid nodules and are associated with a rapid increase in size. Pain is not common but can be seen if hemorrhage occurs into the nodule. Metastasis is bloodborne and lymph node involvement is not seen. FNAC cannot differentiate benign and malignant follicular lesions.

Option D- Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid is one of the most aggressive malignancies. It has rapid growth with visceral invasion and distant metastases. Prognosis is very poor and death usually occurs within 6 months.

  • Most common malignancy of thyroid associated with lymphatic spread – Papillary carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with blood and bone metastasis – Follicular carcinoma

  • Most common thyroid malignancy in iodine deficient areas – Follicular carcinoma
  • Most common thyroid malignancy associated with Multi Nodular Goiter - Follicular carcinoma

  • Minor extrathyroidal extension detected only on histological examination is removed from the definition of T3 disease and therefore has no impact on either T category or overall stage.
  • N1 disease no longer upstages a patient to stage III. If < 55 years of age at diagnosis, N1 disease is stage I. If ≥ 55 years of age, N1 disease is stage II.
  • T3a is a new category for tumors > 4 cm confined to the thyroid gland
  • T3b is a new category for tumors of any size demonstrating gross extrathyroidal extension into strap muscles (sternohyoid, sternothyroid, thyrohyoid or omohyoid muscles)
  • Level VII lymph nodes, previously classified as lateral neck lymph nodes (N1b) is re-classified as central neck lymph nodes (N1a) to be more anatomically consistent and because level VII presented significant coding difficulties for tumor registrars, clinicians and researchers.
  • In differentiated thyroid cancer, the presence of distant metastases (M1) in older patients is classified as IVB disease rather than IVC disease. Distant metastasis in anaplastic thyroid cancer continues to be classified as IVC disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man visits your outpatient clinic for a routine follow-up. Which of the following protocols would you use to assess his health literacy?
questions.solution:
The SPEAK protocol is used to assess health literacy in the geriatric population in a clinical setting.

Health literacy is defined as the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information needed to make appropriate health decisions. The SPEAK protocol provides a simple framework that healthcare providers can use to assess literacy. SPEAK stands for:

  • S - Speech
  • P - Perception
  • E - Education
  • A - Access
  • K - Knowledge

Option A: The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling (usually, family planning and reproductive counseling) to help people make decisions about health. It stands for:

  • G – Greet
  • A – Ask
  • T – Tell 
  • H – Help 
  • E – Explain 
  • R – Return 

Option C: The SPIKES protocol is used to convey distressing information and break bad news in an organized manner to patients and families. It stands for:

  • S - Setting
  • P - Perception
  • I - Invitation or information
  • K - Knowledge
  • E - Empathy
  • S - Summarizing or strategizing.

Option D: The S-BAR technique is used for prompt and appropriate communication among health care workers in hospital settings. It stands for:

  • S - Situation
  • B - Background
  • A - Assessment
  • R - Recommendation

questions.text: A patient with pulmonary tuberculosis comes for a follow-up. While presenting the history, you explain to the medical students that this is a case of chronic inflammation where macrophages predominate. Which of the following statements is false about the classical pathway of macrophage activation?

choices.text: Activation of this pathway is induced by endotoxins
Th1 CD4+T lymphocytes are essential for the activation of this pathway
Interferon-gamma is the primary cytokine involved in the activation of this pathway
Main function of the macrophages activated by this pathway is cessation of inflammation

questions.solution:
The statement main function of the macrophages activated by this pathway is cessation of inflammation is false about the classical pathway of macrophage activation.

Macrophages are the predominant cells involved in chronic inflammation. These cells are derived from precursors in the embryonic yolk sac and fetal liver in prenatal life and from hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow in postnatal life.

The principal functions of macrophages in chronic inflammation are as follows:

  • Microbicidal activity by secretion of cytokines
  • Continuation of the inflammatory response
  • Initiation of tissue repair and end inflammatory response
  • Sending and responding to signals from T lymphocytes that are essential for cell-mediated defense mechanisms

The abovementioned functions of macrophages are carried out once they are activated by two principal pathways:

  • Classical macrophage activation pathway:
    • The macrophages activated in this pathway are called M1 macrophages.
    • The activation of this pathway is induced by microbial endotoxins and other products that activate toll-like receptors (TLRs).
    • The primary cytokine involved in the activation of this pathway is interferon-gamma.
    • Microbicidal actions that are mediated by the release of nitric oxide, reactive oxygen species, and lysosomal enzymes are the primary function of M1 macrophages.
    • Release of IL-1, IL-12, and IL-23 by M1 macrophages is involved in promoting the inflammatory response.
  • Alternate macrophage activation pathway:
    • The macrophages activated in this pathway are called M2 macrophages.
    • The activation of this pathway is induced by IL-4 and IL-13 produced by T-lymphocytes.
    • Tissue repair is the primary function mediated by growth factors and transforming growth factors-β (TGF-β).
    • Cessation of inflammation is another important function mediated by IL-10, TGF-β. 

Three subsets of CD4+ T cells secrete different types of cytokines and elicit different types of inflammation.

TH1 cells - activate macrophages by the classical pathway by secreting IFN­γ.

TH2 cells - recruit and activate eosinophils and are responsible for the alternative pathway of macrophage activation by secreting IL­4, IL­5, and IL­13.

TH17 cells - secrete IL­17 and other cytokines, which are responsible for neutrophils and monocyte recruitment.

questions.text: A patient with Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection was prescribed a parenteral cephalosporin. Within 2 hours of administering the drug, he developed an allergic reaction. The drug was stopped and later aztreonam was administered. The allergic reaction aggravated after aztreonam administration. Which cephalosporin was likely administered at first?
questions.solution:
Ceftazidime was the cephalosporin that was likely to be administered at first. Aztreonam is generally safe for penicillin-allergic patients as there is no allergic cross-reactivity with beta-lactam antibiotics, except when it comes to ceftazidime due to its structural similarities.

Other exceptions also include ceftolozane and cefiderocol, with which aztreonam is structurally similar.
