questions.text: A doctor discharged a post-surgical patient without prescribing any antibiotics and wound dressing. The patient applied cow dung to the wound every day despite being advised to avoid contamination. After a week, the patient was admitted with septic shock. The patient's attenders sued the doctor for negligence. The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence based on ______.
questions.solution:
The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence based on the avoidable consequence rule. 

Avoidable consequence rule is a limitation to contributory negligence in which the negligence of the patient aggravated damage caused by the already negligent act of the doctor. The aggravation of the damage could be avoided if the patient was not negligent afterwards. The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence in such cases.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. The patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

Defenses against negligence:

  • No duty is owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata- If a court has already decided on a negligent case, the patient is not allowed to contest the same question in another proceeding based on the same set of facts. The patient can only make an appeal.
  • Res indicata- A negligent suit can be filed within 2 years of the alleged negligent act

Option A- Good Samaritan doctrine is also a part of contributory negligence where a person assisting another person who is in grave danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence unless the assistance is reckless.

Option B- Medical maloccurrence is a defense against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite of proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Option C- Last clear chance doctrine is a limitation to contributory negligence in which the doctor fails to prevent the damage caused by the negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to avoid the damage. The doctor will not be able to plead contributory negligence in such cases.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A sober young businessman was eating and laughing when he suddenly stood up to catch his breath. He called for help in a hoarse voice, fell down, and was struggling to breathe. He was brought dead to the hospital. On autopsy, a bolus of meat was found at the pharynx. What type of suffocation is seen here?
questions.solution:
The type of suffocation seen in this scenario is choking.

Choking refers to the blockage of internal airways usually between the pharynx and bifurcation of the trachea. The individual develops a sore throat, hoarseness, and respiratory distress.

Choking can be accidental, suicidal, or homicidal. The cause of death is choking is asphyxia, laryngospasm, reflex vagal inhibition causing cardiac arrest.

Treatment is by Heimlich maneuver (abdominal thrusts), a blow on the back or on the sternum may cause coughing and expel the foreign body. 

Other options:

Option A- Gagging is a form of asphyxia resulting from forcing a cloth into the mouth or due to closure of the mouth and nose by a cloth that is tied around the head.

Option B- Overlaying is a form of asphyxia that results due to compression of the chest so as to prevent breathing.

Option C- In café coronary, the victim is usually healthy but grossly intoxicated who dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or of asphyxia. The autopsy reveals a bolus of food lodged in the pharynx or larynx. The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition. The mode of death is clearly cardiac arrest (not the cause of death) presumably from parasympathetic overactivity due to stimulation of the laryngeal or pharyngeal mucosa.

questions.text: The substrate that combines with acetyl-CoA to form citrate in Krebs cycle is:
questions.solution:
Oxaloacetate combines with acetyl CoA to give rise to citrate.

The tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle), also called the citric acid cycle or the Krebs cycle is the final pathway where the oxidative catabolism of carbohydrates, amino acids, and fatty acids occurs with their carbon skeletons being converted to carbon dioxide (CO2). This oxidation provides energy for the production of the majority of ATP. The TCA cycle occurs totally in mitochondria and is in close proximity to the electron transport chain (ETC), which oxidizes the reduced coenzymes nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NADH) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FADH2) produced by the cycle. The final electron acceptor in the TCA cycle is oxygen and is, therefore, an aerobic pathway.

The TCA cycle consists of sequential reactions which begin with the formation of the six-carbon citrate from the four-carbon oxaloacetate and the two-carbon acetyl moiety of acetyl CoA. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme citrate synthase.

In the subsequent reactions, two carbon atoms are lost in the form of CO2 and the remaining four carbons undergo a series of modifications to ultimately form oxaloacetate. Thus, the last substrate of one cycle is ready for use as a substrate in the next cycle. 

In this way, there is no net generation of oxaloacetate, and can also be considered to be playing a catalytic role.

A brief overview of the TCA cycle is given below.

Related Pearl: Steps involved in TCA cycle

Step 1

Acetyl CoA + Oxaloacetate → Citrate

     (2C  + 4C  =   6C)

Enzyme: Citrate Synthase

Irreversible, Exothermic reaction
Step 2

Citrate → Cis –aconitate  → Isocitrate 

( 6C    →          6C →             6C)

Enzyme:   Aconitase

Cofactor:   Fe2+

The Reaction occurs in 2 steps:         

1st step:  Dehydration      

2nd step:  Rehydration

Inhibited by: Fluoroacetate (Non- Competitive)
Step 3

Isocitrate →[Oxalosuccinate]→α- Keto glutarate

        (6C) →         [6C]         →         (5C)

Enzyme:  Isocitrate Dehydrogenase

Cofactor:   Mn2+ or Mg2+

Reaction:  Oxidative  Decarboxylation

Intermediate:   Oxalosuccinate [ Unstable]

Release:    1 NADH and CO2
Step 4

α- Keto glutarate → Succcinyl Co A 

       (5C             →         4C)

Enzyme: α- Ketoglutarate Dehydrogenase(Multienzyme complex)

Reaction:  Oxidative Decarboxylation

Inhibited by: Arsenite  (Non – Competitive)

Physiologically unidirectional step.

Release: 1 NADH and CO2
Step 5

Succinyl- CoA  → Succinate

      ( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Thiokinase

Cofactor: Mg2+

Release:  1 ATP / GTP

Substrate level phosphorylation
Step 6

Succinate  →   Fumarate

( 4C          →         4C )

Enzyme:  Succinate Dehydrogenase (Part of 2nd complex ETC)

Cofactor:  FAD and Fe-S protein 

The only enzyme of TCA cycle attached to the inner mitochondrial membrane.

Inhibited by: Malonate ( competitive)

Release: FADH2
Step 7

Fumarate  →   Malate

( 4C         →     4C )

Enzyme:  Fumarate Hydratase

Reaction: Hydration
Step 8

Malate  →  Oxaloacetate  

( 4C     →        4C )

Enzyme:  Malate Dehydrogenase

Release:  1 NADH

Oxaloacetate is regenerated.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash. She had a tampon in situ for 24 hours. Which of the following toxin is not involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
A patient with fever, hypotension, and skin rash after retaining a tampon for 24 hours likely has toxic shock syndrome. The exfoliative toxin is not involved in this condition.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a multisystem toxin-mediated disease caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) produced by S. aureus is most commonly implicated in TSS. TSST-1 is a superantigen. It binds to MHC class II molecules and causes T-cell stimulation by bypassing the normal activation pathway. This leads to the overactivation of cytokines and inflammatory cells leading to toxic shock syndrome. Staphyloccoccal enterotoxin B is the second most common cause of TSS and recently, streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin has also been implicated.  

Toxic shock syndrome generally occurs in menstruating women who use superabsorbent tampons and do not change them often. However, it can also occur in post-surgical infections, burns, soft tissue infections, and retained foreign bodies like nasal packing, and catheters. Patients present with fever, desquamative skin rash, hypotension, and multisystem organ involvement. Treatment involves prompt removal of the source of infection such as tampons, nasal packing or debridement. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered after culture samples have been taken. The patient should also receive aggressive hydration with crystalloids. 

Exfoliative toxin causes staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome. Neonates are generally affected and present with fever, lethargy, poor feeding followed by rash and formation of large fluid-filled blisters. These blisters often burst which leads to exposed mucosa.

questions.text: A male patient presents with hearing loss and otorrhea for the last one week. He has a history of middle ear infections. The last episode resulted in the perforation of the tympanic membrane. His otoscopy findings are depicted below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and image above showing a perforated tympanic membrane and a large mass of white keratin debris suggest the likely diagnosis of secondary cholesteatoma. 

Cholesteatomas are keratinized squamous epithelium masses present in the middle ear cavity. They are described as skin in the wrong place. Although it is called cholesteatoma, this term is a misnomer as it is not composed of cholesterol crystals.

Cholesteatomas can be classified into the following types :

  • Primary acquired cholesteatomas occur in the absence of previous infection or perforation and patients present with hearing loss.
  • Secondary acquired cholesteatomas occur in those who have a preexisting perforation. 
  • Congenital cholesteatomas arise from the embryonic epidermal cells present in the middle ear cleft. It can be visualized as a white mass behind an intact tympanic membrane. 

Clinical features of cholesteatomas include hearing loss (due to perforation of tympanic membrane and middle ear bone destruction) and otorrhea. Cholesteatomas have a high potential to destroy the bone due to invasion and enzymatic bone destruction. 

Diagnosis of cholesteatoma can be done by history, examination, and radiography. CT can demonstrate bony defects such as ossicular erosion, mastoid aditus widening, and bony ear canal erosion.

Surgery is the only treatment for cholesteatoma. The procedure of choice is modified radical mastoidectomy (MRM), a type of canal wall-down tympanomastoidectomy.

Other options: 

Option A - Acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) is more common in children. It would not have a pearly white mass on otoscopy. Clinical and otoscopy findings depend on the stage of ASOM. 

The following image shows mucopurulent discharge in the external auditory meatus seen in the stage of resolution of ASOM:

Option B - Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IXth cranial nerve. A rising sun sign is seen on otoscopy when a tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear

The following image shows a rising sun sign:

Related Pearl: Classification and theories for origin of cholesteatoma

Classification:

Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth.

Primary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars flaccida. 

Secondary acquired cholesteatoma is associated with a defect in the pars tensa.

Tertiary acquired cholesteatoma is defined as that which occurs behind a normal-appearing tympanic membrane as the result of implantation of an antecedent middle ear inflammation.

 
Type
Theory
Description
Congenital Cholesteatoma
Congenital cell rests
The presence of congenital epithelial cell rests within the middle ear cleft/ temporal bone.
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Wittmaack’s theory of retraction pockets
Negative middle ear pressure leads to the formation of retraction pockets (usually in the posterosuperior part of pars tensa and the pars flaccida) which accumulates keratin debris.
Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
The basal cell layer of the germinal layer of skin proliferates in response to infection & other stimuli.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (Otitis media with effusion) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.
Secondary Acquired Cholesteatoma
Habermann’s theory of epithelial invasion
Marginal perforation leads to ingrowth of squamous epithelium of the meatus or outer surface of the tympanic membrane into middle ear.
Sade’s Metaplasia theory
Repeated infections (ASOM/CSOM) lead to metaplasia of middle ear epithelium into squamous type.

questions.text: A 29-week pregnant woman, who was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia, was prescribed oral iron tablets. However, she is unable to comply as she develops epigastric pain, increased vomiting, and constipation on taking this tablet. Which of the following iron preparations can be given in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Iron sucrose is the iron preparation to be given to a pregnant woman with intolerance to oral iron therapy. 

Iron sucrose is the parenteral iron formulation. Other parenteral iron preparations are iron dextran, sodium ferric gluconate, ferumoxytol, and ferric carboxymaltose. Indications of parenteral iron therapy are:

  • Iron malabsorption (sprue, short bowel syndrome)
  • Severe oral iron intolerance
  • Unresponsive to oral iron therapy
  • In patients who are receiving erythropoietin

Iron sucrose is given intravenously and gets split into iron and sucrose by macrophages. The increase in hemoglobin is equivalent to that of the oral iron formulations. The main adverse events of parenteral formulations include hypersensitivity reactions, headache, arthralgia, and urticaria. The patients should be monitored to avoid iron overload.

Other options:

All the other options are examples of oral iron preparations. Common adverse effects include nausea, epigastric discomfort, diarrhea, or constipation.

questions.text:
Match the following mood disorders with the minimum duration required for diagnosis according to DSM 5.
Mood disorder Duration
I. Major depressive episode A. 2 years
II. Dysthymia B. 4 days
III. Manic episode C. 2 weeks
IV. Hypomanic episode D. 1 week

choices.text: I - C, II - A, III - D, IV - B
I - A, II - B, III - D, IV - C
I - B, II - C, III - A, IV - D
I - D, II - A, III - C, IV - B

questions.solution:
The correct answer is I - C, II - A, III - D, IV - B.

The following are the minimum duration required for diagnosis according to Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders - 5 (DSM-5):

Mood disorder Duration
Major depressive episode 2 weeks
Dysthymia 2 years 
Manic episode 1 week
Hypomanic episode 4 days 

 

Major depressive disorder- It must be accompanied by at least 4 of the following symptoms:

  • Change in appetite
  • Change in weight
  • Change in sleep and activity
  • Lack of energy
  • Feelings of guilt
  • Problems with thinking and making decisions
  • Recurring thoughts of death or suicide 

Dysthymia- It is characterized by symptoms of depression lasting two years. The symptoms are not severe enough to fit the diagnosis of a major depressive episode.   

Manic episode- It is characterized by a distinctive period of persistently and abnormally elevated or irritable mood lasting for at least one week. The diagnosis can also be made if it lasts for less than one week but is serious enough to require hospitalization.   

Hypomanic episode- It is similar to mania but it does not result in impairment of social or occupational function. The episode should last at least 4 days for a diagnosis of hypomania.

Related Pearl: Bipolar disorder

  • Symptoms more severe
  • 1 week unless hospitalized
  • Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or hospitalization necessary
  • May have psychotic features; makes episode manic by definition

Hypomanic episode  

  • Symptoms less severe
  • 4 days to less than 7 days
  • Unequivocal, observable change in functioning from patient's baseline
  • Symptoms not severe enough to cause marked impairment or necessitate hospitalization
  • No psychotic features

  • Manic episode(s)
  • Depressive episodes common (but not required for diagnosis)

Bipolar II

  • Hypomanic episode(s)
  • Major depressive episodes (required for diagnosis)

  • At least 2 years of fluctuating, mild hypomanic & depressive symptoms that
    do not meet criteria for hypomanic episodes or major depressive episodes

questions.text: A 24-year-old boxer presents with sudden onset pain in the right hand. This incident occurred during his training. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness on the medial side of his right hand. An X-ray of the right hand is shown below. Which of the following casts is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray feature showing a fracture of the neck of the 5th metacarpal suggests Boxer's fracture and the cast used is an ulnar gutter splint. 

A boxer's fracture is a fracture of the neck of the 5th metacarpal. There may be swelling and flattening of knuckles. The hand is immobilized in an ulnar gutter splint with the metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) flexed and the interphalangeal joints (IP) straight. The hand is mobilized after 1-2 weeks.

An ulnar gutter splint can be used for various injuries to the upper extremities like soft-tissue injuries to the 4th and 5th fingers and also 4th and 5th metacarpal and phalangeal fractures. It is also used in positioning for rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis.

The below image shows an ulnar gutter splint.

Other options :

Option B) Burkhalter cast involves placing the wrist at 40 degrees of extension with the metacarpophalangeal joints at 70-90 degrees of flexion. This cast is also used to treat metacarpal or phalangeal fractures. 

Option C) Reisser's turnbuckle cast is used in the treatment of scoliosis. This is a body cast with a turn-buckle in between. Correction of the deformity occurs by tightening the turnbuckle that stretches the concave side of the curve.

Option D) Glass holding cast or scaphoid cast is used in scaphoid fracture and also in pain along the radial border of the wrist ie. in the anatomical snuff-box. The position is as if the glass is being held between the index finger and thumb with the wrist being held in slight dorsiflexion and the thumb in the abduction and slight flexion.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: Which of the following protozoan parasites is found in the lumen of the human small intestine?
questions.solution:
Image 2 shows the trophozoite of Giardia lamblia, which is the only protozoan parasite found in the lumen of the human small intestine. It lives in the duodenum and upper jejunum.

Other protozoan parasites found in the human small intestine do not occur in the lumen but are present in the epithelial cells lining the small intestine. These include:

  • Isospora belli
  • Cyclospora cayetanensis
  • Cryptosporidium parvum
  • Sarcocystis hominis

Other options:

Options A and C: Entamoeba histolytica and Balantidium coli are found in the human large intestine.

Option D: Trichomonas vaginalis is found in the genital tract.

questions.text: A 55-year-old obese female patient who was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 2 years ago has come for a change of medication. She has a history of osteoporosis and does not want to take any injectable medications.  Which of the following drugs can be prescribed for her diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
In an obese patient with a history of osteoporosis who does not wish to take injectable medications, semaglutide is the most appropriate drug which can be given.

GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide) analogs increase insulin secretion, reduce glucagon release, delay gastric emptying, and normalize fasting and postprandial insulin secretion. GLP-1 analogs have been found to promote weight loss. Semaglutide is a member of this class that is available as an oral formulation, while all the other GLP-1 agonists are injectable drugs. 

GLP-1 analogs can cause hypoglycemia when in combination with insulin or sulfonylureas. They increase the risk of pancreatitis and medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Other options:

Option A: Canagliflozin is an inhibitor of sodium-glucose transporter 2 which is located in the proximal tubule of the nephron. It reduces the rate of glucose reabsorption and reduces the renal threshold for glucose excretion. It reduces mortality in cardiovascular patients with type II diabetes mellitus. This drug is not preferred in this patient as it can decrease bone mineral density leading to an increased risk of fractures.

Option B: Liraglutide is also a GLP-1 receptor agonist and is given only in the subcutaneous injectable form. It has recently also been approved for the treatment of obesity.

Option D: Pioglitazone belongs to the thiazolidinediones group. It activates PPARγ receptors primarily in the adipose tissue which increases insulin sensitivity and adipose differentiation. They enhance the insulin action in the liver, adipose tissue, and skeletal muscle and improve glycemic control in diabetics. This drug is not preferred in this patient as it can lead to further weight gain and adiposity, leading to increased risk of fractures. Hence, it is best avoided in patients with osteoporosis. The other important adverse effects include edema (fluid retention), macular edema, and increased risk of heart failure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of hair loss over the back of his head. There is no other significant past medical history. On examination, the following can be seen with exclamation mark hairs without scaling or inflammation. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of localized hair loss with exclamation mark hairs without scaling or inflammation on examination is suggestive of alopecia areata. Sparing of white hair is seen in alopecia areata.

Alopecia areata is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to non-scarring hair loss. It is thought to be caused by T-cell-mediated autoimmunity(Option A). The activated T lymphocytes invade the hair bulb but the follicle is spared(Option C). It is associated with many autoimmune diseases systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroiditis, vitiligo, and psoriasis. 

It mainly affects the scalp, but can also affect the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes (Option D). In some cases, this progresses to a total loss of scalp hair (alopecia totalis) or a loss of all hair on the body (alopecia universalis). The lesions of alopecia areata are characterized by a smooth circumscribed patch of alopecia. Some broken hairs can be seen, which are called exclamation marks. They are easily extractable. It preferentially affects pigmented hair and spares non-pigmented or white hair.

Spontaneous remission occurs in a majority of patients with hair loss that is patchy and is of shorter duration. Topical steroids like clobetasol can be useful in patchy alopecia areata. Intralesional steroids are the most effective treatment for patchy alopecia areata. Severe and long-standing alopecia areata require oral corticosteroids.

questions.text: A male patient presented with lower abdominal pain and an inability to urinate after an accident. He was conscious, and his vitals were stable.  X-ray showed a pelvic fracture that was managed conservatively. The retrograde cystogram showed a dense, flame-shaped collection of contrast in the pelvis. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of extraperitoneal bladder rupture associated with pelvic fracture. The next step in the management of this patient is Foley's catheterization.

Bladder rupture may be extraperitoneal or intraperitoneal. The type of bladder rupture depends on the location of the injury and its relationship with the peritoneal reflection as below:

  1. If the bladder rupture is above the peritoneal reflection (on the bladder dome), the urine extravasation will be intraperitoneal.
  2. If the bladder rupture is below the peritoneal reflection (eg: neck) and not on the dome, the urine extravasation will be extraperitoneal.

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is the most common. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture is caused by blunt trauma or surgical damage. The symptoms of extraperitoneal bladder injury are suprapubic pain with the inability to void.

CT cystography is the ideal investigation for bladder injury. Retrograde cystography confirms the diagnosis. On retrograde cystogram, a dense, flame-shaped pattern of extravasation of the contrast material into the perivesical space and the fascia planes anterior to the peritoneum.

Uncomplicated extraperitoneal bladder injury is usually managed with urethral catheter drainage alone. Emergency operative management of bladder injury is done in:

  • Intraperitoneal injury from external trauma
  • Penetrating or iatrogenic non-urologic injury
  • Inadequate bladder drainage or clots in urine
  • Bladder neck injury
  • Rectal or vaginal injury
  • Open pelvic fracture
  • Pelvic fracture requiring open reduction and internal fixation
  • Selected stable patients undergoing laparotomy for other reasons 
  • Bone fragments projecting into the bladder

An algorithm for the management of bladder injury is given below:

Other options:

Option A- Suprapubic cystostomy is done in urethral injury.

Option B- Wait and watch is not a feasible option as there is extraperitoneal extravasation, which, if left untreated, can lead to peritonitis.

Option C- Exploratory laparotomy is done in intraperitoneal bladder rupture and other conditions as mentioned above.

questions.text: A diabetic man presented with vomiting, abdominal pain, and polyuria. He gives a history of missing 2 doses of insulin since morning. He is hypotensive and tachycardic and his breath has a fruity odour. Blood glucose was 350 mg/dL. Which test, done here will give a positive result?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis in which rothera’s test will give positive results due to the presence of ketone bodies in urine. 

Rothera’s test by nitroprusside reagent is a specific test used to detect whether acetone or acetoacetate is present in the given sample of urine. A purple ring at the junction of two liquids indicates a positive test.

Note: Rothera's test does not detect β-hydroxybutyrate. 

Other options:

Option A: Hay's test is used to test for bile salts.

Option B: Fouchet's test is used to test for bilirubin.

Option C: Ninhydrin test is used to test for alpha-amino acids.

questions.text: A 37-year-old male patient presented with redness, pain, and swelling of his right lower limb for the past two days. On examination, you note the following lesion (image below) with raised, demarcated edges and some blister formation. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as erysipelas, and the treatment is flucloxacillin. 

Erysipelas is the infection of the dermis and superficial subcutaneous tissue. It is well-demarcated and has raised edges with blistering. Cellulitis is similar to erysipelas except that it affects the loose connective tissue and is diffuse in appearance.

Clinical features include erythema, pain, swelling, and tenderness. Blister formation occurs frequently, and there may be haemorrhage in the blister. The most common site of involvement in the leg is shown below. In addition to erysipelas, there may also be signs of the source of infection, such as an ulcer, tenia pedis, or an inflammatory lesion. The face is also frequently involved in cases of traumatic injury. 

The most common cause of erysipelas and cellulitis is group A streptococcus. Group B streptococcus is the causative organism for pelvic erysipelas in adults after surgery and children under 3 months of age. Staphylococcus aureus is occasionally present as mixed flora. Organisms like group B streptococcus and Hemophilus influenza type b can cause cellulitis in children.  

For this reason, the first-line treatment involves flucloxacillin given orally as it targets both streptococci and staphylococci. Penicillins are the first-line treatment for both cellulitis and erysipelas. 

If the patient has a beta-lactam allergy, then clarithromycin (Option A) or clindamycin (Option C) can be given. 

If there is a recurrent infection in the same area, there may be damage to the lymphatics, leading to chronic lymphedema. 

Metronidazole (Option D) is used to treat anaerobic bacteria and parasites.

Streptococcus causes a variety of skin and soft tissue infections. These include:

a. Impetigo- Infection of superficial layers of the skin. It presents as superficial vesicles which break down and are then encrusted by honey-colored scab. It usually occurs in children.

Erysipelas is a raised lesion whereas cellulitis is not, ii. Cellulitis is poorly demarcated from the surrounding skin whereas erysipelas is clearly demarcated.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman comes to the U-PHC, requesting maternal health and family welfare advice for her daughter-in-law. Which of the following maternal health and family welfare services cannot be given in a U-PHC?

U-PHC: Urban primary health center

OCP: Oral contraceptive pills

IUD: Intrauterine device
questions.solution:
Sterilization services cannot be provided in an urban primary health center. 

The national urban health mission (NUHM) was implemented to improve the urban population's health status, particularly slum dwellers and other vulnerable sections of society. It aims to facilitate their access to quality health care. NUHM aims to cover all urban areas with a population >50,000.

The services provided by the NUHM are delivered through the following:

  • Urban primary health centers (U-PHCs)
  • Urban community health centers (U-CHCs).
  • Outreach services 

Urban primary health centers are set up for every 50,000 people. U-PHC can be located within, or near a slum catering to a slum population of approximately 25,000-30,000. Outpatient services will be available. In areas of high population density, a U-PHC can be set up for a population of 75,000 as well. The U-PHC is predominantly for simple consultations such as the distribution of OCP (oral contraceptive pills)/ CC (combined contraceptives), IUD (intrauterine device) insertion, referral for sterilization, and postnatal care. 

Urban community health centers are set up for every 4-5 U-PHCs or 2,50,000 people. It functions as a referral unit. It would provide in-patient services and would be a 30-50 bedded facility. In metro cities, U-CHCs may be established for every 5 lakh population with 100 beds. The U-CHC provides medical care and does minor surgeries such as sterilization.

The outreach services are targeted at specific groups such as slum dwellers and other vulnerable groups. It will be provided by female health workers, especially ANMs (auxiliary nursing midwifery). They undergo induction training of three to six months and will be then placed at the U-PHCs. On designated days, they move to their respective areas for outreach services. They provide services such as distribution of OCPs, counseling, and follow-up of contraceptive-related complications.

questions.text: Direct laryngoscopy was performed to evaluate a 60-year-old man with laryngeal cancer. The tumor was noted in the vocal cord and the anterior commissure. Conservative laryngeal surgery was performed. Which of the following surgeries involves the removal of the affected structures?
questions.solution:
The surgery that involves the removal of the vocal cords and anterior commissure is the partial frontolateral laryngectomy.

This surgery is a type of conservative laryngeal surgery. They're performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening. Conservative surgery cannot be done for all types of laryngeal carcinoma so patients should be carefully selected. 

Types of conservation surgeries include:

I) Cordectomy via laryngeal fissure - The vocal cord is excised after splitting the larynx

II) Partial frontolateral laryngectomy - The vocal cord and anterior commissure is excised

III) Partial horizontal laryngectomy - The supraglottis is excised. This includes the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, false cords, and the ventricle.

The other type of surgery is total laryngectomy where the entire larynx along with the hyoid bone, preepiglottic space, strap muscles, and a few tracheal rings are removed. The tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration. 

The indications of total laryngectomy are as follows:

  • T3 lesions
  • All T4 lesions
  • Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
  • Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
  • Lesions of the posterior commissure 
  • Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
  • Transglottic cancers with cord fixation.

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with complaints of backache, morning stiffness, and redness of the eyes. An x-ray image of the spine is given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a young male with backache, morning stiffness, redness of the eye, and the X-ray showing the classical bamboo-spine appearance are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis. All the given options are true, except "sciatica is common". Referred pain in the buttocks and thighs may be mistaken for sciatica and some patients are mistakenly treated for intervertebral disc prolapse.

 

Ankylosing spondylitis commonly involves young male adults. It has a strong association with the HLAB27 genetic marker.

Radiographic findings in ankylosing spondylitis:

  • Sacro-iliac joints:
    • Erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints is the earliest and cardinal sign.
  • Vertebral changes:
    • Earliest- flattening of the normal anterior concavity of the vertebral body ‘squaring’
    • Later- ossification of the ligaments around the intervertebral discs produces syndesmophytes (bridges) between adjacent vertebrae
    • Bamboo spine appearance- due to bridging at several vertebral levels
    • Long-standing cases are associated with osteoporosis. Wedging of the vertebral bodies produces hyperkyphosis of the spine
  • Progressive bony ankylosis or erosive arthritis may be seen in peripheral joints. 

Diagnostic criteria for ankylosing spondylitis: 

Sacroiliitis on imaging: Active inflammation on MRI highly suggestive of spondyloarthropathy associated sacroiliitis and/or definite radiographic sacroiliitis according to modified New York criteria plus ≥1 Spondyloarthropathy (SpA) feature

              OR

HLA-B27 plus ≥2 other SpA features.

Spondyloarthropathy (SpA) features:

  • Inflammatory back pain
  • Arthritis
  • Enthesitis (heel)
  • Anterior uveitis
  • Dactylitis 
  • Psoriasis 
  • Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis
  • Good response to NSAIDs.
  • Family history of spondyloarthropathy
  • HLA-B27 
  • Elevated CRP

Extra-articular manifestations: Acute anterior uveitis occurs in about 25% of patients. It usually responds well to treatment but may lead to permanent damage including glaucoma if it is not treated appropriately. Others are pericarditis, aortic incompetence, apical lobe fibrosis, generalized osteoporosis, and atlantoaxial joint subluxation.

questions.text: To provide epidural analgesia during labour, what is the ideal concentration of epinephrine added to the local anaesthetic?
questions.solution:
Very dilute concentration of epinephrine (1:400,000 to 1:800,000) is used along with local anaesthetics for labour epidural analgesia.

Epidural epinephrine can provide vasoconstriction which would delay the vascular uptake of local anaesthetic and opioid. Additionally, it can activate α2-adrenergic receptors and thus produce analgesia on its own.

Epinephrine, used along with local anaesthetics at a concentration of 5 μg/mL or 1:200,000 may be associated with uterine artery vasoconstriction which can adversely affect the fetus and delay the progress of labour. Hence epinephrine at this dose is used only for test dose (15 μg/mL or 3 ml of 1:200,000). A test dose is given to rule out the intravascular placement of epidural catheter following the procedure.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient presents to the emergency room with chest pain and diaphoresis for the last 45 minutes. An ECG reveals inferior wall myocardial infarction. Which of the following is the best way to reduce mortality?
questions.solution:
The next best way to reduce mortality in this patient is percutaneous coronary intervention.

In myocardial infarction, the occluded coronary artery results in insufficient blood flow to the myocardium resulting in ischemia and myocardial death.

However, if revascularization is done early, the ischemia can be reversed. Early revascularization with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is more beneficial than pharmacological therapy alone. The benefit of revascularization strongly correlates with the timing of the procedure done after symptom onset. Ideally, PCI should be performed within 90 minutes of presentation. However, it is still useful if performed within 12 hours. 

Along with general measures in MI management, systemic and coronary perfusion should be maintained. This is done by using vasopressors and fluids to ensure optimum left ventricular filling pressure to raise the blood pressure. The goal should be a mean arterial pressure of 60-65mmHg or systolic blood pressure of 90mmHg. Other tasks include correction of hypoxemia and acidosis, ventilatory support, avoidance of hypoglycemia. Arrhythmias if present should be monitored and treated. 

Other options: 

Option A - Volume replacement is part of the general management of acute myocardial infarction as part of stabilization. However, it would not reduce mortality. 

Option C - Inotrope administration has not been proven to make significant changes in clinical outcomes in patients with cardiogenic shock. The use of catecholamines has the risk of inducing arrhythmias or increasing myocardial oxygen demand so if used, the administration should not be prolonged. 

Option D - Intraaortic balloon pump is a type of mechanical circulatory support device that is inserted into the aorta. It can be used to provide hemodynamic support. However, its use has not been shown to improve mortality and thus is used when other methods of resuscitation fail.
