questions.text: Which of the following is true about the steps of acute flaccid paralysis (AFP) surveillance?

choices.text: Fecal samples should arrive at the lab within 48 hours of collection
All children with AFP should be tested within 72 hours of onset
Should be able to detect atleast 1 case of AFP/100000 children under 15 years
Fecal specimens should be transported at 2°C

questions.solution:
The statement "Detect at least 1 case of AFP/100000 children under 15 years" is true with regard to the steps of AFP surveillance.

There are four steps under AFP surveillance:

  1.  Finding and reporting children with AFP: 
    • The staff in all health facilities should report every case of AFP in any child less than 15 years of age.
    • The surveillance system of the country should be able to detect at least one case of AFP for every 1,00,000 children under 15 years of age, even in the absence of polio.
  1. Transporting stool samples for analysis:
    • All children with AFP should be reported and tested for wild poliovirus within 48 hours of onset. (option B)
    • The faecal samples are used to test for polio. The specimens should be collected within the first two weeks after the onset of paralysis since the highest concentration of the poliovirus is found during this period.
    • Stool specimens have to be sealed in containers and stored immediately inside a refrigerator or packed between frozen ice packs at 4–8 degrees Celsius in a cold box (option D). Specimens should arrive at the laboratory within 72 hours of collection (option A). Otherwise, they must be frozen at –20 degrees Celsius and then shipped frozen. The procedure is known as the “reverse cold chain”.
  1. Isolating poliovirus:
    • Isolation of the virus followed by distinguishing between wild and vaccine-related poliovirus.
    • If the wild type is isolated, then the virologists identify which of the two surviving types is involved.
  1. Mapping the virus:
    • If the wild type of virus is found, the genetic makeup of the virus is further studied and is compared with the reference bank of known polioviruses to know about the geographical origin of the virus.
    • Once the geographical area is identified, the source of the importation virus can be known. Immunization strategies can be determined accordingly. 

The differential diagnosis for acute flaccid paralysis includes:

  • Non-polio enteroviruses
  • West Nile virus
  • Guillan–Barre syndrome
  • Other neurotropic viruses: rabies, varicella-zoster, and Japanese encephalitis.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presents with increased hand and foot size, and the facial features depicted in the image. Insulin-like growth factor-I (IGF-1) levels are elevated. Which of the following confirms your diagnosis?

GH - Growth Hormone

choices.text: Suppressed growth hormone after oral glucose load
Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load

questions.solution:
The clinical image of a man with mandibular enlargement, prognathism (protrusion of jaw), and jaw malocclusion with elevated IGF-1 suggests the diagnosis of acromegaly. Elevated growth hormone after oral glucose load confirms the diagnosis.

Acromegaly is a result of growth hormone hypersecretion due to a pituitary adenoma. It can also occur due to extra pituitary lesions. If growth hormone hypersecretion occurs before the fusion of the growth plates at puberty, it leads to gigantism. 

75g of oral glucose load is administered to the patient. The growth hormone levels are measured within 1-2 hours after administration. Normally, GH should be suppressed to less than 0.4 ug/L after the oral glucose load. A failure of suppression of growth hormone confirms the diagnosis of acromegaly. In some patients, growth hormone levels may demonstrate a paradoxical rise. 

Acral bony overgrowth in acromegaly manifests as frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement, prognathism, and widened space between incisors. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Generalized visceromegaly is seen including cardiomegaly, macroglossia, thyroid enlargement, etc. Serious complications include diabetes mellitus, obstructive sleep apnoea, and increased risk of colonic polyps and cancer. 

Acromegaly can be treated by transsphenoidal resection of the tumor. It can also be managed medically by using octreotide (a somatostatin analog), pegvisomant (Growth Hormone receptor antagonist), dopamine agonists or radiation. 

Other options: 

Option A - Elevated random growth hormone levels would not help in diagnosis as GH is secreted in a pulsatile fashion. In addition, the GH level does not correlate with severity. 

Option B - Suppressed growth hormone after an oral glucose load is seen in patients without acromegaly. 

Option D - Elevated random prolactin levels are seen in 25% of patients with acromegaly but is not used to confirm the diagnosis. 

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a boundary of the maxillary sinus?

choices.text: Posterior wall is infratemporal and pterygopalatine fossae
Medial wall is middle and inferior meatuses
Floor is alveolar and palatine processes of maxilla
Roof is orbital plate of the frontal bone

questions.solution:
The orbital plate of the frontal bone is not a boundary of the maxillary sinus. 

The following are the boundaries of the maxillary sinus:

Wall Boundary
Anterior wall Facial surface of maxilla
Posterior wall Infratemporal and pterygopalatine fossae  
Medial wall Middle and inferior meatuses
Floor

Alveolar and palatine processes of maxilla
Roof

Floor of the orbit

The maxillary sinus is an air cavity in the maxilla and is part of the anterior group of paranasal sinuses. It is also known as the Antrum of Highmore. Its appearance is described as a pyramid, with its base being formed by the nasal wall and the apex pointing towards the zygomatic process. 

The mucus produced by the maxillary sinus is drained through the natural ostium into the middle meatus. 

The role of the paranasal sinuses is to humidify and warm the inspired air, to add resonance to voice, to lighten the skull bone, act as thermal insulators for the organs in the orbit, to increase olfactory sensation surface, and to provide a buffer for trauma. 

Image below shows sagittal and coronal view of maxillary sinus respectively.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida comes for her first antenatal check-up. Investigations revealed a fasting blood sugar of 156 mg/dL with an HbA1c of 6.6%. Which of the following is not likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis, in this case, is overt diabetes first detected in pregnancy, and post-term pregnancy is not likely to be associated with this condition. Overt diabetes is most likely to cause preterm birth.

To diagnose overt diabetes first detected in pregnancy, the International Association of Diabetes and Preg­nancy Study Groups (IADPSG) consensus panel gave the following threshold values:

  • Fasting blood glucose > 126 mg/dL
  • HbA1c > 6.5%
  • Random plasma glucose > 200 mg/dL with classic symptoms of polyuria, polydipsia, and unexplained weight loss.
  • These apply to women with no known history of diabetes.

The maternal and fetal complications that are directly attributable to overt diabetes are given below:

  1. Neonatal and fetal complications
    1. Spontaneous abortion - are commonly associated with HbA1c >12% and preprandial glucose levels > 120 mg/dL.
    2. Preterm delivery
    3. Malformations - Cardiovascular malformations are most commonly associated with diabetes. Sacral agenesis and caudal regression syndrome are rare malformations that are frequently associated with maternal diabetes.
    4. Altered fetal growth in the form of macrosomia. It can also present as growth retardation due to compromised maternal blood flow due to diabetes.
    5. Stillbirths
    6. Polyhydramnios due to polyuria from fetal hyperglycemia
    7. Respiratory distress syndrome is more commonly due to prematurity
    8. Neonatal hypoglycemia
    9. Hypocalcemia
    10. Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia
    11. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy primarily affects the inter­ ventricular septum.
    12. Cognitive impairment.
  2. Maternal complications
    1. Pre-eclampsia
    2. Diabetic retinopathy
    3. Diabetic nephropathy
    4. Diabetic gastropathy
    5. Infections like vulvovaginitis, urinary and respiratory tract infections
    6. Diabetic ketoacidosiss.

questions.text: All the following statements are true regarding insomnia management except:

choices.text: Ramelteon is a melatonin agonist used in sleep onset insomnia
Agomelatine is used in depression with insomnia
Suvorexant is an orexin agonist used in treatment of insomnia
Tasimelteon is used to induce sleep in totally blind people

questions.solution:
Suvorexant is orexin 1 and 2 receptors antagonist used in the treatment of insomnia.

The neurons that produce orexin in the lateral hypothalamus are inert during sleep and active during wakefulness. Orexins assist in wakefulness but their antagonists increase the REM and non-REM sleep. Suvorexant reduces the sleep onset latency.

Other options:

Option A- Ramelteon is a synthetic analogue of melatonin. There are two melatonin receptors, MT1 and MT2, in the suprachiasmatic nucleus where MT1 receptors promote the sleep onset and MT2 receptors change the timing of the circadian system. Ramelteon acts as an agonist to both MT1, MT2 receptors and is used in the treatment of sleep-onset insomnia.

Option B- Agomelatine is a melatonin (MT1 and MT2) receptor agonist and 5-HT2C receptor antagonist. Agomelatine increases noradrenaline and dopamine release providing an antidepressant effect. It also synchronizes circadian rhythms in circadian rhythm disruption. It is approved for the treatment of a major depressive disorder associated with insomnia.

Option D- Tasimelteon is a selective agonist at MT1 and MT2 receptors. It is approved for the treatment of non-24 hour sleep-wake syndrome in totally blind people.

Note: 

Daridorexant has been approved for the treatment of adult patients with insomnia characterized by difficulties with sleep onset and/or sleep maintenance. It is a dual orexin type 1 and type 2 (OX1R and OX2R) receptor antagonist similar to suvorexant.

questions.text:
A homeless, alcoholic man presented with altered sensorium and rapid shallow breathing. His abdomen is distended, and fluid thrill is positive. Icterus and multiple spider hemangiomas are noted. You also find multiple needle tracks on his arms and a half-empty strip of paracetamol tablets in his pocket. The liver function test results are given below. What is the most likely cause for this patient's presentation?

Total Bilirubin: 3.2mg/dL

Aspartate transaminase (AST): 80 IU/L

Alanine transaminase (ALT): 25 IU/L

Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 200 IU/L

γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT): 68 IU/L

Albumin: 2.6 g/dL

Discriminant function (DF): 34

Fingerstick blood glucose: 50 mg/dL.
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for this patient's presentation is alcoholic liver disease. 

This patient's presentation of altered consciousness with jaundice (scleral icterus) and signs of liver cirrhosis (distended abdomen, spider angiomas) is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy. The AST: ALT ratio in this patient is > 2:1 which is characteristic of alcoholic liver disease (Normal levels: AST- 10-40 IU/L, ALT - 10-40 IU/L). This is because there is a deficiency of pyridoxal 5'- phosphate in alcoholics. 

An AST: ALT ratio >2:1 is suggestive, whereas a ratio >3:1 (as in this patient) is highly suggestive, of alcoholic liver disease.

In this patient with alcoholic liver cirrhosis, not eating his meals has resulted in hypoglycemia and dehydration, precipitating hepatic encephalopathy. 

Discriminant function (DF) is calculated using prothrombin time and bilirubin level. It is also known as the Maddrey score and it assesses the severity and mortality risk in alcoholic hepatitis. DF ≥ 32 indicates severe disease.

Other options:

Option B: This patient's homelessness and multiple needle tracks suggestive of IV drug abuse put him at risk of contracting viral hepatitis. In acute viral hepatitis, the aminotransferases are often elevated > 500 IU (400-4000 IU/L) due to extensive cell injury.

Option C: In autoimmune hepatitis, aminotransferase levels are elevated and fluctuate in the range of 100-1000 IU/L. Autoimmune hepatitis may present as acute or chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis. Commonly associated symptoms include fatigue, anorexia, pruritis, arthralgias, upper abdominal discomfort, skin rashes including acne among others. 

Option D: Finding an empty strip of paracetamol arises suspicion of paracetamol overdose/ acute acetaminophen poisoning. However, in acute acetaminophen poisoning, the aminotransferases are elevated > 1000 IU and may exceed 10,000 IU/L due to acute hepatocellular injury. 

Liver Function Tests patterns in Hepatobiliary Disorders

Type of Disorder Bilirubin Aminotransferases Alkaline phosphatase

Acute hepatocellular necrosis (viral and toxin-induced hepatitis, acute heart failure)

Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin 

Elevated often, >500 IU/L

ALT > AST

 Normal to <3x normal elevation
Alcoholic hepatitis Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin AST:ALT >2  Normal to <3x normal elevation
Chronic hepatocellular disorders  Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin Elevated but usually <300 IU/L Normal to <3x normal elevation
Hemolysis Increase in indirect bilirubin (85% of total serum bilirubin) Normal Normal
Intra- and extrahepatic cholestasis Increase in both direct and indirect bilirubin Normal to moderate elevation Elevated, often >4x normal
Obstructive jaundice Increase in direct bilirubin Normal to a slight elevation  Elevated, often >4x normal

 

Note: The minimum toxic dose of paracetamol for single ingestion posing a significant risk of severe hepatotoxicity in adults is 7.5-10 g. A half-empty strip is unlikely to reach this threshold, which, coupled with the lab findings, makes acetaminophen poisoning unlikely.

questions.text:
In an experiment aimed at studying the physiological ventilatory responses to inhalation of carbon dioxide (CO2), a subject was made to inhale oxygen with gradually increasing concentrations of carbon dioxide. Which of the following physiological responses would most likely be seen?

RR- Respiratory rate

MV- minute volume

PCO2 - alveolar partial pressure of carbon dioxide.
questions.solution:
The most likely physiological response seen is ↑RR, ↑MV, ↑PCO2.

The normal arterial PCO2 is maintained at 35- 45mmHg. 

In the given experiment, when a gas mixture of oxygen and carbon dioxide is inhaled, the alveolar PCO2 raises. The CO2 diffuses across the alveolar membrane and increases the PCO2 in the arterial blood.

Increased RR: The CO2 readily crosses the blood-brain barrier and gets hydrolyzed to H2CO3 that dissociates to H+ and HCO3-. The increase in the H+ concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid and the interstitial fluid of the brain stimulates the central chemoreceptors located in the medulla. This stimulates the respiratory center, thus increasing the respiratory rate.

Increased MV: Minute volume is the volume of air moved in and out of the lungs in one minute. It is given by the formula MV = RR * Tidal volume. As the respiratory rate increases, the minute volume also increases. 

Increased PCO2: In this experiment, as the subject is inhaling a gradually increasing concentration of CO2, a new slightly higher equilibrium of alveolar PCO2 is achieved. 

Other options:

Option A - This is unlikely as MV cannot decrease as RR increases.

Option C- ↑RR ↑MV normal PCO2: In cases where there is a sudden brief increase in CO2 inhalation (as opposed to gradually increasing concentration of CO2 in this case). The compensatory mechanism acts as mentioned above to increase the RR and MV, but the alveolar PCO2 decreases or comes back to normal levels due to increased elimination by hyperventilation. 

Option D is not likely in this scenario.

Note: When the inspired concentration of CO2 is more than 7%, despite an increase in respiratory rate, the alveolar and arterial PCO2 increase. This results in hypercapnia, CO2 narcosis, and depression of the central nervous system. Thus, ↓RR ↓MV ↑PCO2  can be observed in such a scenario.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with symptoms of confusion, visual changes, palpitations, and diaphoresis. His family recounts that he has had similar episodes that subside after consuming chocolates. Further workup shows the histopathological finding below. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: C-peptide levels will be low in this patient
Amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes an insulinoma and amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of this condition.

This patient presents with characteristic neuroglycopenic (confusion, visual change, and unusual behavior) and sympatho-adrenergic symptoms (palpitations, diaphoresis, and tremulousness) of hypoglycemia. The image shows neoplastic cells that are monotonous with minimal pleomorphic or mitotic activity. Deposition of amyloid is a characteristic feature of insulinomas.

β-cell tumors (insulinomas) are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50mg/dl. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

The most reliable test for diagnosis is a supervised 72-hr fasting test. Blood examinations reveal increased insulin-to-glucose ratio, high circulating levels of insulin, and c-peptides. Insulinomas may occur in association with gastrinomas in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

Histopathological examination shows giant islets, with preservation of the regular cords of monotonous cells with minimal pleomorphism. Malignant tumors are also well-differentiated. Amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of many insulinomas.

Surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Medical treatment includes frequent meals and diazoxide or octreotide.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old female patient with psoriasis is undergoing the therapeutic modality shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this therapy?

Ultraviolet A - UVA

Ultraviolet B - UVB

Psoralen with Ultraviolet A - PUVA

choices.text: The UVB  spectrum is between 280 and 320 nm
The UVA  spectrum is between 320 and 400 nm
PUVA has a lesser skin cancer risk than UVB
Can be used to treat cutaneous T-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The given image shows phototherapy being used as a treatment modality. UVB is generally preferred over PUVA as it has a lesser skin cancer risk than PUVA. It is also easier to administer and its exposure time is shorter. 

Phototherapy is a form of treatment where nonionizing radiations, commonly ultraviolet radiations are used in a controlled manner over the skin. 

Ultraviolet radiation is divided into three groups based on its wavelength- UVA (320-400nm), UVB (280-320nm), and UVC (<280nm).

UVB- Ultraviolet B rays are the rays that have wavelengths between 280 and 320 nm. If all these wavelengths are used it is called a full spectrum. If only 311–313 nm is used, then it is called narrow-band UVB.  It has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties.

UVA is used in combination with oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer. This combination treatment is termed as PUVA (psoralen with UVA). This leads to crosslinking of DNA with psoralen leading to inhibition of replication, depletion of Langerhans cells, immunosuppression, and restoration of the Th17/regulatory T cell imbalance. 

Phototherapy is used to treat psoriasis, atopic eczema, cutaneous T cell lymphoma, vitiligo, and polymorphic light eruption. 

Phototherapy is contraindicated in dysplastic nevus syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, genetic cancer syndrome, bloom syndrome, and medically unfit and uncompliant patients.

questions.text: A child born to a 35-year-old mother was found to have a round face, flat occiput, and a protruding tongue. Karyotyping of the child is as shown below. Which of the following is commonly associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical findings and the karyotyping suggest a diagnosis of Trisomy 21 or Down syndrome. The most common cardiovascular lesion in Down’s syndrome is an endocardial cushion defect.

Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension.

Other congenital defects are seen in some syndromes:

Syndrome Congenital defect
Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) Endocardial cushion defect, VSD, ASD
XO (Turner syndrome) Bicuspid aortic valve, coarctation of aorta
William's syndrome Supravalvular aortic stenosis, peripheral pulmonic stenosis
Noonan syndrome Pulmonic stenosis, ASD
Holt–Oram syndrome ASD, 1st-degree heart block
Marfan's Syndrome Mitral or Aortic Regurgitation

questions.text: An 86-year-old woman presented with sepsis and a massive right pleural effusion. She developed a chylous effusion 2 days after a chest tube insertion. An injury to the thoracic duct is suspected. Which of the following parts is not drained by it?
questions.solution:
The right upper limb is drained by the right lymphatic duct, not the thoracic duct.

The filtered lymph passes through larger lymphatics and eventually collect into two large trunks, the thoracic duct and right lymphatic duct, which in turn drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

  • Thoracic duct - drains both lower limbs, left upper limb, abdomen, left halves of thorax, and left side of the head and neck regions (areas shaded green in the image).
  • Right lymphatic duct - drains right upper limb, and right halves of thorax, and right side of the head and neck regions (areas shaded blue in the image).

Injury to the thoracic duct is a rare complication of traumatic chest tube insertion.

questions.text: A dead body was found in a forest. The postmortem change shown in the image below was prominently seen in the body. Which of the following features will not be present in the body at this time?

choices.text: A reddish frothy fluid coming out of nostrils and mouth

questions.solution:
The appearance shown in the image is marbling. Prominent marbling is seen in 36-48 hours after death. By this time, rigor mortis disappears.

Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours. It then passes off by 18-36 hours. 

Other changes which are seen in 36-48 hours after death:

  • Well distended abdomen
  • Features become bloated and distorted due to the accumulation of gases of decomposition
  • Breast, scrotum, and penis markedly distended
  • A reddish, frothy fluid may get forced out from the nostrils and mouth as the lungs are forced upwards due to the pressure of gases in the abdomen.
  • Appearance of maggots

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man was recently diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the colon. While explaining the pathogenesis of the disease to him, which of the following would you mention as the "first hit" in the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence?

LOH - Loss of heterozygosity
questions.solution:
The mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21 is the "first hit" in the classical adenoma-carcinoma sequence. 

Adenocarcinoma of the colon is the most common malignancy of the GI tract. The pathogenesis of colon cancer can be explained by three distinct pathways of genomic instability:

  1. Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/Classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence
  2. Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI)
  3. CpG island methylator phenotype pathway.
Chromosomal instability/APC-β-catenin pathway/classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence is the most common pathway, accounting for 80% of sporadic cancers. The "first-hit" in this pathway is the inherited or acquired mutation of the cancer suppressor gene APC on chromosome 5q21. Both copies of the APC gene must be inactivated. The "second hit" is due to methylation abnormalities and inactivation of the normal β-catenin. The loss of the second APC allele follows the "second hit." Mutations of KRAS on chromosome 12p12, TP53 on chromosome 17p13, and LOH at chromosome 18q21 are also involved in further steps of the classic adenoma-carcinoma sequence.
 
Microsatellite instability pathway (MSI) occurs in patients with DNA mismatch repair deficiency, leading to the accumulation of mutations in microsatellite repeats. The main pathogenic mechanisms are mutations of type II TGF-β receptor leading to uncontrolled cell growth, and loss of pro-apoptotic BAX which may enhance the survival of genetically abnormal clones.
 
CpG island hypermethylation phenotype (CIMP) - In these tumors, the MLH1 promoter region is typically hypermethylated, thus reducing MLH1 expression and repair function. Activating mutations in the oncogene BRAF are common in these cancers. KRAS and TP53 are not typically mutated. The combination of MSI, BRAF mutation, and methylation of specific targets, such as MLH1, is the signature of this pathway of carcinogenesis.

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

questions.text: A researcher while studying causality comes across the statement: "When one causal agent is known, the standards of evidence are lowered for a second causal agent that is similar to the known agent in some way." Which of the following Bradford Hill criteria does this statement refer to?
questions.solution:
The Bradford Hill criteria explained in this statement is analogy. 

Bradford Hill criteria are nine criteria that provide a framework for defining the causal relationship in epidemiological studies. 

Analogy means that when one causal agent is known, the standards of evidence are lowered for a second causal agent that is similar to the known agent in some way.

Other Options:

Option A - The consistency criteria are upheld when multiple epidemiologic studies in different settings done by different methods show a consistent association between two variables

Option B - Temporality is interpreted as, for an exposure-disease relationship to be causal, exposure must precede the onset of disease.

Option C -  The criteria for plausibility is satisfied when the association is in agreement with the current knowledge regarding the etiology and mechanism of disease. i.e, there is biological credibility to the association.

Related Pearl: Hill's Criteria for Causal Association

  • It is also called Bradford Hill criteria.
  • It was established in 1965 by English epidemiologist, Sir Austin Bradford Hill.

Criteria

Brief Description

Temporality

Suspected cause precedes observed effect.

Strength

Larger the relative risk, the more likely it is causal.

Consistency

If the association is observed repeatedly under the same or various conditions, then more likely it is causation.

Specificity

When exposure is associated with a specific outcome only, then it is more likely to be causal.

Plausibility

A biologically plausible mechanism between cause and effect can be support for causation.

Coherence

A causal conclusion should not seriously conflict with the present substantive knowledge of the outcome.

Analogy

Other established cause-effect relationships may be used in analogies to support this causal relationship.

Gradient

It is called dose-response or response curve. It refers to the existence of an exposure-response relationship.

Experiment

To check if the condition can be or has been changed, weakened or prevented by experimental approach.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea and syncope. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis.

Aortic stenosis is the narrowing of the aortic valve. It may be caused due to the calcification of the normal aortic valve, calcification of congenital bicuspid valve, and rheumatic heart disease.

Three cardinal clinical features of aortic stenosis are:

  1. Exertional dyspnea - this occurs due to the left ventricular (LV) diastolic dysfunction. Raised end-diastolic LV volume and reduced LV compliance lead to increased LV pressure, leading to elevation of pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.
  2. Angina pectoris - it occurs due to the combination of the increased O2 needs of hypertrophied myocardium and reduction of O2 delivery.
  3. Syncope - it occurs due to the combination of decreased cardiac output and systemic arterial dilation which lead to a reduction of cerebral perfusion.

questions.text: You are the medical officer of a community health center and asked to find out the incidence rate of a disease in your community. Which of the following information cannot be derived from the incidence rate?

choices.text: Magnitude of disease in the community

questions.solution:
The magnitude of disease in the community cannot be assessed from the incidence rate.

The incidence rate is defined as the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. The incidence rate must be described in units of time. It is given by the formula:

Incidence = (Number of new cases of specific disease during a given time period / Population at risk in that period) x 1000.

Incidence measures the rate at which new cases are occurring in a population. The duration of a disease does not affect its incidence. The incidence is generally calculated in acute conditions. Uses of incidence rates as a health status indicator:

  • Incidence can indicate the possible etiology of a disease. For example, a common infectious source would lead to a peak in the incidence of a disease.
  • By studying the pattern of incidence of a disease, we can formulate measures to control the disease outbreak.
  • A decrease in the incidence of a disease would reflect on the efficacy of a therapeutic measure taken to cure that disease.
  • The distribution of disease can be determined by studying incidence with respect to age, geography, gender, socioeconomic standards, etc.

The specialized incidence rates are:

  • Attack rate - It is an incidence rate expressed in percentage. It is used when the population is exposed to a risk factor for a short amount of time as in epidemics.  It reflects the number of new cases in the at-risk population due to the risk factor. 
  • Secondary attack rate - It is defined as the number of cases that develop following exposure to the primary case within one incubation period.

The magnitude of disease or health problems in the community is given by prevalence. It is also useful in identifying potential high-risk populations. Prevalence refers specifically to all current cases (old and new) existing at a given point in time, or over a period of time in a given population. Prevalence rates are useful for administrative and planning purposes like manpower needs, hospital beds needed, etc.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Morbidity Measurements in Epidemiology

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy was brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of pain in the leg, lethargy, and recurrent fevers. Detailed evaluation reveals TdT-positive lymphoblasts in bone marrow aspirate. Which of the following is a good prognostic marker of the above condition?

TdT - terminal deoxy- nucleotidyl transferase
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points towards acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and translocation (12;21) is a good prognostic marker of ALL. 

Acute onset of symptoms of bone marrow suppression such as lethargy, recurrent fever due to infections, and easy bruising in a young male child is suggestive of the diagnosis as ALL. This is supported by the presence of TdT-positive lymphoblasts on bone marrow aspiration.

Favorable prognostic markers of ALL-

  • Age of 2 to 10 years 
  • Low WBC counts. 
  • Hyperdiploidy (> 50 chromosomes )
  • Trisomy 4,7 and 10
  • Translocation (12;21)

Unfavorable prognostic markers of ALL-

  • Age under 2 years, age more than 10 years
  • Peripheral blasts cells >100,000 (Option D)
  • Translocation (9;22) (Option A)
  • Hypodiploidy <44 chromosomes (Option B)
  • Translocation (17;19).

ALL is the most common cancer of children. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is neoplasms of immature B or T cells (lymphoblasts). Two distinct types of ALLs are :

B-ALL T-ALL
More common Less common
Manifest in childhood Manifest in adolescent males
Peak incidence at around 3 years Peak incidence in adolescence
May present as skin or bone manifestations. Present as thymic neoplasms

Both immature B and T cells stain positive for terminal deoxy- nucleotidyl transferase (TdT). The most common molecular pathology behind ALL is hyperdiploidy (>50 chromosomes). The chromosomal abnormalities present in ALL block the functions of transcription factors that are needed for normal B and T cell development.

Clinical features:

  • Acute in onset within days to weeks
  • Symptoms due to bone marrow depression such as lethargy and fatigue due to anemia, recurrent infections due to leukopenia, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia.
  • Mass effects such as bone pain, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement.
  • Central nervous system manifestations such as headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies resulting from the meningeal spread.

Examination of bone marrow aspirates shows, a hypercellular bone marrow packed with lymphoblasts. In both B-ALL and T-ALL, the tumor cells have scant basophilic cytoplasm and nuclei somewhat larger than those of small lymphocytes. These cells are also myeloperoxidase-negative and often contain periodic acid–Schiff– positive cytoplasmic material.

The mainstay of treatment is multiagent chemotherapy.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the demographic process and cycle of various countries.  In which stages of the demographic cycle would he observe a stationary population?
questions.solution:
The population remains stationary in stages 1 and 4 in the demographic cycle.

Stage 1 - This stage is also known as high-stationary. The population remains stationary due to very high birth and death rates that cancel each other out. India was is in this stage until 1920.

Stage 4 - This stage is also known as low-stationary. The population remains stationary due to very low birth and death rates that cancel each other out.  Countries like the United Kingdom, Denmark, Sweden, and Belgium were in this stage in 1980-85.

Related Pearl: Demographic Process and Cycle

Stages of the demographic cycle include:

  • Stage 1 - High stationary 
    • High birth rates and high death rates render the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 2 - Early expanding 
    • The death rate declines and the birth rate remains unchanged
    • The demographic gap starts increasing and becomes maximum
  • Stage 3 - Late expanding
    • Death rate declines further and birth rate falls
    • India is in this stage, currently
    • The demographic gap starts declining
  • Stage 4 - Low stationary 
    • Low birth rate and low death rate renders the population stationary
    • Narrow demographic gap
  • Stage 5 - Declining 
    • The population begins to decline as the birth rate is lower than the death rate
    • The demographic gap is negative

questions.text: A healthy boy is brought to the pediatrician for a regular check-up. He runs up to the play area and makes a tower of 6 cubes. His mother tells that he has started eating with a spoon for one month. He is unable to tell his full age and gender correctly. Which of the following activities will he not be able to do?

choices.text: Walks up and down the stairs, 1 step at a time

questions.solution:
The history elicited from the mother leads to the conclusion that the boy is aged 2 years. He cannot tell stories at this age.

The child who is able to make a tower of 6 blocks and handles the spoon well is around 2 years of age and he will not be able to tell a story at the age of 2 years. Storytelling is attained at the age of 4 years. Knowledge of one's age and gender is attained at 36 months of age.

Developmental milestones at the age of two:

Social and Emotional:

The child will be able to handle the spoon well, usually tells about the immediate experience, listen to stories when shown with pictures, help to undress self, copy adults, and older children.

Language and Communication:

The child will be able to make simple sentences of 2-4 words with meaning and has a vocabulary of around 50-100 words. The child will be able to understand 2-step commands such as "bring your shoes and then go to play", and points to things or pictures when they are named.

Cognitive:

The child will be able to make a tower of 6-7 cubes, imitates to make a horizontal stroke, scribble in a circular pattern, imitates fold a paper once, names items in a picture book such as a cat, dog, etc.

Motor:

The child will be able to run well, climb the stairs up and down with 1 step at a time, open doors, and climbs on furniture.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female patient presents with worsening redness of her face for the past week. She had started using makeup two weeks ago daily. On noticing the redness, she has been applying more makeup to cover it up. On examination, you notice erythema of the face with mild scaling.  Which of the following is the long-term management for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has allergic contact dermatitis due to cosmetics. The long-term management for allergic contact dermatitis is avoidance of allergens.

This patient has erythema and scaling on her face after she started using makeup. These symptoms are consistent with those of allergic contact dermatitis. The symptoms worsened when she used more makeup (allergen) to cover up her symptoms.

Allergic contact dermatitis is defined as an eczematous reaction that occurs as an immunological response following exposure to a substance to which the immune system has previously been sensitized. Allergic contact dermatitis to cosmetics usually causes erythema and scaling. The severity of symptoms depends on the product used and where it was applied.

The incidence of cosmetic contact dermatitis has reduced due to strict manufacturing regulations. However, the use of fragrances to improve product appeal may still cause dermatitis. The most common causes of cosmetic allergic contact dermatitis are fragrances and preservatives. 

Long-term treatment of allergic contact dermatitis involves avoidance of the allergen. Patch testing can confirm the specific allergen involved. The International Nomenclature Cosmetic Ingredient (INCI) name of the allergen can be provided to the patient since this is the name that will be used on product labels. 

An acute flare-up can be managed with topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors (tacrolimus, pimecrolimus). For severe, extensive involvement, systemic corticosteroids can be used. 

The following image shows allergic contact dermatitis in response to poison ivy. 

Other options: 

Option A - Systemic corticosteroids are indicated when there is involvement of more than 20% of the body surface area. In addition, it is useful for acute relief of symptoms, not long-term management. 

Option C - The use of barrier creams is not helpful once the patient has been sensitized to the allergen. 

Option D - Cyclosporin can be administered if there is chronic contact dermatitis and when allergens cannot be avoided, as in airborne contact dermatitis.

questions.text: A child presents to you with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and hematuria. Which of the following statement is false about the syndromes associated with this condition?

choices.text: Trisomy 18 can result in cognitive impairment
Aniridia is associated with WAGR syndrome
Male abnormal genitalia is commonly seen in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome
Early-onset renal failure is characteristic of Denys-Drash syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a diagnosis of Wilms tumor. Male abnormal genitalia is associated with Denys-Drash syndrome and not with Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome. Both of these are syndromes associated with Wilm's tumor. 

Wilms tumor is the most common primary malignant renal tumor in children. After neuroblastoma, it is the second most common malignant abdominal tumor in childhood. The clinical presentation of Wilms tumor is an incidental discovery of asymptomatic abdominal mass, hypertension, abdominal pain, and gross painless hematuria. Pulmonary embolism can be a fatal complication. 

Wilm's tumor arises due to loss of function mutation of the WT1 (Wilm's tumor 1) gene. The syndromes associated with Wilms tumor are WAGR syndrome, Denys-Drash syndrome, Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome, Fraiser syndrome, Fanconi anemia, trisomy 18, and Perlman syndrome.

Noteworthy syndromes and their features are:

  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, aniridia, genitourinary abnormalities, mental retardation
  • Denys-Drash syndrome: Early-onset renal failure, gonadal dysgenesis / male pseudohermaphroditism
  • Beckwith-Weidemann syndrome: Hemihypertrophy, organomegaly, macroglossia
  • Trisomy 18: Prominent occiput, cognitive impairment, hypertonia

Histologically, Wilms tumor is made of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cells. 

Wilms tumor is an example of small, round, blue-cell tumors that are malignant neoplasms that have a characteristic appearance under the microscope. Other examples include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The diagnosis can be confirmed by radiological investigations like CT, abdominal ultrasound, and biopsy.

Surgery, and chemotherapy, with or without radiotherapy can be used for the management.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient presented with dysarthria, dystonia, and depression. Ocular examination findings are shown below. Laboratory evaluation shows elevated transaminases and increased urinary copper excretion. Which of the following is not consistent with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with dysarthria, dystonia, and depression with high urinary copper excretion and elevated liver enzymes is suggestive of Wilson's disease. The given image shows the Kayser-Fleischer ring that occurs due to copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea. Low serum hepcidin is not associated with Wilson's disease, but rather with hemochromatosis.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. There is a copper overload that primarily affects the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the brain (leading to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms). 

Clinical features of Wilson's disease include: 

  • Hepatic features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient might develop cirrhosis and acute decompensation of liver function. Massive release of copper into the circulation from the liver can lead to hemolytic anemia (option A).
  • Neurologic features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia (option D).
  • Psychiatric features include personality changes (irritability, anger) depression, and anxiety.
  • Ocular features include Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract. 
  • Other manifestations include renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis. 

Reduced serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper excretion point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Percutaneous liver biopsy for measuring hepatic copper content is the gold standard investigation for establishing the diagnosis.

Copper chelation in patients with Wilson's disease is done using penicillamine. Pyridoxine is prescribed with penicillamine to counteract the deficiency that may develop with the treatment. In patients with predominant neurological manifestations, trientine is used as the chelating agent because penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms. Tetrathiomolybdate is under trial for the treatment of Wilson's disease. Zinc is used for maintenance therapy in patients after the initial chelation is complete.

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disorder associated with a decrease in the functioning of hepcidin. This leads to increased absorption of intestinal iron. There is a deposition of this excessive iron in parenchymal cells, leading to cirrhosis, diabetes mellitus, bronze discoloration of the skin, congestive cardiac failure, hypogonadism, and arthropathy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl underwent abdominal ultrasound as a part of the evaluation for stomach ache. She was incidentally found to have an absent uterus and intra-abdominal testes. Clinical examination revealed female external genitalia and breast development appropriate for age but sparse axillary and pubic hair. The karyotype is 46,XY. Which of the following is not preferred as a treatment option in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) and immediate orchidectomy at diagnosis is not a treatment option to manage this condition. Orchidectomy should preferably be performed after pubertal maturation in a patient with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome. It is preferably done at 16-18 years.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder in which the androgen receptors are absent, or scanty, or fail to respond to testosterone. As a result, resistance to androgens may be complete, and female external genitalia are found. The individual has a genetic makeup of 46XY but is phenotypically a female. The Wolffian duct fails to develop because of the absence of testosterone receptors. Testes produce Mullerian-inhibiting factors, so the Müllerian system fails to develop. However, the lower portion of the vagina derived from the sinovaginal bulb appears as a dimple of 1–2 cm in length.

AIS can be present in two forms:

  • Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome

In complete AIS, the individual is born as a phenotypically normal female but generally presents with primary amenorrhea. The external genitalia appears normal, with absent or scant pubic and axillary hair. The vagina is shortened and blind-ending with an absent uterus and ovaries. These patients may also present with a history of childhood inguinal hernias, due to the presence of undescended testis in the abdomen or in the inguinal canal. Due to the constant conversion of testosterone into estrogen, these individuals have normal breast development.

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound reveals the absence of ovaries and the uterus.
  • Testosterone > 200 ng/mL
  • Leutinizing hormone level is raised, but follicle-stimulating hormone level is normal.
  • Chromosome study reveals XY chromosomes.

Management:

  • Identify the location of ectopic testis and perform orchidectomy after puberty to prevent malignant degeneration. Malignant transformation usually does not occur until after puberty.
  • Estrogen therapy for the development of the breasts as well as to prevent osteoporosis
  • Surgical vaginoplasty at the time of marriage
  • Absent reproductive function, surrogacy is considered.

In partial AIS, a few receptors do respond to testosterone, whereby the clinical features are variable. Some patients present at birth with ambiguous genitalia, and chromosome study reveals XY chromosomes, while others present at puberty, with lack of virilization in a boy or signs of virilization in a girl with primary amenorrhoea.

The treatment is based on the sex in which the child is reared, psychological behavior, and the amount of virilization. If the child is reared as female, it is best to perform gonadectomy in childhood to avoid virilization. In a boy, testosterone will help.

questions.text: The sustainable development goals adopted in 2015 aim to reduce the under 5 mortality rate to as low as ___  per 1000 live births by the year 2030.
questions.solution:
The sustainable development goals adopted in 2015 aim to reduce the under 5 mortality to as low as 25 per 1000 live births by the year 2030.

The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), also known as the Global Goals, were adopted by the United Nations in 2015 as a call to action to end poverty, protect the planet, and ensure that by 2030 all people enjoy peace and prosperity.

It consists of 17 integrated sustainable development goals to be achieved by the year 2030 with priority being given to countries that are furthest behind. The SDGs are designed to end poverty, hunger, AIDS, and discrimination against women and girls.

SDG 3 deals with ensuring healthy lives and promoting wellbeing for all at all ages. The important sub-targets of SDG 3 are:

Sub-target Goal

3.2
  • Reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12/1000 live births.
  • Reduce under 5 mortality to at least as low as 25/1000 live births.
3.3 End epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, and neglected tropical diseases, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, and other communicable diseases
3.5 Prevention and treatment of substance abuse, narcotic abuse, and harmful use of alcohol.
3.7 Universal access to sexual and reproductive health care services, including family planning.
3.9 Substantially reduce deaths and illnesses due to hazardous chemicals and air, water, and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: A microbiologist is culturing strains of various bacteria. One of the bacteria produces various pigments such as pyocyanin, pyorubin, and pyomelanin. Which of the following is the most common community-acquired infection caused by this bacteria?
questions.solution:
The species of bacteria that produce the pigments pyocyanin, pyorubin, and pyomelanin is Pseudomonas. The most common community-acquired infection caused by Pseudomonas is suppurative otitis. 

Pseudomonas causes a lot of hospital-acquired infections. This usually occurs as a result of secondary infection of wounds and bedsores (Option A). Infection following instrumentation is common like urinary tract infections (Option C) after catheterization and acute cholangitis (Option D) following endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography. Other hospital-acquired infections caused by Pseudomonas include septicemia, endocarditis, ecthyma gangrenosum, and infection of the nailbed. 

Pseudomonas is a group of aerobic, non-sporing, gram negative bacilli. It is motile with the help of a single, polar flagellum. Although it does not have a capsule, it has a mucoid slime layer which is a defense mechanism. 

Cultural characteristics: 

Pseudomonas grows well on ordinary media, forms non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey medium, and are hemolytic on blood agar. It forms dense turbidity with surface pedicles when grown in broth. 

It produces many pigments. Pyocyanin is blue-green in color and is only produced by P. aeruginosa. Fluorescein or pyoverdin is a greenish-yellow pigment. Pseudomonas also produces pyorubin and pyomelanin which are red and brown pigments respectively. 

Pseudomonas is catalase-positive, and oxidase-positive. 

Resistance:

Pseudomonas is not heat resistant, but it is resistant to common antiseptics. It can even grow in antiseptic bottles like Dettol or cetrimide selective medium that has been stored in the hospital. 

Pathogenesis: 

Pseudomonas produces extracellular toxins that contribute to its pathogenicity. This includes exotoxin A which behaves similarly to the diphtheria toxin by inhibiting protein synthesis. It also produces enzymes like proteases, elastase, hemolysins, and enterotoxin. The slime layer contributes to biofilm production. 

The below image shows the pyocyanin pigment produced by Pseudomonas.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male patient had a stroke involving the medulla and pons, which led to the complete obliteration of the vagal input to the esophagus. Which of the following changes in esophageal peristalsis are likely to be seen after a few days?

choices.text: Elimination of primary esophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of secondary esophageal peristalsis only
Elimination of both primary and secondary esophageal peristalsis
No change in primary or secondary esophageal peristalsis

questions.solution:
The absence of vagal input to the esophagus will result in the elimination of only primary peristalsis of esophagus. The secondary peristalsis will remain intact due to the activity of the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus. Within a few days, the excitability of the myenteric plexus increases, resulting in strong secondary peristaltic waves.

There are two types of esophageal peristaltic movements: primary and secondary.

A. Primary peristalsis occurs as a continuation of the peristaltic wave that begins in the pharynx and spreads into the esophagus during the pharyngeal stage of swallowing. It passes from the pharynx to the esophagus, within about 8 to 10 seconds. However, due to the effect of gravity in an upright position, the food passes within 5 to 8 seconds.

B. Secondary peristalsis occurs if the primary peristaltic wave failed to empty the food from the esophagus into the stomach. Secondary peristalsis is initiated by the distension of the esophageal wall by the retained food. Waves continue until all the food is emptied into the stomach. Secondary peristaltic waves are initiated partly by intrinsic neural circuits in the myenteric nervous system and partly by reflexes that begin in the pharynx. 

Control of peristaltic waves: The musculature of the pharyngeal wall and upper third of the esophagus is striated muscle. These regions are controlled by skeletal nerve impulses from the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves.

The musculature of the lower two-thirds of the esophagus is smooth muscle. This region is strongly controlled by the vagus nerves, which act through connections with the esophagal myenteric nervous system.

Effect of obliteration of vagal input to the esophagus: When the vagal nerves are cut, or the vagal input is obliterated by any other cause such as stroke, the primary peristalsis, solely dependent on the vagal innervation, is eliminated. 

However, the intrinsic myenteric nerve plexus of the esophagus becomes excitable within days, causes strong secondary peristaltic waves. Therefore, even after paralysis of the brain stem swallowing reflex, food fed by a tube into the esophagus passes into the stomach due to the secondary peristaltic movements.

questions.text: A young woman presents with fatigue, diarrhea, and weight loss. She reports that the stool is bulky, pale, and foul-smelling. On examination, she has pallor and itchy rashes on her elbows, as shown below. Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies are noted to be positive. What is the treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is consistent with celiac disease/celiac sprue/gluten-sensitive enteropathy, and the treatment is avoidance of gluten. 

The image shows grouped erythematous papules and vesicles over the elbow. This is dermatitis herpetiformis, the cutaneous manifestation of celiac disease. It generally presents on the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. These lesions are intensely pruritic and occur due to IgA deposits in dermal papillae.

Celiac disease is characterized by autoantibodies to tissue transglutaminase leading to an excessive inflammatory response to gluten and its breakdown product, gliadin. This leads to inflammatory infiltration of the lamina propria and impairs nutrient absorption. Gluten is commonly found in wheat, barley, and rye. 

It is characterized by:

  • Gastrointestinal manifestations such as bloating and irregular bowel habits. There is villous atrophy in the proximal intestine causing steatorrhea (bulky, pale, and foul-smelling) as well as fluid hypersecretion from crypt epithelium. 
  • Extraintestinal manifestations: 
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis - pruritic papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces of the limbs
    • DEficiency of vitamins B12 and E causing ataxia and peripheral neuropathy
    • Iron-deficiency anemia
    • Hyposplenism
    • Abnormal liver enzymes
    • Increased risk of malignancy such as enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma and small-bowel adenocarcinoma.
    • Refractory celiac disease 

Screening for celiac disease is done by testing for tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deamidated anti-gliadin antibodies. Diagnosis is confirmed by small-intestinal biopsy, which shows characteristic villus blunting and crypt hyperplasia and inflammation. Given below is a histopathological image of celiac disease:

Treatment of celiac disease involves strict avoidance of gluten.

Other options: 

Option B - Broad-spectrum antibiotics and folic acid are used to treat tropical sprue. It is characterized by chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and nutritional deficiency. It occurs in people who live in tropical climates.  To diagnose tropical sprue, malabsorption of two unrelated substances is required. 

Option C - Sulfasalazine is administered in patients with ulcerative colitis. It is characterized by rectal bleeding, diarrhea, passing mucus, and abdominal pain. 

Option D - Opiates are used to treat short bowel syndrome. This will reduce the frequency of passing stool. Short bowel syndrome occurs in people who have had an intestinal resection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female patient presented with foreign body sensation, blurring of vision, and mucopurulent discharge from the left eye for the last two days. The other eye is starting to get itchy. The ocular findings are shown below. What is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with marked conjunctival congestion, chemosis, and flakes of mucopus seen in the fornices is likely to have acute bacterial conjunctivitis. The treatment is topical chloramphenicol. 

Treatment of acute bacterial conjunctivitis should ideally involve antibiotics selected after culture and sensitivity. However, this takes time. Thus, broad-spectrum antibiotics like chloramphenicol, gentamicin, or tobramycin may be given. Drops should be administered 3 to 4 times a day.

Systemic antibiotics may be used in specific circumstances like gonococcal infection, H. influenza infection in children, and meningococcal conjunctivitis. 

Dark goggles can help the photophobia, and anti-inflammatory and analgesic drugs can provide symptomatic relief. It is important that the patient washes their hands frequently and avoids sharing pillows and towels with others to reduce the spread of infection. 

Bacterial conjunctivitis is an infection of the conjunctiva. The most common causative organisms are Streptococcus pneumonia, Staphylococcus aureus, Hemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis.

It is transmitted through close contact, material transfer via infected fingers and towels, and vector transmission. It can also spread locally from infected nasopharynx, lacrimal sac, and eyelids. 

Clinical features of bacterial conjunctivitis include discomfort, foreign body sensation, photophobia, mucopurulent discharge, blurring of vision, and colored halos. The examination will reveal flakes of mucopus, conjunctival congestion, chemosis, fine papillae, petechial hemorrhages, matted cilia, and edematous eyelids. 

It usually affects both the eyes but in some cases, one eye will be affected before the other. If untreated, it may resolve or become chronic catarrhal conjunctivitis. 

Complications include superficial punctate epitheliopathy, corneal ulceration, superficial keratitis, blepharitis, or dacryocystitis. 

Other options:

Option B - Topical oxytetracycline is used to treat angular bacterial conjunctivitis. It is caused by Moraxella axenfield. It is characterized by mild inflammation of the conjunctiva at the junction of the lid margins and the angles of the eyes. 

Option C - Topical carboxymethyl cellulose or artificial tears are used to soothe symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis. It is characterized by itching, hyperemia, and a papillary response of the conjunctiva. 

Option D - Cold compresses and sunglasses are used to soothe symptoms and reduce glare in adenoviral conjunctivitis. It is characterized by sudden onset redness, discomfort, lymphadenopathy, and photophobia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes with a history of a hip fracture which was treated surgically, four months ago. You observe him walking with the gait shown below. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of left superior gluteal nerve injury. 

The patient shows characteristic lurching gait/ Trendelenburg's gait (positive Trendelenburg's sign), which is seen in paralysis of gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. These muscles are supplied by the superior gluteal nerve. 

When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius and minimus muscles, on the opposite supported side, exert traction on the hip bone by acting from the femur. This action results in the slight raising of the pelvis on the unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in the upright position.

When the gluteus medius and minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on the unsupported (normal) side, when the patient tries to stand on the affected limb.

In the given case, when the patient lifts up his right leg and tries to stand on the left leg, his right pelvis tilts down. This shows that the left side abduction mechanism is paralyzed and the right side is normal. Hence, the left superior gluteal nerve injury is present in this case.

The image given below shows the Trendelenberg test.

Note: Inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle.

Related Pearl: Eponyms named after Friedrich Trendelenburg

  • Trendelenburg sign: This sign is demonstrated by asking the patient to stand on one limb. When the patient stands on the affected limb, the pelvis severely drops over the swing limb. This is seen in the paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus, dislocated hip, fracture neck of femur
  • Trendelenburg gait: This gait is seen in patients with Trendelenburg sign. The body swings to the opposite side every time when the weight is borne on the same side. 
  • Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's head is lower than his feet (head-down position)
  • Reverse Trendelenberg position: It is a position in which the patient is placed on a bed which is put into incline such that the patient's feet are lower than his head (head-up position)
  • Brodie Trendelenburg test: It is a test for presence of incompetent valves in lower limb.

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1L1 woman at term is admitted to the labor room for normal vaginal delivery. A per vaginal examination was performed once her membranes ruptured, and a pulsatile cord-like structure was felt. An immediate ultrasound revealed that the baby was still alive, and cardiotocography revealed prolonged and variable decelerations. What is the definitive management in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of cord prolapse and the definitive management in this condition is delivery of the baby by cesarean section.

The management algorithm of cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

  • Living or dead baby
  • Maturity of the baby
  • Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is the delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

  • If the baby is dead - 
    • Reconfirmation with ultrasound
    • Spontaneous delivery when death is confirmed
    • Destructive operations are rarely needed
  • If immediate safe vaginal delivery is possible - 
    • When the fetal head is engaged - delivery by forceps. Ventouse is not ideal in such circumstances as it takes a longer time 
    • Breech presentation - the delivery is to be completed by breech extraction
    • Transverse lie - the internal podalic version, followed by breech extraction
  • When immediate safe vaginal delivery is not possible - 
    • Relieve pressure on the cord
    • Oxytocin infusion is stopped
    • Oxygen supplementation and intravenous fluids are given

The contraindications of immediate delivery are fetal death, lethal fetal anomalies, and a pre-viable gestation.

Forceps-assisted (Option A) delivery can be done if deemed quicker and the head is engaged. But, this is not the definitive management. Manual repositioning (Option D) of the cord is done to minimize exposure to the external environment that may induce vasospasm due to colder temperatures. It is rarely used nowadays and Vago's method is preferred.

In Vago's method (Option B) a Foleys catheter is placed and the bladder is filled with >500 mL of saline, and then clamped. The patient’s enlarging bladder provides upward pressure on the fetus and alleviates the compression of the cord and helps decrease uterine contractions. It is generally used to stabilize the mother and baby until definitive management is done. 

Other methods that may be used:

  • Manual elevation of the fetal presenting part using two fingers or the whole hand through the vagina
  • Positioning of the patient in a steep Trendelenburg position, an exaggerated Sim’s position, or knee-chest position as shown below
  • Tocolysis can be considered if there is a prolonged interval before delivery, but is associated with a risk of uterine atony after delivery

questions.text:
A middle-aged man developed severe pain abdomen and fever 3 days after undergoing surgery for bowel perforation. There is no dehiscence or discharge from the sutured wound seen. His blood pressure was 60/40mmHg and his intra-abdominal pressure was 35mmHg. The procedure in the given image was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?

IAP- Intrabdominal pressure
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is abdominal compartment syndrome.

The above clinical features of increase in intraabdominal pressure >35 mmHg without any wound dehiscence, discharge and the given image showing rapid decompression of the abdomen by letting out the bowel and covering it with a plastic bag (Bogota bag) are suggestive of abdominal compartment syndrome.

Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP) leading to organ dysfunction. The normal IAP is 5-7 mmHg. When the IAP is > 12 mmHg, it is termed intra-abdominal hypertension. Abdominal compartment syndrome occurs when the IAP is > 20 mmHg as in this clinical scenario.

Physiological changes in ACS are:

  • Central nervous system- Increased intracranial pressure
  • Respiratory system- Decreased compliance, increased airway pressures, pulmonary artery pressure, and central venous pressure
  • Cardiovascular system- Decreased venous return, cardiac output, stroke volume, and increased systemic vascular resistance
  • Renal system- Decreased renal blood flow, glomerular filtration rate, and urine output

Grading of ACS:

  • Grade I: 10-15 mmHg
  • Grade II: 16-25 mmHg
  • Grade III: 26-35 mmHg
  • Grade IV: > 35 mmHg

Diagnosis is made by measuring IAP using a urinary bladder (Foley's catheter) or gastric catheter. CT scan, abdominal perfusion pressure, renal filtration gradient are some of the tests done to check organ dysfunction.

The primary goal of management is to reduce the IAP. So rapid decompression is done by opening the abdomen and performing a temporary closure of the abdominal wall using a mesh or a plastic bag (Bogota bag). After the resuscitation and management of the specific causes, a definite closure of the abdomen can be done by vacuum-assisted closure (VAC), split-skin graft, or prosthetic mesh.

Other options:

Option B- Meleney's synergistic gangrene of the abdominal wall is the post-operative infection due to microaerophilic streptococci, staphylococci and other anaerobes. It is characterized by sudden pain, redness, blackening, and gangrene of the skin with abdominal wall necrosis. It is most commonly seen in HIV, diabetes, and immunocompromised people. Treatment includes antibiotics like penicillins and metronidazole, excision of the gangrenous tissue till it bleeds, skin grafting and management of toxaemia, hyperbaric oxygen, and critical care.

Option C- Burst abdomen is the mechanical wound failure causing separation of the closed abdominal wound associated with abdominal content evisceration. It usually occurs between the 5th and 8th postoperative days. A sudden giving way feeling from the wound precipitated by bouts of cough, pinkish serosanguinous discharge can be seen. Omentum or coils of the intestine are forced out of the wound. Management includes delayed closure with initial mesh wrap or Bogota bag, placing a subcutaneous drain, suitable antibiotic therapy, and prevention of abdominal compartment syndrome as described above.

Below is an image showing a burst abdomen.

Option D- Divarication of recti is the thinning of the linea alba in the epigastrium with protrusion of the abdominal wall with prominent edges of both recti. It becomes prominent on lifting the head from the bed. No treatment is required in the divarication of recti.

Related Pearl: Physiological Consequences of Increased Intra-abdominal Pressure

Decreased :

  • Cardiac output
  • Venous return
  • Visceral blood ﬂow
  • Renal blood ﬂow
  • Glomerular filtration

Increased :

  • Cardiac rate
  • Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure
  • Peak inspiratory pressure
  • Central venous pressure
  • Intrapleural pressure
  • Systemic vascular resistance

questions.text: While karyotyping a sample of cells to look for the presence of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, the dividing cells are arrested in which phase of the cell cycle?
questions.solution:
For karyotyping, dividing cells are arrested in the metaphase in the M-phase of the cell cycle.

Chromosomes isolated from cells during the metaphase stage of mitosis are chosen for karyotyping because, it is during metaphase that the chromosomes assume their characteristic condensed, discrete shape.

The cell cycle refers to the events surrounding eukaryotic DNA replication and cell division (mitosis). The period preceding DNA replication is called the Gap 1 phase (G1). DNA replication occurs during the synthesis (S) phase. Following DNA synthesis, there is the Gap 2 phase (G2) before mitosis occurs (M). Cells that have stopped dividing, for example, T lymphocytes, have gone out of the cell cycle into the G0 phase.

There are five stages in mitosis namely prophase, prometaphase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. These occur in strictly sequential order. In metaphase, the individual chromosomes take the form of two chromatids connected at the centromere. Hence, in metaphase chromosomes can be visualized clearly during karyotyping.

The image given below shows different phases of the cell cycle:


Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

questions.text: A researcher is using the instrument given below to measure air humidity. Which of the following statement is true regarding the instrument?

choices.text: Can be used in strong sunshine
Most widely used instrument for measuring air humidity

questions.solution:
The given image is identified as an Assmann psychrometer. The true statement is that it can be used in strong sunshine. 

Psychrometers are instruments used for the measurement of air humidity. The commonly used are:

  1. Assman psychrometer.
  2. Dry and wet bulb hygrometer
  3. Sling psychrometer

These instruments consist of two thermometers, a wet and dry one. The relative humidity is then calculated using the readings of these thermometers and psychometric charts. 

Assman psychrometer is a portable instrument designed to give an accurate measurement of the wet and dry bulb temperature of the air. This instrument draws in air at a speed of > 5 m/sec by a clock-work fan after which readings are noted. The bulbs of the thermometer are protected from solar radiation so that the instrument can be used even in strong sunshine.

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer is the most widely used instrument for measuring air humidity. It consists of two identical thermometers - a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer, mounted side by side on a stand. 

A Sling psychrometer is also known as whirling psychrometer consists of two thermometers (wet and dry) mounted side by side, on a suitable wooden frame, and provided with a handle for rotating the instrument as shown below. The wet bulb is rotated for 15 seconds facing away from the sun to obtain an airspeed of about 5 m/sec after which readings are noted.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers
