questions.text: An anesthetist is performing the regional block technique shown in the image given below. This technique cannot be used for analgesia/anesthesia in which of the following conditions/procedures?
questions.solution:
The image shows a needle at the midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid. This procedure is used in superficial cervical plexus block. This cannot be used to provide analgesia for a dislocated shoulder.

Interscalene blocks are used to provide regional anaesthesia for conditions of the shoulder like shoulder dislocation.

The cervical plexus is derived from the C1, C2, C3, and C4 spinal nerves and innervates prevertebral muscles, strap muscles of the neck, and the phrenic nerve. The superficial cervical plexus provides a cutaneous sensation of the skin between the trigeminal innervation of the face and the T2 dermatome of the trunk. The deep cervical plexus innervates the musculature of the neck.

Cervical plexus blocks (CPB) are techniques of regional anaesthesia that is used to provide anaesthesia/analgesia in various head and neck surgeries.

The superficial cervical block is achieved by inserting a 22-gauge needle, at the midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. The needle is inserted 4 cm deep, and 5 mL of the solution is injected along the posterior border and the medial surface of the sternocleidomastoid.

This technique can be used for surgeries like

  • Carotid endarterectomy 
  • Thyroidectomy
  • Tracheostomy
  • Lymph node dissection
  • Plastic surgery repairs
  • Minimally invasive parathyroidectomy
  • External ear surgery

The complications that may occur are inadvertent intravascular injection; phrenic nerve injury (rare); blocking of the accessory nerve, leading to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscle weakness; and puncture of the internal jugular vein and carotid artery.

This technique is contraindicated if there is an active infection overlying the injection site, contralateral phrenic nerve palsy, previous neck surgery and radiation, and allergy to injected drugs.

Interscalene block results in the blockade of the superficial and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. To perform this technique, the patient should be in the supine position, with the head turned away from the side to be blocked. The interscalene groove is palpated. A transverse line from the cricoid cartilage is drawn to intersect the interscalene groove. This point of intersection indicates the transverse process of C6 where the drug is administered.

questions.text:
A woman presents with insidious onset worsening exertional breathlessness and occasional exertional chest pain. On examination, she has increased JVP, peripheral edema, ascites, and a loud P2. Her investigations are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
  • Chest X-ray - enlarged central pulmonary arteries and vascular pruning 
  • Echocardiography - hypertrophied right ventricle
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

JVP: Jugulovenous pulse, STEMI: ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is pulmonary hypertension. 

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is characterized by an elevation in pulmonary arterial pressures and increased vascular resistance caused by various causes. It is defined by mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) > 20mmHg

Clinical features include dyspnea, edema, chest pain, and syncope. It is irreversible as it does not have a curative treatment and thus can lead to decompensated right heart failure and death. 

Clinical signs may include right heart failure features such as elevated JVP, edema, ascites as a result of disease progression. Chest auscultation may reveal loud P2, S3 and S4. 

Investigations of PH include: 

  • Echocardiogram with bubble study - it is an important screening test. It usually shows a dilated, hypertrophied right ventricle and increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure.
  • Right heart catheterization - it is the gold standard test to establish the diagnosis of PH and to select appropriate therapy.
  • Chest X-ray - may show obliteration of retrosternal space, enlarged pulmonary arteries, and peripheral vascular pruning.
  • ECG - right ventricular hypertrophy

Other options: 

Option A: Acute STEMI would reveal ST elevations in ECG. It is an acute event while this patient has had insidious onset exertional chest pain. Pain is classically described as heavy, squeezing, and crushing. Cardiac biomarkers are also raised in STEMI.

Option C: Left-sided heart failure is characterized by pulmonary edema, dyspnea, orthopnea, and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Elevated JVP, weight gain, gastrointestinal symptoms and ascites are signs of right-sided heart failure. 

Option D: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is the most common cause of sudden death in young individuals. It is characterized by exertional dyspnea, angina, left-sided congestion, and left-ventricular outflow obstruction.

questions.text:
Identify the correctly matched pair of inhibitory cells in the olfactory sensory pathway and the neurotransmitter they secrete.

GABA - Gamma-aminobutyric acid

choices.text: Mitral cells and periglomerular cells - Glycine
Periglomerular cells and granule cells - GABA
Granule cells and tufted cells - Glycine
Tufted cells and mitral cells - GABA

questions.solution:
The correctly matched pair is periglomerular cells and granule cells - Gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA).

Cells involved in the olfactory pathway are:

  • Olfactory neurons are bipolar neurons present in the roof of the nasal cavity that pass through the cribriform plate and project into the olfactory bulb.
  • Mitral and tufted cells are primary excitatory cells present in the olfactory bulb. Together, they are known as the olfactory glomeruli. These cells act via glutamate. 
  • Periglomerular cells connect one glomerulus to another. They are present in the olfactory bulb. These are inhibitory cells that act via GABA. 
  • Granule cells are devoid of any axons and cause reciprocal inhibition by forming synapses with lateral dendrites of mitral and tufted cells. They are present in the olfactory bulb. They reciprocally inhibit the olfactory glomeruli acting via GABA.
  • Supporting cells secrete mucus that dissolves odorants and provides an appropriate molecular and ionic environment.

Olfactory pathway:

The olfactory neurons have olfactory receptors which are G-protein coupled receptors with cAMP as second messengers. The axons of olfactory neurons synapse with mitral and tufted cells of the olfactory glomeruli in the olfactory bulb. Each glomerulus is connected to the other by periglomerular cells and granule cells. 

The axons of mitral and tufted cells pass via the lateral olfactory striae to terminate on five regions of the olfactory cortex:

  • Anterior olfactory nucleus
  • Olfactory tubercle
  • Piriform cortex
  • Amygdala
  • Entorhinal cortex

These regions, via the thalamus, connect to the olfactory center is present on the orbital surface of the prefrontal cortex.

Olfactory dysfunction is an early marker of Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness.

Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates right-sided conductive deafness or left-sided sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne's test is positive on both the ears, conductive deafness can be ruled out and hence, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of heaviness of head, swelling on the forehead, and dull headache throughout the day. The image shows a CT scan of the skull. Biochemical tests show raised alkaline phosphatase and normal serum calcium. The most likely diagnosis is?

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given image shows Tam o'Shanter sign and clinical findings suggest Paget's disease of bone or osteitis deformans.

Paget's disease is characterized by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. This causes localized sites of lysis and excavations in bone. This is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone because of increased osteoblastic activity. The internal architecture is abnormal and the bone is unusually brittle. Raised levels of plasma alkaline phosphatase is seen. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal

The radiological signs seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected.
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

Image shows cotton wool appearance of skull seen in Paget's disease.

Tam o'Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph resembling the Scottish Tam o'Shanter hat.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism is caused due to increased parathyroid hormone. It causes osteoclastic resorption of bone leading to raised calcium levels and complications of hypercalcemia like renal stones, abdominal pain, depression. Sub-periosteal resorption of the phalanges is a diagnostic feature of hyperparathyroidism. The x-ray skull shows a salt pepper appearance showing a well-marked stippling, but the opaque areas are small pinhead size.

Image shows salt and pepper appearance seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Option C: Osteopetrosis occurs due to a defect in the genes that control the osteoclastic activity and hence usually presents much earlier in life. Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. The bones appear sclerotic and the skull base is uniformly radiodense. Radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the ‘rugger-jersey’ sign. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity
 

An X-ray image showing dense bones seen in osteopetrosis is shown below.

Option D: Osteomyelitis can occur in the frontal bone is associated with forehead swelling and redness. It usually results from acute frontal sinusitis but can also occur as sequelae of trauma or surgery. Pus can be formed under the periosteum as soft boggy swelling called pott's puffy tumor. ESR and CRP are elevated with leukocytosis, serum calcium and ALP are usually unchanged. X-ray is done initially but a CT scan clinches the diagnosis. Radionuclide scanning, MRI are other radiological investigations that are used.

Image shows MRI, T1, sagittal, gadolinium contrast showing pott's puffy tumor, spreading towards patients' brain.

Related Pearl: Pathological fracture

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

  • Fracture after minor trauma
  • Pain at the site before the fracture
  • Multiple recent fractures
  • History of primary malignancy

  • Osteoporosis
  • Metabolic bone diseases
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Paget's disease
  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Myelomatosis

2. Local benign conditions:

  • Chronic infection
  • Solitary bone cyst
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Chondroma

3. Primary malignant tumors:

  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Ewing's tumor

4. Metastatic tumors

  • Mets from breast, lung, kidney, thyroid, colon and prostate

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a throbbing unilateral headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by movement and is associated with photophobia. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists were found to be effective in the management of her headache. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of throbbing unilateral headache responsive to CGRP antagonists indicates a diagnosis of migraine headache.

Migraine is the second most common cause of headaches, after tension headaches. It is characterized by unilateral and throbbing headaches of moderate to severe intensity. Other features of migraine include deep-seated pain and sensitivity to environmental and sensory stimuli. The headache can be triggered by glares, bright lights, sounds, hunger, stress, physical exertion, hormonal fluctuations during menses, lack of or excess sleep, or alcohol.

Management of migraine includes nonpharmacologic management and pharmacologic measures. Triggers unique to the patient should be avoided. Lifestyle modifications to avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol, and to maintain a healthy sleep cycle are necessary. Triptans (Sumatriptan, Zolmitriptan) is used in the treatment of acute attacks. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be useful if taken early after symptom onset. Other drugs include oral dopamine receptor antagonists and opioids. 

Migraine is associated with the release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) within the trigeminal nucleus. Hence, newer therapies under evaluation include CGRP antagonists and monoclonal antibodies to CGRP and its receptor. They are considered to be as effective as triptans and are better tolerated. 

Other options:

Option A - Cluster headaches are deep, retro-orbital, unilateral, excruciating headaches. They are characterized by attacks at the same time every day. 

Option B - Temporal arteritis or giant cell arteritis is a vasculitis. It affects medium to large-sized arteries. It is characterized by fever, anemia, high erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and headaches in people over the age of 50. 

Option D - Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by excruciating pain in the area of the trigeminal nerve. It lasts for a few seconds to a minute and can recur. 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: An infant in the neonatal intensive care unit was observed to have a minimal nasal flare, marked xiphoid retractions, intercostal retractions that were just visible, and inspiratory lag with a grunt audible with a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score?
questions.solution:
Silverman-Anderson score of this infant would be 6. 

Silverman Anderson score is more suited for preterms with hyaline membrane disease. This score is indicative of the severity of respiratory distress. It is given as follows:

Score 0 1 2
Upper chest retraction (Chest movement) sync lag on inspiration see-saw
Lower chest retraction (Intercostal retraction) none just visible marked
Xiphoid retraction none just visible marked
Nasal dilatation none minimal marked
Grunt none stethoscope only naked ear


In the given scenario:

  • Presence of grunt audible on stethoscope- 1
  • Minimal nasal flaring- 1
  • Marked xiphoid retraction- 2
  • Intercostal retractions that were just visible- 1
  • Chest movement with inspiratory lag- 1

Total score: 6

A score of >6 indicates impending respiratory failure.

The image given below gives the scoring system for the Silverman-Anderson score.

Another score called the Downes’ Score is more comprehensive and can be applied to any gestational age and condition. Scoring is to be done every half an hour and charting is carried out to monitor progress. The parameters in Downes' scores are:

  • Respiratory rate
  • Air entry
  • Cyanosis
  • Grunting
  • Retraction

Downe’s score of >6 means impending respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida is undergoing cordocentesis to obtain samples for fetal karyotyping. Identify the false statement regarding this procedure.

choices.text: Anti-D Ig is administered in Rh-ve women

questions.solution:
Fetal tachycardia is not seen as a side effect of cordocentesis.

Cordocentesis also known as percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (PUBS), was initially described for assessment of fetal anemia and as a method for fetal blood transfusion. It is also indicated for assessment and treatment of platelet alloimmunization and for fetal karyotyping. It is usually done at 18-20 weeks period of gestation.

A 22-23 gauge spinal needle is introduced into the umbilical vein under sonographic guidance under strict asepsis. Blood is slowly withdrawn in a heparinized syringe. The umbilical vein is preferred as it is larger in size, associated with lesser fetal bradycardia, and lesser hemorrhage. The umbilical vein is commonly pierced near the insertion of the cord to the placenta. 

Arterial puncture is associated with fetal bradycardia. Test results are usually obtained within 24-48 hours. After the procedure, anti-D Ig 300 μg is administered if the woman is Rh-negative.

Complications -

  • Higher risk of fetal loss as compared to amniocentesis and chorionic villous sampling
  • Cord-vessel bleeding
  • Feto-maternal bleeding
  • Fetal bradycardia.

 A table differentiating between the invasive prenatal diagnostic techniques is given below.

questions.text: The glucose transporter responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into adipocytes is ______.
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into adipocytes is GLUT-4.

Glucose transporters, also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitative diffusion. Facilitative diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions through the cell membrane by them binding chemically to a carrier/ transport protein that is responsible for their movement across the cell membrane.

GLUT-4 is a transport protein present in adipocytes. When there is a rise in blood glucose level, insulin secreted by the pancreatic beta cells binds to its receptors on the plasma membrane of adipocytes. Upon binding of insulin to its receptor, activation of the receptor's tyrosine-kinase domain occurs. This activation starts a protein activation cascade leading to the translocation of GLUT4 to the plasma membrane.

Once translocation occurs and GLUT4 is inserted into the plasma membrane, facilitated diffusion of glucose down its concentration gradient into the cell occurs.

Additionally, GLUT-4 is also present in skeletal muscle cells and cardiomyocytes.

Other options:

Option B: GLUT-2 is found in the liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, and kidney. Its function is the rapid uptake or release of glucose.

Option C: GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine and is involved in the absorption of fructose.

Option D: SGLT-1 is a sodium dependent unidirectional transporter present in the small intestine and kidney that is involved in the active uptake of glucose against a concentration gradient.

questions.text: A 45 years old male patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain and breathlessness after a road traffic accident. No penetrating injury to the chest is seen. His chest X-ray is as given below. Which of the following is an indication for thoracotomy?

choices.text: Persistence of hemothorax despite a tube thoracostomy
Continuous bleeding < 50 ml/h for 3 consecutive hours
Drainage of > 1500 ml blood when chest tube is first inserted

questions.solution:
Drainage of >1500 ml blood when the chest tube is first inserted is an indication for thoracotomy.

The above clinical scenario with the chest radiograph showing blunting of the costophrenic angle and opacification of the half of the hemithorax is suggestive of hemothorax. 

Thoracotomy is a creation of access to contents of the thoracic cavity by an incision between the ribs.

The indications for thoracotomy in a thoracic trauma are:

  • Drainage of more than 1500 ml (blunt trauma) or 1000ml (penetrating trauma) blood when the chest tube is first inserted
  • Continuous hemorrhage of more than 200 mL/h for 3 consecutive hours (Option C)
  • Caked hemothorax (Persistence of hemothorax despite two tube thoracotomies) (Option B)
  • Great vessel injury
  • Pericardial tamponade
  • Cardiac herniation
  • Inadequate ventilation with a massive air leak in chest tube
  • Trachea or main stem bronchial injury(diagnosed on imaging or endoscopy)
  • Open pneumothorax
  • Esophageal perforation
  • Air embolism

Other options:

Option A- Surgical emphysema is a common phenomenon complication tube thoracostomy for pneumothorax. It is usually benign, self-limiting that requires only conservative treatment.

questions.text:
A child presents with seizures and infantile spasms to the pediatric outpatient. Her mother gives a history of DPT vaccination 2 days back. Under which of the following categories would you classify this adverse effect following immunization?

DPT : diptheria-pertussis-tetanus
questions.solution:
The occurrence of seizures and infantile spasms following the administration of the DPT vaccine is classified as a vaccine product–related reaction.

Adverse effects following immunization (AEFI) are defined as any untoward medical occurrence which follows immunization and which does not necessarily have a causal relationship with the usage of the vaccine. It can present as an unfavorable or unintended sign, abnormal laboratory finding, symptom, or disease.

In the given scenario, the onset of a seizure and infantile spasms are known side effects due to the inherent property of the pertussis component of the DPT vaccine. Hence, they are classified as vaccine product-related reaction AEFI.

Revised cause-specific categorization of AEFI as given by the WHO:

1. Vaccine product–related reaction - AEFI is caused or precipitated by a vaccine due to one or more of the inherent properties of the vaccine product.

2. Vaccine quality defect–related reaction - AEFI is caused or precipitated by a vaccine that is due to one or more quality defects of the vaccine product, including its administration device as provided by the manufacturer. Example - failure by the manufacturer to completely inactivate a lot of inactivated polio vaccines leading to cases of paralytic polio (Option A)

3. Immunization error–related reaction - AEFI is caused by inappropriate vaccine handling, prescribing, or administration and thus is preventable. Example- the transmission of infection by a contaminated multidose vial (Option C)

4. Immunization anxiety–related reaction - An AEFI arising from anxiety about the immunization. Example - vasovagal syncope in an adolescent during/following vaccination (Option D)

5. Coincidental event - AEFI is caused by something other than the vaccine product, immunization error, or immunization anxiety. Example - a fever occurring at the same time as the vaccination (temporal association), but is, in fact, caused by another disease such as malaria

Vaccine product-related reactions and vaccine quality defect-related reactions are together known as vaccine reactions.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1L1 woman is 18 weeks pregnant. She mentions that her previous labor was prolonged and tedious and eventually the doctor used an instrument to deliver her first child. Which of the following measurements would point towards the diagnosis of cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as cephalo-pelvic disproportion (CPD). Cephalo-pelvic disproportion at the pelvic inlet is diagnosed when the diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm.

Disproportion with respect to the maternal pelvis is a state where the normal proportion between the size of the fetus to the size of the pelvis is disturbed. The disparity in the relation between the head and the pelvis is called cephalopelvic disproportion.

It can either occur due to an average size baby with a small pelvis or a relatively large baby with a normal pelvis. A history of prolonged or tedious labor, followed by either spontaneous or difficult instrumental delivery is suggestive of pelvic contraction. Difficult vaginal delivery ending in a stillborn or neonatal death without any etiological factor also suggests a contracted pelvis. Past history of fracture, rickets, osteomalacia, tuberculosis of the pelvic joints or spines, and poliomyelitis is elicited.

CPD can occur at the inlet, mid pelvis, or at the pelvic outlet. It is diagnosed at these levels by the following measurements.

  • Inlet CPD
    • Anteroposterior diameter < 10 cm
    • Diagonal conjugate < 11.5 cm
    • Transverse diameter < 12 cm.
  • Midpelvis CPD
    • Sum of the interspinous and posterior sagittal diameters of the mid pelvis </= 13.5 cm
    • Interspinous diameter < 8 cm
  • Outlet CPD
    • Interischial diameter </= 8 cm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was started on an anticancer drug for the germ cell tumor of the testes. After 2 months he started developing the following skin lesions. Identify the anticancer drug:
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a germ cell tumor of the testes and the image shows flagellate dermatitis. So, the anticancer drug is bleomycin.

Flagellate dermatitis is bands of pruritic, linear, and erythema maculae over the trunk and extremities. It can be associated with conditions such as dermatomyositis. It can also be seen as an adverse effect a few hours to 6 months after the administration of drugs like bleomycin, and peplomycin.

The rash of flagellate dermatitis heals with persistent flagellate hyperpigmentation. These lesions readily respond to topical corticosteroids, but usually, disappear after the stoppage of the drug. 

Bleomycin is DNA cleaving anticancer antibiotic that causes oxidative damage to nucleotides, resulting in single- and double-stranded breaks in DNA. It is used as a component in the treatment regimens of testicular cancer and Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Bleomycin has a little myelosuppression effect. The major adverse events include dose-dependent pulmonary toxicity (irreversible pulmonary fibrosis) and flagellate dermatitis.

Other options: 

Option A: Oxaliplatin is an antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of colorectal cancer. The adverse events include peripheral neuropathy, leukemia, and pulmonary fibrosis. 

Option C: Dacarbazine is a methylating agent used in the treatment of Hodgkin's lymphoma, malignant melanoma, and sarcomas. The adverse effects include myelosuppression, hepatotoxicity, flu-like syndrome, and alopecia.

Option D: Doxorubicin is an anthracycline antineoplastic drug used in the treatment of malignant lymphomas, Ewing sarcoma, soft-tissue sarcomas, and breast carcinoma. The major adverse effects include myelosuppression, cardiomyopathy, alopecia, and stomatitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with worsening night blindness for the last few years. On further questioning, he reveals that he has been having increasing difficulty doing daily activities like reading and walking without bumping into objects. His fundoscopy findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a clinical picture of worsening night blindness, difficulty in walking and reading, with fundoscopic features (bone spicule changes, retinal atrophy, and a peripheral ring of depigmentation) is likely to have retinitis pigmentosa.

Retinitis pigmentosa is retinal dystrophy that results in retinal rod and cone degeneration. It can be inherited (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive) or acquired due to sporadic mutation in the rhodopsin gene. 

Patients present with worsening night blindness. However, patients do not often notice night blindness and may present after much disease progression. They also develop tunnel vision, which manifests as difficulty performing activities of daily living such as reading, walking, and driving. 

Ocular examination reveals normal visual activity and central vision (though central vision will be involved later in disease progression). Fundoscopy shows bilateral, mid-peripheral intraretinal perivascular 'bone-spicule' changes and atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. There is severe peripheral pigmentation, arteriolar narrowing, and pallor of the disc. 

Retinitis pigmentosa can lead to posterior subcapsular cataracts, open-angle glaucoma, keratoconus, and posterior vitreous detachment as possible complications. 

There is no specific treatment for retinitis pigmentosa. Some interventions that may help include the following: 

  • Regular follow-up to assess vision and provide low-vision aid, rehabilitation, and social services
  • Cataract surgery
  • 'Nanometer controlled' sunglasses as light protective strategies for outdoor and indoor use
  • Avoidance of retinotoxic medications

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency would lead to xerophthalmia. This also has night blindness and loss of vision. However, retinal involvement would be characterized by yellowish, peripheral dots in advanced cases. 

Option C: Retinal detachment occurs when there is a separation between the neuroepithelium and pigment epithelium of the retina. This can occur due to trauma, neoplasm, or fluid accumulation. It is characterized by light flashes, floaters, and a 'curtain' obscuring the vision. Ophthalmoscopy features depend on the stage. Early stages may not be apparent other than color changes, but later stages may show folds that oscillate on eye movement, grey depressions, and bright summits. 

The image given below shows a shifting fluid sign in exudative retinal detachment.

The following image shows central retinal detachment.

Option D: Acquired syphilis is characterized by anterior uveitis, chorioretinitis, and posterior placoid chorioretinopathy. The retina will have a ground-glass appearance and have vasculitis, leading to scars.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology

X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A patient with a slow-growing ulcerated lesion was diagnosed with basal cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements about this condition is incorrect?

choices.text: They mostly occur on the head and neck

questions.solution:
Since basal cell carcinoma does not have a premalignant stage, option B is incorrect.

Basal cell carcinoma is a slow-growing malignant tumor with locally invasive characteristics affecting the pilosebaceous skin. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation exposure, human papillomavirus infection, immunosuppression, photosensitizing drugs, occupational factors, and arsenic exposure. 

On histopathological examination, they can be the multifocal superficial type that extends over the skin surface or the nodular type that grows into the dermis. They have hyperchromatic nuclei in a mucinous matrix and are surrounded by fibroblasts and lymphocytes. They demonstrate peripheral palisading (option A).

The below image shows the histological features of BCC:

Gross morphology: The most common type of BCC is nodular BCC. They are pearly, have a rolled border, and may be ulcerated (option C). Ulcerated BCCs are called rodent ulcers. Nodular BCCs are most commonly present on the head and neck (option D). 

The below image shows a nodular BCC with ulceration over the supraorbital area. 

BCCs can be managed medically with imiquimod, 5 fluorouracil, and intralesional interferon alpha-2b. Surgical methods involve excision with predetermined margins, curettage and cautery, and Moh's micrographic surgery. 

Note: Squamous cell carcinomas (SCC) have premalignant stages. SCC may arise from actinic keratosis, cutaneous horn, arsenical keratosis, post-ionizing radiation keratosis, disseminated superficial actinic porokeratosis, and Bowen disease. However, these lesions are considered to have uncertain malignant potential and share histological characteristics.

questions.text: A young woman presents with burning micturition and fever for the past two days. Gram stain of the urine sample was performed which revealed pink organisms. It was also cultured on MacConkey's agar which can be seen below. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The causative organism in this patient with features of urinary tract infection, gram-negative organism (pink color in gram staining), and lactose fermenting (pink) colonies in MacConkey's agar is Escherichia coli. 

Urinary tract infection (UTI) can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. Symptomatic UTI is characterized by burning micturition, increased frequency of micturition, urgency, pelvic discomfort, and pain. If pyelonephritis is present, there will also be flank pain. In asymptomatic patients, bacteriuria is present and in women, if untreated can lead to complications during pregnancy. 

UTI can be caused by a variety of organisms. Since the question stem describes a gram-negative (pink gram staining organism) and lactose fermenting (pink colonies on MacConkey agar), the causative organism is likely E. coli.

E. coli grows well on ordinary media, is hemolytic on blood agar, demonstrates uniform turbidity with a heavy deposit in broth, and ferments glucose, lactose, mannitol, and maltose. It has several virulence factors:

  • Surface antigens:
    • Colonization factor antigens
    • Lipopolysaccharide O antigen
    • P fimbria
  • Toxins:
    • Hemolysins
    • Cytotoxic necrotizing factor-1
    • Heat-labile toxin
    • Heat-stable toxin
    • Shiga-like toxin (E.coli verocytotoxin or verotoxin )

Lower UTIs caused by E. coli are generally caused by the same serotype present in the gut of the patient due to ascending infection. Upper UTIs caused by E. coli are generally due to hematogenous spread. 

It is diagnosed by demonstrating 'significant bacteriuria' which is 100,000 and more bacteria. This is because the urine can be contaminated with E. coli during sample collection so a significant presence of the organism has to be present for diagnosis. 

Other options: 

Option B - Proteus mirabilis is a non-lactose fermenting bacteria. Although it is a normal commensal of the intestine, it is not a coliform bacteria. It is a gram-negative, encapsulated, pleomorphic, motile rod. 

Option C - Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus that is actively motile, encapsulated, with a mucoid slime layer. It forms non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. 

The following image shows non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar:

Option D - Staphylococcus aureus is a lactose fermenter. However, it is a gram-positive organism. It produces characteristic golden-yellow pigment on nutrient agar as seen in the image below.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida has come for an antenatal ultrasound examination. The sonographic image obtained is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the lemon sign, which is seen in spina bifida.

Spina bifida is the common open neural tube defect associated with hydrocephalus and Arnold-Chiari II malformation. It is the most common open neural tube disorder. Spina bifida is characterized by a cleft in the vertebral column with a corresponding defect in the skin so that the meninges and spinal cord are exposed.

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  • Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal, or it may have some hair growing from it.
  • Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  • Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - A defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

The lemon sign is related to changes in the configuration of the fetal frontal bone, which loses convexity and appears concave or linear on ultrasonography; this sign can be detected during the first six months of gestation.

The banana sign is another sign that is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari II malformation. Herniation of the brainstem and cerebellar tonsils occurs through the foramen magnum, with the cerebellum surrounding the brainstem, thus giving rise to the appearance of the curved shape of a banana.

Other options: 

Option B: Anencephaly is characterized by an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. It is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. Frog eye sign is seen in USG. Prominent orbits (arrows) and an absence of cerebral tissue more cranially are seen.

Option C: Holoprosencephaly is a rare congenital brain malformation resulting from incomplete separation of the two hemispheres. On antenatal ultrasound, there may be also evidence of polyhydramnios, and the snake-under-the-skull sign may also be seen.

Option D: Omphalocele is a midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel may herniate. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac. Given below is a fetal ultrasound image suggestive of an omphalocele (asterisk).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

questions.text:
A 25-year old dancer presented with sudden pain in her right knee during her performance. On examination, the knee is swollen. The resident performs the test shown in the image and a click sound is heard at the end. The best investigation for diagnosis is ________.

CT - Computed Tomograhy

MRI - Magnetic Resonance Imaging
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image demonstrating a positive McMurray's test indicates injury to the menisci. The next best investigation for diagnosis is MRI.

The rotational forces at the knee, compress and rotate the menisci anteriorly or posteriorly causing a tear in them. The medial meniscus is less mobile than the lateral meniscus and hence is more prone to injury.

McMurray's test: This test is used to detect injuries to the menisci. The patient is made to lie in the supine position and the knee is completely flexed. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint while the other hand is used to internally and externally rotate the leg. The leg is then slowly extended. Any palpable or audible click indicates injury to the menisci.

The image below shows McMurray's test:

Arthroscopy can also be used to diagnose but MRI is more sensitive and can reveal tears that are missed by arthroscopy.

X-ray and CT scans are not used in the diagnosis of meniscal injuries.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents for a health check-up, during which the doctor finds that he is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic, while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behaviour. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the centre of attraction. They also have inappropriate, sexually seductive, or provocative behaviour. They try to use their physical appearance to draw others' attention.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with complaints of hematuria. Family history reveals the maternal uncle had grade 5 chronic kidney disease. Auditory and ophthalmologic evaluation reveals sensorineural hearing loss and an anterior lenticonus.  Electron microscopy of the kidney biopsy reveals the given image. What is the type of collagen that is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) in electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome. Alport syndrome is a glomerular basement membrane disease that is caused due to mutations in the type IV collagen genes.

It is hereditary and can be inherited as an X-linked, autosomal dominant, or autosomal recessive disorder. However, the most common mode of inheritance of classic Alport syndrome is X-linked. Therefore, male relatives tend to be affected as in this case. 

Clinically, the classic variant of Alport syndrome presents with hematuria due to nephritis that slowly progresses to end-stage renal disease, an anterior lenticonus, and a mild, non-progressive sensorineural hearing loss that usually involves higher frequencies. Other eye findings include lens dislocation, corneal dystrophy, and posterior cataracts.

The investigation involves biopsy and histopathologic examination which includes the following findings-

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal until late in the disease course. End-stage renal disease can show histological features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
  • Electron microscopy: Irregular foci of thickening, alternating with attenuation (thinning), and pronounced splitting and lamination of the lamina densa producing a distinctive basket-weave appearance. 
  • Immunofluorescence: No deposits.

Other options:

Option B - Deficiency of type I collagen synthesis causes osteogenesis imperfecta. It presents as postnatal fractures, blue sclera, lax joints, fragile skeleton, dentinogenesis imperfecta, and normal stature.

Option C - Deficiency of type III collagen is associated with vascular type IV Ehler-Danlos syndrome. It presents as thin easily bruisable skin, arterial and uterine rupture, and joint hyperextensibility.

Option D - Deficiency of type II collagen is associated with skeletal dysplasia, ocular findings such as lens subluxation, cataract, myopia, etc, hearing impairment, and facial features.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a slow-growing painless mass in front of and below the right ear. It measured 7.5 cm. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the parotid gland showed the following histological picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is mucoepidermoid carcinoma.

This patient has a painless mass of the parotid measuring 7.5cm with the given histological features of sheets of mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles, which is suggestive of mucoepidermoid carcinoma. It is more common in females.

On examination, they can grow as large as 8cm in diameter, appear well-circumscribed, but there is no well-defined capsule present. On gross examination, they appear pale grey or white, with small mucin-containing cysts.  

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary glands. They are most commonly seen in the parotids but also in minor salivary glands. These are associated with balanced t(11;19) CRTC1-MAML2 fusion. The CRTC1-MAML2 fusion protein acts by influencing Notch and cAMP-dependent signaling pathways. They usually present as a painless swelling on the cheek with or without facial nerve involvement.

Surgical treatment is clear margins is indicated. Removal of the facial nerve and its branches may be required in invasive malignancies. Radiotherapy is indicated in high-grade lesions.

Other options:

Option A - Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a rare tumor commonly occurring in the palatine glands, parotid, and submandibular glands. On gross examination, these are small, poorly encapsulated, infiltrative, gray-pink lesions. Histological examination shows small cells with dark, compact nuclei and scant cytoplasm arranged in a cribriform growth pattern similar to swiss cheese as shown below.

Option C -  Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. It is found exclusively in the parotid gland. These are benign tumors that occur commonly in men. On gross examination, these are round or oval encapsulated masses, 2 to 5 cm in diameter readily palpable within the superficial parotid gland. On dissection, a pale gray surface with narrow cystic or cleft-like spaces filled with secretions is observed. On microscopy, it has a double layer of oncocytic cells; the innermost layer is columnar and the outer layer is cuboidal as shown below:

Option D - Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common salivary gland neoplasm. They are commonly seen in the parotid. They are painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular glands.  On gross examination, these tumors are rounded, well-demarcated masses that seldom exceed 6 cm, and have a gray-white cut surface with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the cartilage-like stroma.

The dominant histologic feature is morphologic heterogeneity characterized by a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells as shown below:

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child being evaluated in a primary health center is found to have disfigured lips due to constant biting, inability to walk, dystonia, spasticity, and choreoathetosis. He has been diagnosed with a deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely to have Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is an X-linked disorder characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT). 

Developmental delays with hyperuricemia are typical of this syndrome. Symptoms are predominantly neurological and these include hypotonia and developmental delay which become apparent before the child is 4 months old. Dystonia appears before the child is 1 year old and progresses to a point where the child cannot attain milestones like crawling and walking. Involuntary movements such as choreoathetosis develop within the first few years of life. Pyramidal signs like spasticity and hyperreflexia can also be observed by then.

Self-injurious behavior is the hallmark of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. The most commonly noted ones include biting of lips, fingers, and cheeks, causing profound disfigurement. There might also be a history of aggressive behavior like pinching, spitting, grabbing, hitting, or verbally abusing. Nephrolithiasis and gouty arthritis occur due to hyperuricemia.

Increased serum uric acid (>8 mg/dL) is found. Blood investigations generally show features of megaloblastic anemia.

Allopurinol, a drug that blocks the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme, is the mainstay of treatment for hyperuricemia and its complications. Pyramidal signs such as spasticity can be managed with the use of benzodiazepines or baclofen. Physical rehabilitation with walking aids, and devices to maintain posture, help prevent deformities.

Behavioral symptoms are managed with psychiatric, and medical interventions.

Other options: 

Option B: Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome is characterized by a partial deficiency of HGPRT. It is also associated with hyperuricemia but there are no neurological complications associated with it.

Option C: Orotic aciduria type I is characterized by a deficiency of the enzymes orotate phosphoribosyltransferase and orotidylic acid decarboxylase.

Option D: Orotic aciduria type II is characterized by a deficiency of the enzyme orotidylic acid decarboxylase.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy with sickle-cell anemia was brought by his parents with complaints of fever and a runny nose. The child has a maculopapular rash with a lacy pattern on his trunk and extremities, sparing the palm and soles. He also has a rash on his face as shown below. What specific complication would you anticipate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical symptoms and the typical ‘slapped cheek appearance’ that is the erythematous facial flushing as shown in the image are suggestive of erythema infectiosum. A transient aplastic crisis is a complication that is anticipated in this patient. 

Erythema infectiosum or fifth disease is a viral infection caused by parvovirus B19. It usually has three phases:

  • First phase - sudden onset diffuse and macular, asymptomatic erythema of the cheeks or slapped cheek appearance. Prodromal symptoms may occur
  • Second phase - begins after 1–4 days, with discrete erythematous macules and papules on the proximal extremities and later the trunk
  • Third phase - recurring stage, the eruption is greatly reduced or invisible, only to recur after the patient is exposed to heat or sunlight, or in response to crying or exercise

Parvovirus B-19-induced transient aplastic crisis is a complication seen in patients with all types of chronic hemolytic anemia like sickle-cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, and pyruvate kinase deficiency.

Other options:

Option A: Coronary aneurysm is a complication of Kawasaki disease. Patients with this disease present with high fever for at least 5 days along with at least four out of the five characteristic features: polymorphous exanthem, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis with limbal sparing, lip cracking, and oral mucosal erythema with strawberry tongue appearance, cervical lymphadenopathy, and extremity involvement - erythema of palms and soles with edema of hands and legs.

The image given below shows strawberry tongue and erythema of hands seen in Kawasaki disease.

Option B: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a complication of measles. The characteristic presentation of measles includes a high fever, cough, coryza, and a maculopapular rash which typically begins after 3-5 days of fever in a cephalocaudal fashion involving the palms and soles. A pathognomonic feature of measles is the Koplik spots which are bluish-white spots located on the buccal mucosa opposite the 1st and 2nd molars.

The image given below shows rashes and Koplik spots of measles.

Option D: Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis seen as a complication of group A streptococcal infection (more commonly seen with skin strains and a few pharyngeal strains). Common streptococcal infections in childhood are bacterial pharyngitis, Scarlett fever, non-bullous impetigo, and erysipelas. They present with acute pharyngitis or erythematous papulovesicular lesions which can become purulent.

The image given below shows the rash and strawberry tongue appearance of Scarlett fever.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes with a history of a mobile lump in the left breast. On clinical examination, the size of the lump in the left breast is 7×9 cm with no axillary lymphadenopathy. The histopathology of the biopsy from the lump is given below. What is the gene most likely to be mutated in this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with a large breast lump in a woman in her 6th decade, with no axillary lymphadenopathy and characteristic histological features such as increased stromal cellularity with typical leaf-like architecture points towards the diagnosis of phyllodes tumor. The gene most likely to be mutated is the MED12 gene.

Phyllodes tumors are benign tumors, also known as the cystic disease of Brodie or cystosarcoma phyllodes. They present in the 6th decade, 10-20 years later than the occurrence of fibroadenoma. Similar to fibroadenomas, the majority of these tumors have MED12 mutations. Malignant behaving tumors are more likely to express additional genes such as TERT. Histologically they can be low-grade tumors like fibroadenomas but are more mitotically active.

Clinically these present as a large, sometimes massive, tumor with an uneven bosselated surface. Occasionally, ulceration of overlying skin occurs because of pressure necrosis. Phyllodes tumors remain mobile on the chest wall. Lymphatic spread is rare and axillary lymph node dissection is contraindicated. Metastasis in high-grade tumors is by the hematogenous route

Other options:

Option A - p53 mutation is associated with the comedo subtype of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), high nuclear grade, and a high mitotic index. Comedo pattern of DCIS is defined by two features, tumor cells with pleomorphic, high-grade nuclei and areas of central necrosis. The various patterns of DCIS are shown below.

Option B - CDH1 mutation is associated with lobar carcinoma in situ (LCIS) of the breast. Histologically, LCIS consists of a monomorphic population of cells with oval or round nuclei and small nucleoli involving ducts and lobules. Mucin-positive signet ring cells are commonly present. The histological image is given below:

MED12 gene mutations are seen in two-thirds of fibroadenoma cases. They occur in women in their 20s and 30s, and they are frequently multiple and bilateral. Histology shows delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma. The epithelium may be surrounded by stroma (pericanalicular pattern) or compressed and distorted by it (intracanalicular pattern) as shown below:

questions.text: A patient presented to the ER with dizziness and palpitations. ECG is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario and ECG findings (absent P waves and RR intervals that are irregularly irregular) are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Lignocaine is not used in atrial arrhythmias. 

Lignocaine is a class 1B anti-arrhythmic agent. It blocks Na+ channels mostly in the closed/inactivated state. It is not used in atrial arrhythmias because the atrial action potential is so short that the Na+ channels are in a closed/ inactivated state for only a brief amount of time.

Lignocaine is used in the acute treatment of ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Drugs mostly used for supraventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Adenosine
  • Verapamil
  • Diltiazem
  • Digoxin
Drugs used for ventricular arrhythmia are:
  • Lidocaine 
  • Mexiletine
Drugs used in both conditions are:
  • Amiodarone
  • Beta-blockers
  • Class 1a / 1c antiarrhythmics

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with a widespread rash. It started on the chest and spread out over his body. On examination, there are multiple purpuric macules affecting the face and torso. Nikolsky's sign is positive. There is also the involvement of his mouth and eyes. The body surface area affected is 10%. He was recently started on allopurinol for gout. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). 

SJS is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. 

Patients usually present 7-10 days after consuming the drug with malaise and fever. It then progresses to a skin rash starting on the face and chest which then spreads over the rest of the body. There are purpuric macules that can easily be desquamated. Positive Nikolsky's sign may be present (gentle lateral pressure causing sliding of the epidermis).

Eyes, oral mucosa, and genitals are frequently involved. 

SJS/TEN is classified based on severity and involvement of body surface area (BSA)

SJS Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
SJS/TEN overlap Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN with spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN without spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with loss of large epidermal sheets without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets

Complications of SJS/TEN involve loss of thermoregulatory control, severe dehydration, and septicemia. Dehydration can cause acute kidney injury due to hypoperfusion. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and be monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.  

The following image shows Nikolsky's sign, where the application of gentle lateral pressure causes sliding of the epidermis. 

The following image shows the involvement of the oral mucosa and large areas of loss of skin. 

Other options: 

Option B - TEN is not the answer as the BSA involvement is only 10%. 

Option C - Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease that mainly affects older people. It is characterized by pruritus with widespread tense blisters. It doesn't occur after consumption of allopurinol. There is not much mucosal involvement. The following image shows bullous pemphigoid with unruptured, multiple tense blisters. 

Option D - Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease due to antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. Patients usually present with oral lesions which are the predominant feature. There are flaccid blisters which rupture. The following image shows the multiple ruptured and flaccid blisters.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used in the test shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows antibiotic sensitivity testing which uses the lawn culture method.

Lawn or carpet culture is the method in which a uniform surface growth of bacterium is present on the medium. It is used for antibiotic sensitivity testing (disc method) and bacteriophage typing. Stab culture (option D) is used for demonstration of gelatin liquefaction and oxygen requirements of bacterium, for maintenance of stock cultures. Streak culture (option A) is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. Stroke culture (option C) is used for providing pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests. Other methods of culture include: 

  • Liquid culture - These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances.
  • Pour plate culture - It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension.

questions.text: A mixture of gas X and oxygen is sometimes used in anesthetic practice to provide relief from upper airway edema until more definitive care can be delivered. Gas X is stored in the cylinder shown below. According to the Pin Index Safety System (PISS), what is the pin index of the given cylinder containing only gas X?
questions.solution:
The gas X used in the mixture is helium, stored in brown-colored cylinders as shown. Helium cylinder has no pin index. 

Helium-oxygen mixture, together known as heliox, is used to improve gaseous exchange in acute exacerbation of asthma and COPD.

The helium-oxygen mixture in 79%-21% ratio is sometimes used in anesthetic practice to provide relief from upper airway obstructions due to subglottic edema, foreign bodies, and tracheal tumors. It is only a temporary measure that is used until definitive care is provided. 

Pin Index Safety System (PISS) is a unique configuration of holes and pins which match precisely to eliminate connection of the wrong cylinder to equipment, thus preventing delivery of wrong gas to a patient. It incorporates two holes in specific positions on the cylinder valve below the outlet port. The cylinder can only be connected to a pressure regulator or yolk, with the corresponding matching pair of pins.

Other options:

Option A - A PISS of 1,4 indicates that gas in the cylinder is nitrogen. The nitrogen cylinder is completely black in color.

Option B - A PISS of 1,6 indicates that gas in the cylinder is carbon dioxide. The carbon dioxide cylinder is completely grey in color.

Option D - A PISS of 7 indicates that the gas in the cylinder is Entonox. It is a 50:50 mixture of oxygen and nitrous oxide supplied as a gas. It is used as a labour analgesia. It is manufactured by mixing these two separate components together utilizing the Poynting effect or lamination effect. Cylinders containing Entonox are colored blue with a white shoulder.

Note: Poynting effect - When gaseous oxygen at high pressure is passed through liquid nitrous oxide, vaporization of liquid occurs, forming a 50:50 mixture of oxygen and nitrous oxide.

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the marked structure in the given image of the axilla.

choices.text: It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of supinator
It lies medial to the third part of axillary artery in the axilla
It provides sensory innervation to lateral one and half fingers
It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of pronator teres

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the median nerve and the true statement regarding median nerve is D i.e., it enters the forearm between the 2 heads of the pronator teres.

The median nerve is formed by joining of lateral root (C5, C6, C7) from the lateral cord and medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord. It lies lateral to the third part of the axillary artery in the axilla and runs down to the arm. It shifts from lateral to medial side and stays medial to brachial artery in the cubital fossa.

It enters the forearm between the 2 heads of the pronator teres. It lies lateral to the ulnar artery and descends through the forearm posterior and is adherent to the flexor digitorum superficialis and anterior flexor digitorum profundus. Just before the wrist, it lies between the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis and flexor carpi radialis. It then passes deep to the flexor retinaculum into the palm.

The median nerve does not give any branches in the axilla and the arm.

Branches in the forearm:

  • Nerve to pronator teres
  • Nerve to palmaris longus, flexor carpi radialis and flexor digitorum superficialis
  • Anterior interosseous nerve supplying flexor pollicis longus, lateral part of flexor digitorum profundus, and pronator quadratus
  • Palmar cutaneous branch supplying the thenar skin

Branches in the hand:

  • Digital cutaneous branch supplying the lateral three and a half fingers
  • Muscular branches to thenar muscles (except adductor pollicis), 1st and 2nd lumbricals

Other options:

Option A- Posterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the radial nerve passes between the 2 heads of the supinator.

Option B- Ulnar nerve lies medial to the third part of the axillary artery in the axilla.

Option C- Median nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral three and a half fingers.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old female patient is posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. She forgot the instruction of being nil per oral and had breakfast a few hours back. The anesthetist decides to use the device shown below to reduce the risk of gastric aspiration. Identify the device used.

LMA - Laryngeal mask airway
questions.solution:
The image shown above is the LMA Supreme.

The LMA Supreme (SLMA) is a single-use, second-generation supraglottic airway device, identified by the presence of a modified cuff design, a drainage tube that allows for gastric access, an integrated bite block, and a fixation tab.

The fixation tab should rest 1-2.5 cm above the upper lip and help in the determination of the proper size of SLMA to be used. It helps in an improved perilaryngeal seal when the cheek is taped across the fixation tab. SLMA is based on the LMA ProSeal (PLMA) variant. Studies suggest that second-generation LMAs such as the SLMA and PLMA reduced the risk of gastric aspiration. 

The property of preventing gastric aspiration along with the improved airway seal and higher leak pressures have enabled supraglottic airway devices to be used in various applications where the classic LMAs (cLMA) are potentially unsuitable. Such situations include non-supine positions, laparoscopic surgeries like cholecystectomy, and in patients who are obese. The successful, routine use of the SLMA in fasted, nonobese patients for cesarean section has also been reported.

An image of LMA Supreme is given below:


Other options:

Option A - LMA ProSeal (PLMA) is a second-generation re-usable supraglottic airway. It is identified by the presence of a gastric drainage tube that allows for gastric access with an orogastric tube, bite block, and a softer cuff. The fixation tab is absent in PLMA.

The orogastric tube diverts regurgitated gastric contents away from the airway, effectively isolating the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. PLMA and SLMA can be used to provide positive pressure ventilations up to 30cm H2O.

An image of PLMA is given below:


Option C - Classic LMA is the prototype and most widely used supraglottic device. It is identified by the presence of an oval-shaped, silicone mask with an inflatable cuff that sits in the hypopharynx and forms a seal around the periglottic tissues.

It does not have any port for gastric access. The seal formed around the laryngeal inlet allows for the delivery of oxygen and inhaled anesthetics permits positive pressure ventilations up to 20 cm H2O. The cLMA is reusable up to 40 times.

An image of cLMA is given below:


Option D - Fastrach LMA is available in single or multiple-use versions. It is designed for blind or endoscopically-guided intubation. It is identified by the presence of a handle for easier insertion and troubleshooting cuff leaks, stiff tubing, and integrated bite block.

The image given below shows Fastrach LMA:
