    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O.

questions.text: Through which receptor does the virus responsible for infectious mononucleosis enter the epithelial cells of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
Ebstein-Barr virus (EBV) causes infectious mononucleosis. EBV enters pharyngeal epithelial cells through CD 21 (or CR2) receptors. They are the same as those for the C3d component of complement.

EBV may lead to the following presentations:

  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Burkitt’s lymphoma
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Lymphomas in immunodeficient persons such as AIDS or transplant recipients.

EBV multiplies inside the lymphocyte in two ways. First, they immortalize the lymphocytes that they infect leading to uncontrolled growth. The cells produce different types of immunoglobulins as a result. The second way they damage the lymphocyte is by causing lysis leading to the release of virions. 

In infectious mononucleosis, the infected B lymphocytes express EBV antigens on the cell surface. The atypical lymphocyte seen in EBV infections is due to T lymphocytes transforming in response to the infected B lymphocytes.

Other options:

Option A: CD 1 receptors are associated with thymocytes and Langerhans cells. 

Option B: CD 3 receptors are associated with the T cell antigen receptor complex.

Option C: CD 8 receptors are associated with suppressor/cytotoxic T cells.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn baby was found dead in the waste bin of the hospital. An autopsy was conducted at the request of the police to know if the baby was stillborn or live-born. During the autopsy, the abdomen was opened to visualize the level of the diaphragm. The baby will be considered live-born if the diaphragm is:

choices.text: At the level of the 3rd rib
At the level of the 6th rib
At the level of the 5th rib
At the level of the 4th rib

questions.solution:
The baby will be considered live-born if the diaphragm is at the level of the 6th rib.

During the postmortem examination, the abdomen should be opened first before the thorax to note the highest point of the diaphragm.

  • The diaphragm is at or above the 4/5th rib: Respiration has not occurred
  • The diaphragm is at or below the 6th/7th rib: Respiration has occurred.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat, 1-2cm less than the abdominal circumference  Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70 of body weight 1/35 of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040-1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sink in water Contains mucin and air. Floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue Air replaces the embryonic tissue

 

Other tests for live birth:

  • Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/ Raygat’s test)- the organ tested is the lung. It is based on the ability of the lung to sink or float in water.
  • Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water to check if it floats or sinks.
  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.
  • Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of lungs due to increased blood flow after birth.The weight of the unrespired lung is 30-40 g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60-66 g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs - 1/70
    • Respired lungs - 1/35

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man was posted for elective appendicectomy. During the pre-anesthetic workup, he gives a history of denervating injury over his left elbow due to an accident 2 years back. While administering muscle relaxants to this patient prior to surgery, which of the following responses would you most likely observe in the denervated area?

DMR - Depolarising muscle relaxant

NDMR - Non-Depolarising muscle relaxant

choices.text: Resistance to both DMR and NDMR
Exaggerated response to both DMR and NDMR
Exaggerated response to NDMR and resistance to DMR
Exaggerated response to DMR and resistance to NDMR

questions.solution:
The most likely observation is an exaggerated response to DMR and resistance to NDMR.

Neuromuscular blocking agents are subdivided into two classes

  1. Depolarizing muscle relaxants
  2. Non-Depolarizing muscle relaxants

To understand the response of administering muscle relaxants with a history of denervation injury, we must first know the mechanism of action of both types of muscle relaxants. All neuromuscular blocking agents are quaternary ammonium compounds with an affinity for nicotinic ACh receptors due to the positively charged nitrogen present in them. 

Depolarising muscle relaxants (DMRs), such as succinylcholine (SCh) closely resemble the neurotransmitter acetylcholine (ACh). When administered, they rapidly bind to the ACh receptors on the muscle end-plate and cause depolarization. Unlike ACh, DMRs are not metabolized by the acetylcholinesterase enzyme. This results in their prolonged presence in the synaptic cleft. As a result, there is continuous endplate depolarization.

This continuous endplate depolarization does not allow the endplate to repolarize. Hence, the time-limited perijunctional sodium channels that were inactivated during depolarization fail to re-open. This leads to muscle relaxation.

Non-Depolarising muscle relaxants (NDMRs) such as atracurium, pancuronium, etc compete with ACh and bind to its receptors, preventing the action of ACh on its receptors. However, the NDMRs are incapable of inducing the conformational change necessary for ion channel opening. Hence, their binding does not lead to the development of end-plate potential.

Thus, DMRs behave as ACh receptor agonists while NDMRs behave as competitive antagonists. 

In the given clinical scenario, where there is a history of a chronic denervation injury, the physiological response is that of overexpression of ACh receptors on the muscle membranes. These overexpressed receptors are low conductance receptors with a prolonged opening time, similar to fetal nicotinic ACh receptors.

The prolonged opening time of these receptors leads to an exaggerated response to DMRs. Whereas, the increased number of receptors leads to resistance to the action of NDMRs, as the NDMRs now cannot block all these receptors. The net effect is an exaggerated response to DMR and resistance to NDMR.

The opposite happens in conditions like myasthenia gravis, where the number of ACh receptors is greatly reduced. This leads to an exaggerated response to NDMRs due to complete antagonism of all receptors and resistance to DMRs due to an inadequate number of receptors being depolarized. (Option C)

Options A and B are not possible in this scenario.

Related Pearl: High yield in muscle relaxants

  • Shortest acting non-depolarizing muscle relaxant:
    • Gantacurium (Not FDA approved)
    • Mivacurium: 12-20 minutes. (FDA approved)
  • Shortest acting depolarizing muscle relaxant: Succinylcholine (3-6 minutes)
  • Muscle relaxant having the maximum duration of action: Doxacurium (benzylisoquinoline) > Pancuronium (Aminosteroid)
  • Muscle relaxant causing pain on IV injection site: Rocuronium
  • Muscle relaxant which crosses placenta: Gallamine
  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene
  • Muscle relaxants with central action: benzodiazepine, mephenesin, baclofen, carisoprodol, metaxalone
  • Muscle relaxant and mode of clearance:

    • Biliary clearance: Vecuronium and rocuronium
    • Renal clearance: Doxacurium, pancuronium, vecuronium, and pipecuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with sympathetic stimulation:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
  • Muscle relaxant with vagolytic activity:
    • Gallamine
    • Pancuronium
    • Rocuronium (mild)

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

questions.text: You observe a forensic surgeon doing en masse removal of organs during an autopsy. Which of the following autopsy techniques is he performing?
questions.solution:
The en masse removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique.

It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. They are subsequently dissected into organ blocks. 

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for active rewarming?

choices.text: Decreased heart rate and cardiac output
Loss of consciousness and pupillary dilation

questions.solution:
A core temperature of 33 ºC is not an indication of active rewarming. 

Active rewarming is indicated when:

  • The core temperature is less than 32 ºC (< 90º F)
  • Presence of cardiovascular instability
  • Extremes of age
  • Nervous system dysfunction
  • Hormonal insufficiency. 

Active rewarming can be done externally or by active core rewarming. External rewarming can be done by using forced-air heating blankets, external heat exchange pads, radiant heat sources, and hot packs. Electric blankets should be avoided as burns are common in vasoconstricted skin. 

Active core rewarming can also be done via heated humidified oxygen, heated crystalloids, heated irrigation of the gastrointestinal system, or bladder, closed thoracic lavage, peritoneal lavage. Severe cases require extracorporeal blood rewarming. 

Hypothermia is a disorder of thermal regulation when there is a drop in the body's core temperature to less than 35 ºC (95 ºF). As a result, there are changes in the body's physiologic mechanisms. 

Some features of hypothermia include impaired judgment, progressive depression of consciousness, paradoxical undressing, decreased cardiac output, arrhythmias, J wave on ECG, and asystole.  

Other options: 

Option B - Decreased heart rate and cardiac output is an indication of active rewarming as there is cardiovascular dysfunction. 

Option C - Loss of consciousness and pupillary dilation is a sign of central nervous dysfunction needing active rewarming. 

Option D - Elderly male patient with hypothermia is an indication for active rewarming. The elderly have poorer responses to thermal changes and may have systemic illnesses that impair heat generation.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents with mental retardation and short stature. His parents also say that he is frequently hungry and eats multiple times a day. On examination, truncal obesity and short hands and feet are noted. He has not developed secondary sexual characteristics. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The possible diagnosis is Prader-Willi syndrome, a genomic imprinting disorder.

Prader Willi syndrome occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes. Deletion of the paternal chromosome occurs in 70% of the cases, in the rest, it is caused due to uniparental disomy where there are two copies of the silenced maternal gene with absent paternal genes. The net effect in uniparental disomy is the same as deletion. Loss of the SNORP family of genes is responsible for this syndrome. It is characterized by:

  • Mental retardation
  • Obesity
  • Hyperphagia
  • Hypogonadism
  • Short stature
  • Small hands and feet
  • Abnormal facial features like
    • Small upturned nose
    • Narrow bifrontal distance
    • Thin upper lip

The above-mentioned features of short stature, obesity, small upturned nose, thin upper lip, and small hands and feet can be seen in the images given below. 

Other options:

Option A- Klinefelter syndrome occurs due to 47 XXY karyotype. It is one of the most common causes of male hypogonadism. The patients have tall stature with abnormally long legs and lack of secondary sexual characters. Gynecomastia may be present with atrophic testes and a small penis. The patients may have average to below-average cognitive abilities. Features of Kleinfelters are listed in the image given below.

Option B- Noonan syndrome- It is associated with abnormalities in the PTPN11 gene, RAS/MAPK pathway. The 3 most common characteristics of Noonan syndrome are:

  • Unusual facial features - a broad forehead, ptosis, ocular hypertelorism, a short, broad nose, low-set ears that are rotated towards the back of the head, small jaw,  short neck with excess skin fold,  a lowset hairline.
  • Short stature - Usually normal birth weight and length, but frequently associated with short stature and failure to thrive later in life. There is delayed puberty.
  • Heart defects present at birth -  Pulmonary stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and septal defects.

Most individuals have normal intelligence but are associated with behavioral abnormalities. An image of a child suffering from Noonan syndrome is given below in which a short posterior hairline, broad chest, a short webbed neck can be observed.

Option D- Angelman syndrome is characterized by deletion of ubiquitin ligase gene (UBE3A) on maternal chromosome 15q12 and silencing of the paternal chromosomal counterpart. It is characterized by:

  • Intellectual disability
  • Microcephaly
  • Ataxic gait 
  • Seizures
  • Inappropriate laughter

Due to inappropriate laughter and ataxia, they are also known as "happy puppets" as shown below.

Other diseases due to genomic imprinting are :

  • Angelman syndrome
  • Beckwith-Weidemann sydrome
  • Silver-Russell syndrome.

Mnemonic:

Prader–Willi Syndrome: Paternal gene deletion - P for P
Angelman syndrome: Maternal gene deletion (Mothers are Angels, Maternal gene deletion leads to Angelman syndrome)

questions.text: A 30-year-old  P1L1  woman is found to have an asymptomatic invasive disease of the cervix penetrating to a depth of 4 mm and 6 mm wide. She wishes to preserve fertility. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Invasive cervical disease measuring 6mm in width and 4mm in depth is stage IA2. The most appropriate management here would be a radical trachelectomy with pelvic lymphadenectomy.

Stage IA2 is defined as carcinoma is strictly confined to the cervix and the measured stromal invasion is >3 mm and not >5 mm in depth and no wider than 7mm.

For patients who desire to preserve their fertility, radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are the treatment of choice. For women who do not desire to preserve fertility, radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy are advised.

Other options:

Option A - Chemoradiation is indicated from stage IB onwards.

Option B - Conization is indicated in women who want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Option D - Simple hysterectomy is indicated in women who do not want to preserve fertility and with stage 1A1 disease.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease developed acute mesenteric ischemia. A laparotomy procedure was done with resection of the gangrenous bowel.  Around 190 cm of small bowel was kept intact and the rest was resected. Which type of renal stone will this patient be at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient will be at risk of developing oxalate stones in the kidneys. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of short bowel syndrome.

Patients with short bowel syndrome are at risk of developing oxalate renal stones due to hyperoxaluria as a result of increased absorption of oxalate in the colon and gall stones due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts. 

Short bowel syndrome is referred to intractable diarrhea with malabsorption of nutrients after intestinal resection or intestinal bypass surgery leading to malnutrition. The features of short bowel syndrome usually appear when the length is less than 200 cm of the small bowel, but the length and nature of the remaining bowel are also important.

The common causes for short bowel syndrome are resection due to Crohn's disease, mesenteric vascular occlusion, radiation enteritis, and tumors.

Complications of resection include:

  • Steatorrhea - due to fat malabsorption
  • Peptic ulcers - due to gastric hypersecretion
  • Cholelithiasis
  • Oxalate renal stones

Management:

Initial treatment priorities include repletion of fluid and electrolytes lost in severe diarrhea by initiating total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Long-term management involves:

  • Administration of oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts
  • Dietary fat restriction
  • Parenteral vitamin and mineral supplements
  • Proton pump inhibitors to lower gastric pH
  • Octreotide to reduce the volume of GI secretions
  • Antimotility agents such as loperamide hydrochloride to delay small-intestinal transit
  • Hormonal therapy such as growth hormone, glutamine, and GLP-2 (glucagon-like peptide-2) analog (teduglutide) are used to promote intestinal adaptation

Small intestine lengthening procedures done to increase absorption and transit time are:

  • Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring procedure (LILT) (Bianchi procedure)
  • Serial transverse enteroplasty procedure (STEP)

Intestinal transplantation is indicated only in complicated cases.

Other options:

Option B- Uric acid renal stones are seen in myeloproliferative disorders, conditions with increased uric acid production, inflammatory bowel disease, and ileostomies 

Option C- Cystine renal stones are seen in familial cystinuria.

Option D- Phosphate renal stones are seen in infections (Proteus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus) and renal tubular acidosis type I.

questions.text: A jaundiced patient presented with complaints of colicky abdominal pain and itching all over the body. USG abdomen showed thickening of the gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid. MRCP showed extrinsic compression of the common bile duct, suggestive of Mirizzi syndrome. Identify the incorrect statement about this condition.

choices.text: Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, gallbladder, and the stone
Cystic duct obstruction will be present
Fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct

questions.solution:
A palpable gallbladder will not rule out gallstones in Mirizzi syndrome. It is an exception to Courvoisier's law.

Courvoisier's law states that in the presence of a painless, palpable, enlarged gallbladder and mild jaundice, the cause is unlikely to be gallstones. Its exceptions include:

  • Double impacted stones (stones in both the cystic duct and the distal common bile duct)
  • Primary CBD stone
  • Oriental cholangiohepatitis 
  • Mirizzi's syndrome

In Mirizzi’s syndrome, gallstones become impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder due to inflammation. This causes common bile duct (CBD) obstruction and jaundice. The gallbladder is distended and may be palpable.

ERCP, PTC (Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography), or MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. 

Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone. In patients whose gallbladder is densely adherent to the common bile duct, partial cholecystectomy should be done.

If left untreated, a fistula forms between the gallbladder and common bile duct (cholecysto-choledochal fistula).

Related Pearl: Mirizzi’s syndrome

Gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct or neck of the gallbladder producing CBD obstruction and jaundice.

 

  • ERCP, PTC, MRCP will usually demonstrate the characteristic extrinsic compression of the CBD. 
  • Surgery consists of removing the cystic duct, diseased gallbladder, and the impacted stone.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presented with episodic wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. He was diagnosed with mild asthma with intermittent symptoms. According to GINA 2022 guidelines, what is the initial recommendation for treating this patient?

GINA - Global Initiative for Asthma
questions.solution:
According to GINA 2022 guidelines, beclomethasone with formoterol is preferred for mild asthma with intermittent symptoms.

Asthma is a respiratory condition characterized by reversible airflow obstruction. GINA recommends the treatment of asthma with low-dose inhaled corticosteroids with formoterol. Short-acting beta-agonists are associated with increased exacerbations.  

Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are found to have reduced hospitalizations, death, and exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and can improve lung function. 

Thus, adults or adolescents with asthma should be started on low-dose ICS with formoterol as needed. If there are multiple episodes during the week or the patient is waking up with asthma more than once a week, then maintenance therapy with the same can be started. 

Other options: 

Option B - Albuterol is a bronchodilator that is a short-acting beta 2 agonist (SABA). It is no longer recommended for treatment for asthma as regular use increases allergic responses, airway inflammation, and reduces the bronchodilator response during exacerbations. 

Option C - Beclomethasone alone is generally not prescribed as it is a combination of low-dose ICS with formoterol. 

Option D - Beclomethasone (ICS) and albuterol (SABA) can be given as an alternative in the form of regular low-dose ICS with as-needed SABA when the preferred treatment is not possible. However, the current guidelines prefer formoterol.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with multiple superficial nodular lesions. A picture of his lesions is shown below. The lepromin test is negative and he is diagnosed with lepromatous leprosy. Which of the following is not consistent with his form of disease?

choices.text: Due to deficient cell mediated immunity
Lesions contain predominantly CD4+ T cells
Lesions contain predominantly CD8+ T cells
Not more susceptible to viral opportunistic infections

questions.solution:
The statement 'lesions contain predominantly CD4+ T cells' is not consistent with lepromatous leprosy. It is associated with CD8+ T cells.

The given image depicts a male patient with cutaneous nodules over the face and loss of eyebrows, consistent with nodular lepromatous leprosy. 

Mycobacterium leprae is a gram-positive, acid-fast bacillus that causes leprosy. Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease that affects the skin and peripheral nerves. 

There are different forms of leprosy depending on the immune status of the person who is infected. 

The lepromatous form occurs when there is poor cell-mediated immunity (Option A). It is termed as 'multibacillary disease' as there are numerous bacilli seen within the lesions. The lepromata (superficial nodular granulomatous lesions) that develop contain vacuolated cells in different stages of development. The bacteria are also shed in nasal and oral secretions. The lepromatous form is considered to be very infectious. 

Within the lepromatous granulomas, there is an infiltrate of CD8+ T cells (Option C). In the tuberculous type, there are predominantly CD4+ T cells. 

In lepromatous leprosy, there is a deficiency in cell-mediated immunity. However, the deficiency is specifically for the lepra antigens. Individuals with this form are not more susceptible to other viral or parasitic infections (Option D) even though cell-mediated immunity is required. 

In tuberculoid leprosy, individuals have good resistance. There are not many lesions and if present, they are sharply demarcated. The lesions do not have extensive bacilli presence and it is not very infective. This form is termed 'paucibacillary disease'.

Other forms of leprosy also exist such as borderline, borderline tuberculous, borderline lepromatous types based on the Ridley-Jopling classification. These contain features of both tuberculous and lepromatous types. 

The lepromin test is one way to understand the immunity in a patient with leprosy. Lepromin antigens from armadillo-derived lepra bacilli are used and injected into the skin. It has two reactions: the early reaction (Fernandez) and the late reaction (Mitsuda). The early reaction develops within 1-2 days and will persist for 3-5 days. It is characterized by erythema and induration. The late reaction starts 1-2 weeks later with a peak at 4 weeks and then subsides. Here, there is an indurated nodule that may ulcerate.

The presence of a Mitsuda reaction is a measure of the cell-mediated immunity. It is not used to diagnose. It is used to classify, assess prognosis, resistance, and verify the identity of candidate lepra bacilli. The test is positive in tuberculoid leprosy and negative in lepromatous leprosy as seen in our patient. A positive reaction demonstrated good prognosis and resistance. 

The below image shows a histopathological slide of lepromatous leprosy. Here, large groups of lipid-laden macrophages filled with globi of pink/red acid-fast bacilli are seen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs)?

choices.text: SNPs occur only in exons and coding regions
Neutral SNPs have no effect on phenotype

questions.solution:
The statement 'single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) occur only in exons and coding regions' is false regarding SNPs. 

Genetic variations in the non-protein-coding regions are involved in disease causation and account for only 0.5% of our DNA. SNPs and copy number variations are the two most common forms of DNA variation in the human genome.

SNPs are defined as variants that occur due to the substitution of a single nucleotide at a specific position in the genome. Hence, they are almost always bi-allelic (Option A). SNPs occur across the whole genome - within introns, exons, coding regions, non-coding regions, and intergenic regions. 

Neutral SNPs have no effect on gene function and individual phenotype (Option C). They may be useful as markers when inherited alongside a disease-associated polymorphism due to their physical proximity.

A few examples of diseases associated with SNPs are Parkinson's disease (Option D) bipolar affective disorder, blood pressure, systemic sclerosis, type II diabetes, autism, etc. 

Copy number variations (CNVs) are the genetic variations where sections of the genome are repeated and the number of repeats varies among individuals. These can range from thousands to millions of base pairs.

CNVs can be bi-allelic, duplicated, deleted, or even be rearranged in a complicated manner. The CNVs are responsible for a large portion of human phenotypic diversity, due to their presence in gene-coding sequences.

A few examples of diseases associated with CNVs are schizophrenia, autism spectrum disorders, Parkinson's disease, Alzheimer's disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, etc.

questions.text: The false statement about cystic masses of the neck is:

choices.text: Branchial cyst arises from the second pharyngeal pouch
Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph
Thyroglossal cyst moves upwards on swallowing and tongue protrusion
Fluctuation is positive in branchial cyst

questions.solution:
Branchial cyst does not arise from the second pharyngeal pouch. 

The branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. The squamous epithelium lines the cyst and contains thick, turbid fluid of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate. The most common site of a branchial cyst is at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border.

Branchial fistulas may be congenital or acquired. The external orifice of the congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid and the internal orifice is present on the anterior aspect of the posterior faucial pillar. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete excision for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

Treatment is complete excision of the cyst or fistula to avoid recurrence.

The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Cystic hygroma is a cystic swelling due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac. It usually presents in the early infancy or at birth which may obstruct labor. The cyst contains clear lymph and is lined by a single layer of epithelium with a mosaic appearance. The swelling may involve parotid, submandibular, tongue and floor of mouth areas. It is soft and compressible which increases in size when the child coughs or cries. It is characterised by its brilliant transillumination capacity. 

Complete excision of the cyst is the definitive treatment. An alternative treatment is the injection of a sclerosing agent. Tracheostomy is required if the cyst expands rapidly and causes respiratory distress.

Below is an image showing a child with cystic hygroma.

Thyroglossal cysts are persistent thyroglossal duct tracts and thus can be found anywhere along or adjacent to the midline from the base of tongue to the thyroid isthmus. The cyst moves upwards while swallowing or on tongue protrusion. It can become infected or spontaneously rupture presenting as a discharging sinus on the skin of the neck. 

Definitive treatment is the Sistrunk operation where complete excision of the tract along with the body of the hyoid.

Below is the image of a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: Screening for inborn errors of metabolism in a newborn revealed the presence of severe hyperammonemia with respiratory alkalosis. Plasma levels of orotic acid were normal. Where is the deficient enzyme located in the cell?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario, hyperammonemia and normal orotic acid suggest a carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 enzyme deficiency. It is an enzyme located in the mitochondria of the cell. 

The urea cycle begins in the mitochondria and ends in the cytoplasm. During the metabolism of amino acids through the process of transamination, the amino acids are then cleaved into a carbon skeleton and an amino group that gets removed as ammonia. Ammonia later enters the urea cycle and gets converted into urea which is excreted in the urine.

The urea cycle begins with one molecule of ammonia combined with CO2 in the presence of two molecules of ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate. The reaction is catalyzed by the mitochondrial enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthetase-I (CPS-I).

CPS-I reaction is the rate-limiting step in urea formation which is irreversible and allosterically regulated.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presented with itching and a rash located on his torso. He also complains of chronic cough with sputum production and mucoid diarrhea. His laboratory investigations reveal peripheral eosinophilia and raised serum IgE levels. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Cough with sputum production, mucoid diarrhea, eosinophilia and larva currens is likely caused by Strongyloides stercolaris. 

In the image, the patient has multiple erythematous tracts in the skin. This is called larva currens or racing larvae caused by migrating larvae within the skin and is seen in Strongyloides infection. Strongyloides stercolaris is a nematode that infects the small intestine. It is the smallest nematode that causes infection in humans. In addition to the parasitic cycle, it also has a free-living soil cycle by feeding on bacteria. Humans get infected when the third-stage filariform larvae penetrate their bare skin. 

Clinical manifestations can be grouped as follows: 

  1. Cutaneous manifestations: 
    1. Dermatitis characterized by pruritus and erythema: This occurs at the site where the larvae penetrate the skin. 
    2. Larva currens or 'racing' larvae:  Characterized by multiple urticarial tracts in the skin caused by migrating larvae
  2. Pulmonary manifestations: Bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthma. 
  3. Intestinal manifestations: Mucoid diarrhea, protein losing enteropathy and paralytic ilieus. 
  4. Hyperinfection occurs in immunocompromised individuals due to extensive autoinfection and worm load. 

Diagnosis of strongyloides is by the wet mount of stool or aspirates of sputum, jejunum or duodenum, showing rhabditiform larvae. Peripheral eosinophilia is present and IgE may be raised. The image below shows the rhabditiform larvae.

Treatment involves ivermectin (200ug/kg/day for 2 days) or albendazole (400mg/day for 3 days). 

Other options: 

Option A - Aspergillus fumigatus is an opportunistic infection that causes allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), aspergilloma, and invasive aspergillosis. ABPA is a hypersensitivity reaction to the aspergillus antigen causing asthma and alveolitis. Aspergilloma is the formation of a fungus ball within a preexisting lung cavity leading to hemoptysis. Invasive aspergillosis begins as pneumonia and becomes disseminated in immunocompromised individuals. 

Option C - Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis. The adult worms block the lymphatic vessels leading to inflammation and granuloma formation. This causes hard pitting or brawny edema. It can present as lymphadenitis, lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis. 

Option D - Enterobius vermicularis is also known as 'pin worm'. It causes intense pruritus of the anal region in children. The worm has a tendency to migrate out of the anus at night leading to disturbed sleep and nocturnal enuresis. In females, it can cause irritation of the vagina and vulva and chronic salpingitis. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality shown below:
questions.solution:
The imaging modality shown is called diffusion tensor imaging (DTI).

Diffusion tensor imaging is a variation of diffusion-weighted imaging, where the diffusion of the fluid, is assessed in six or more directions. The technique is based on the principle that the diffusion in the brain is directionally dependent (anisotropic), which is more in the compacted white matter tracts, and least evident in grey matter.

The technique is used for mapping of the white matter tracts and hence is useful in evaluating the connectivity between various brain regions, and identifying any disease process that affects it.

The image below shows diffusion tensor tractography:

Arcuate fasciculus (AF), the superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF), the inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF), the uncinate fasciculus (UF), and inferior fronto-occipital fasciculus (IFOF). (Arrows at bottom right. A: Anterior, L: Lateral).

Other options:

  • Option a: Dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI refers to the serial MRI acquisitions following IV contrast agent.
  • Option b: Dynamic susceptibility contrast MRI measures induced alterations in the transverse relaxation times (T2 and T2*). This results in signal loss causing transient darkening of the tissues.
  • Option d: Functional magnetic resonance imaging detects changes in the regional cerebral blood flow during various brain activities. It is used to study the eloquent cortical activation.

Related Pearl: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

  • Optic neuritis
  • Vestibular schwannoma
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Spinal cord tumor
  • Neurofibroma
  • Viral encephalitis
  • Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text:
A patient is subjected to p-amino hippuric acid (PAH) clearance test. The values obtained are given below. What is the effective renal plasma flow (EPRF) in this patient?

Concentration of PAH in urine (UPAH) : 18 mg/mL

Urine flow (V) : 0.6 mL/min

Plasma concentration of PAH (PPAH) : 0.02 mg/mL

Extraction ratio : 0.9
questions.solution:
The effective renal plasma flow (EPRF) in this scenario is 540 mL/min.

Clearance is defined as the volume of plasma that is completely cleared of a substance by the kidney in unit time. PAH is used in the measurement of renal plasma flow by using the concept of clearance. PAH is filtered by the glomeruli and secreted by the tubular cells. In low doses, almost 90% of PAH is cleared from the plasma in the span of a single circulation through the kidney. Therefore, by calculating the clearance of PAH, we can arrive at the EPRF.

In the given scenario, the values obtained are: 

  • Concentration of PAH in urine (UPAH) : 18 mg/mL
  • Urine flow (V) : 0.6 mL/min
  • Plasma concentration of PAH (PPAH) : 0.02mg/mL

The formula for EPRF is given by: EPRF = (UPAH x V) / PPAH

On substituting the values in the given equation, we get:

EPRF =  (18 mg/mL x 0.6 mL/min) / 0.02 mg/mL          

         =   10.8 / 0.02             

EPRF =  540 mL/min

Actual renal plasma flow can be calculated by taking into account the small amount of PAH (approximately 10%) that is still left in the circulation.

By dividing the EPRF by the extraction ratio of 0.9 of PAH, actual renal plasma flow can be calculated.

The formula for actual RPF is given by: RPF = EPRF / Extraction ratio of PAH       

      = 540 / 0.9        

      = 600 mL/min

questions.text: An infant was brought with a history of recurrent pneumonia and copious, adherent secretions. The history also was suggestive of chronic malabsorption with fatty stools and poor weight gain. Blood examination shows high levels of immunoreactive trypsinogen. What is the most common gene mutation in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given scenario is cystic fibrosis (CF). The most common gene mutation in CF is the F508del mutation.  

F508del mutation is a deletion of a phenylalanine residue at the CFTR position 508, which results in endoplasmic reticulum–associated degradation. At least 90% of patients with CF have this mutation. A mutation affecting protein degradation is termed a class II defect.

There are 6 classes of defects involving the CFTR gene:

Class Defect
Class I Absence of synthesis e.g., W1282X, G542X
Class II Defective protein maturation and premature degradation e.g., F508 deletion
Class III Disordered gating/regulation, e.g. G551D mutation
Class IV Defective conductance through the ion-channel pore
Class V Promoter or splicing abnormality leading to reduced CFTR transcripts
Class VI Accelerated turnover from the cell surface

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder that affects fluid secretion in the exocrine glands and in the epithelial lining. It is primarily caused by a mutation in the CFTR gene, which codes for an anion channel in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. This leads to abnormally viscous secretions that obstruct organ passages, resulting in recurrent infections, pancreatic insufficiency, steatorrhea, malnutrition, hepatic cirrhosis, intestinal obstruction, and male infertility.

Diagnosis of CF is made at the time of newborn screening. Sweat electrolyte levels are measured after pilocarpine iontophoresis. In these patients, the chloride level is high. It is then confirmed through genetic testing with one of the 20–140 CFTR variants. 

The diagnosis of CF is confirmed if both of the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of
    • Clinical symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary) or
    • Positive newborn screening or
    • A sibling with cystic fibrosis
  • Evidence of dysfunction of the CFTR gene in the form of
    • Two positive sweat chloride test results obtained on separate days or
    • Identification of two CFTR mutations by genetic testing or
    • An abnormal measurement of nasal potential difference

Management of cystic fibrosis requires a multidisciplinary approach:

  • Mucus accumulation - chest physiotherapy, aerosolized dornase alfa (recombinant DNase), N-acetylcysteine, albuterol, corticosteroids, and hypertonic saline
  • Respiratory infections - antibiotics (oral for Staphylococcus and aerosolized for Pseudomonas)
  • Pancreatic insufficiency - pancreatic enzyme supplements
  • Malabsorption - nutritional supplementation along with fat-soluble vitamins (K, E, D, and A) and minerals 

Other options: 

Option A: In a G551D mutation, there is a glycine to aspartic acid replacement at the 551st position, which leads to the disruption in HCO3- and Cl- transportation. This is a class III defect. 

Option C: W1282X is the most common defect amongst Ashkenazi Jews. It is a class I defect. 

Option D: G542X is another class I defect that is not very common.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient who is known to have Bell's palsy presented with dryness in her left eye. Ocular examination reveals mild punctate epithelial defects and dryness of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with clinical features of dry eye and unilateral facial nerve palsy likely has a diagnosis of exposure keratopathy. 

Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea despite normally produced tears. It occurs due to incomplete eyelid closure, also known as lagophthalmos.

Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve palsy, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. 

Clinical features include dry eyes, symptoms and signs of mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown. 

Treatment depends on whether the exposure is reversible or permanent. Reversible exposure can be treated with artificial tears and eye ointments. The eyelid can be taped closed at night or external barriers like bandage silicone hydrogel or scleral contact lenses can be used. Permanent exposure requires permanent tarsorrhaphy. For facial nerve palsy, a gold weight can be inserted into the upper eyelid.  

Other options: 

Option B - Neurotrophic keratopathy is the loss/reduction of corneal sensation that occurs due to loss of innervation by the trigeminal nerve. It may be due to stroke, trigeminal ganglion ablation for neuralgia, diabetes, etc. 

Option C - Mooren ulcer is an autoimmune disorder that results in progressive peripheral corneal ulceration. This is characterized by severe pain and the involvement of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma.

Option D - Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). The patient complains of ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

questions.text:
A primigravida whose blood group is B negative is being investigated for signs of fetal anemia at 35 weeks of gestation. On fetal MCA doppler, peak systolic velocity is 1.7 MoM, with a hematocrit of 40 %. What is the next step?

MCA - Middle cerebral artery

MoM - Multiples of median

choices.text: Deliver at 35 completed weeks of gestation

questions.solution:
The next step is to deliver at 35 completed weeks of gestation.

In this scenario of an Rh-ve pregnancy at 35 weeks of gestation, where the peak systolic velocity of MCA is 1.7 MoM (>1.5 MoM), delivery at >/=34 completed weeks is recommended. 

Fetal middle cerebral artery Doppler measurements of peak systolic velocity(PSV) are the recommended test for the detection of fetal anemia. In the anemic fetus, blood is shunted preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxy­genation. As a result, the velocity rises because of increased cardiac out­put and decreased blood viscosity.  

If the PSV is between 1.0 and 1.5 MoM and the slope is rising and approaching 1.5 MoM, fetal surveillance is increased to weekly Doppler examination. If the MCA peak systolic velocity > 1.5 MoM and the gestational age is <34 or 35 weeks, fetal blood sampling should be considered and followed by fetal transfu­sion if needed. If the gestation age is >/=34 weeks, delivery is considered.

questions.text:
A 6-month-old baby presented with failure to thrive, generalized hypotonia, and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray showed massive cardiomegaly. Muscle biopsy findings and the lab results are given below. Which of the following enzymes can be used for successful enzyme replacement therapy of this disease?

Muscle enzyme assay- low levels of acid maltase level

Genetic testing- mutation of the GAA gene sequence
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the muscle biopsy showing large vacuoles filled with glycogen suggest the diagnosis of Pompe's disease. Myozyme or alglucosidase alfa, a recombinant form of alpha-1,4-glucosidase, can be used for enzyme replacement therapy of this disease

Pompe's disease is also known as type 2 glycogen storage disorder. It is autosomal recessive and occurs due to a mutation of the GAA gene on chromosome 17. This gene codes for alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), a lysosomal enzyme that catalyzes the alpha 1,4 and 1,6 glycogen linkage. 

A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of glycogen in various cells. It begins with accumulation in peripheral, voluntary muscles and progresses to involve the cardiac muscle and diaphragm. 

Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), motor delay, cardiomegaly, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, failure to thrive, and poor feeding. Late involvement of the diaphragm leads to respiratory failure. Cardiac involvement can lead to arrhythmias and cardiomyopathy. 

Laboratory investigations will reveal elevated serum creatine kinase, aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase. Urine glucose tetrasaccharide is a glycogen breakdown product that can be used to assess severity of disease and response to treatment. 

Myozyme can prevent worsening or can reverse cardiac and skeletal abnormalities. Administering methotrexate, rituximab, and intravenous immunoglobulin can prevent the immune tolerance that may develop to myozyme or enzyme replacement therapy.

Other options:

Option A - Aldurazyme (laronidase) is used to treat Hurler's disease, also known as mucopolysaccharidosis type I. It is characterized by facial dysmorphism, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, upper airway obstruction, skeletal deformity, and cardiomyopathy. 

Option C - Naglazyme is used in the treatment of Maroteaux–Lamy syndrome (mucopolysaccharidosis type VI). It is characterized by macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, macroglossia, short stature, and contractures. 

Option D - Elaprase is used in the treatment of Hunter Syndrome, mucopolysaccharidosis II. It is characterized by large round cheeks, broad nose, macroglossia, hoarse voice, sleep apnea, macrocephaly, hydrocephaly, and ocular problems.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor in the intensive care unit. You administer a drug 'X' to a patient. The plasma concentration of the drug reaches 500 mg/L. The drug follows zero-order kinetics. 200 mg of the drug 'X' is eliminated in 4 hours. What is the clearance of this drug?
questions.solution:
The clearance of drug X is 1.66 mL/min.

Since drug X follows zero-order kinetics, the elimination rate (amount of drug eliminated in unit time) is constant.

200 mg is eliminated in 4 hours. Therefore, 50 mg is eliminated in 1 hour as it follows zero-order kinetics.

Clearance = Rate of elimination/Plasma concentration

Rate of elimintation= 50 mg/h
Plasma concentration= 500 mg/L

Clearance = (50 mg/hr)/(500 mg/L)= 0.1 L/h

To convert L/h to mL/min, multiply by 1000 and divide by 60.

∴ Clearance = 0.1 x 1000 ml/60 min= 1.66 mL/min

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A male patient is brought into the emergency after a road traffic accident in which he has sustained injuries on the face. You note excessive mobility of the maxilla but no mobility of the nose. A CT scan reveals a fracture line passing through the lower part of the nasal septum, maxillary antrum, and pterygoid plates. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. 

Le Fort Type 1 fractures generally occur on the horizontal plane at the level of the nose base. It is caused due to downward directed force onto the lower part of the maxillary rim.

It involves the three walls of the maxillary sinus as well as the pterygoid processes, extending around the maxillary antrum, nasal septum, and pterygoid plate. This leads to the separation of the palate and face. There is no involvement of the glabella or zygoma in this case. 

Clinically, patients present with swollen upper lip, anterior open bite malocclusion, maxillary buccal vestibule, palate ecchymosis, and mobility of the maxilla.

Diagnosis is made with X-rays (Water's view, posteroanterior view, and lateral view) and CT scan. They help to understand the full extent of injuries. 

Treatment requires fixation of the maxillary fractures which can be achieved by interdental wiring, and intermaxillary wiring using arch bars. Open reduction and interosseous wiring may be required in zygomatic fractures.

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female patient presents with electric shock-like sensations that go down her legs for the last two days. A few months ago, she had bilaterally decreased visual acuity which spontaneously resolved. Her T2-weighted MRI is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is multiple sclerosis (MS). 

The MRI given depicts Dawson's fingers which are areas of perivenous demyelination that are seen as lesions that are perpendicular to the ventricle. They appear as hyperintense areas on the T2-weighted images.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease characterized by inflammation, multiple demyelinating plaques, and relapsing and remitting symptoms. It occurs due to infiltration of the white matter by T cells and macrophages leading to axonal damage and neurodegeneration. It presents abruptly or insidiously with variable intensity of symptoms depending on the location. 

The most common symptoms experienced are as follows:

  1. Sensory symptoms:
    1. Paresthesia, pins and needles sensations, hypoesthesia
    2. Horizontal cut-off on limbs for sensory involvement suggests lesions at the level of the spinal cord 
    3. Pain
  2. Optic neuritis:
    1. Reduced visual acuity, color perception, dimness in the central visual field, unilaterally or bilaterally.
    2. Periorbital pain
    3. Funduscopy: optic disc swelling, pallor
  3. Weakness of limbs
    1. Loss of strength, speed, dexterity
    2. Gait disturbance
    3. Upper motor neuron weakness
    4. Pyramidal signs: spasticity, hyperreflexia
  4. Facial weakness 
  5. Internuclear ophthalmoplegia - bilaterally

Paroxysmal symptoms may occur, characterized by short duration and high-frequency occurrence per day. These can manifest as Lhermitte's sign (electric shock-like sensations that go down legs or back on neck flexion), and Uthoff symptom (neurological symptoms produced by elevated core body temperature). Other symptoms may include dysarthria, trigeminal neuralgia, bladder dysfunction, and fatigue.

MS can have three different clinical courses: 

  1. Relapsing or bout onset (90%) of cases. Here, there is complete recovery between episodes. As the disease progresses, the recovery may not be complete. 
  2. Secondary progressive MS starts as relapsing MS but then experiences decreased function as a result of the attacks.
  3. Primary progressive MS (10% of the cases) has a consistent decline in function from disease onset. They do not have discrete episodes. 

Other options: 

Option A: Thalamic stroke is usually unilateral and is characterized by hemi-sensory disturbance throughout the body. 

Option C: Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by extreme episodic pain affecting the area of the face supplied by the trigeminal nerve except for the ophthalmic division. It is of sudden onset and short duration, lasting up to a few minutes. 

Option D: Neuromyelitis optical (NMO) is characterized by recurrent optic neuritis and transverse myelitis. It is similar in presentation to MS except that NMO is severe, bilateral, and can cause severe visual loss. Myelitis usually involves three or more contiguous vertebral segments. NMO does not have progressive symptoms in contrast to MS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old accident victim is brought with a blood pressure of 70/40mmHg. Her vitals have not improved with crystalloids. Her blood samples were sent for typing and cross-matching. In view of the blunted response to crystalloids, which packed red blood cells can she receive until the cross-matched blood arrives?
questions.solution:
O negative packed red blood cells (pRBCs) can be given to this female patient till the cross-matched blood is available.

To prevent transfusion reactions, donor and recipients' blood are cross-matched for ABO and rhesus antigens to ensure compatibility. Cross-matching of blood usually takes up to 45 minutes.

In urgent situations, type-specific blood with ABO and rhesus antigens matched is provided within 10-15 minutes. In more emergencies where blood is to be given immediately, group O (universal donor) can be given (O negative to females and O positive to males). To avoid rhesus sensitization and future complications, Rh-negative pRbC is preferred for females of the reproductive age group.

The decreasing order of preference of pRBCs is cross-matched blood > type-specific blood > type O blood.

Group AB plasma is given when uncross-matched plasma is needed.

Massive transfusion is required in some patients of shock where > 10 units of pRbCs within the first 24 hours of admission or > 4 units of blood in 1 hour is transfused. Complications of massive transfusion include:

  • coagulopathy
  • hypocalcemia
  • hyperkalemia
  • hypokalemia
  • hypothermia

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Complication Mechanism
Hypothermia As blood products are normally stored between 1°C and 6°C
Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Can be prevented by starting early transfusion of FFP, platelets, pRBCs in a 1:1:1 ratio
Acidosis/ Alkalosis

Mild acidosis - increased CO2 levels in stored blood by 21-35 days

Metabolic alkalosis - citrate gets metabolized to bicarbonate

Metabolic acidosis - due to tissue hypoperfusion
Hyperkalemia/ Hypokalemia

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis
Hypocalcemia Stored blood is anticoagulated with citrate, which binds calcium.
Hypomagnesemia Infusion of large volumes of magnesium-poor fluids and binding of magnesium to citrate
Impaired O2-carrying capacity of hemoglobin Decreased 2, 3 DPG
Volume overload Due to massive transfusion

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric department with severe pain in the hands and feet. On examination, corneal opacities and telangiectatic skin lesions on the thighs were observed. On further investigation, he is found to be deficient in α-galactosidase A enzyme. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is Fabry disease.

Fabry disease is an X-linked inborn error of glycosphingolipid metabolism due to deficient activity of α-galactosidase A enzyme. This enzyme deficiency leads to accumulations of neutral glycosphingolipids, primarily globotriaosylceramide, especially in the plasma and lysosomes of vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells, cardiac myocytes, and renal podocytes.

Features of Fabry disease:

  • Angiokeratomas - telangiectatic skin lesions characteristically seen densest between the umbilicus and knees called the bathing trunk area
  • Hypohidrosis - decreased sweating
  • Corneal and lenticular opacities
  • Painful acroparesthesias 
  • Fabry crises - severe agonizing pain in the hands, feet, and proximal extremities
  • Urinary examination shows lipid inclusions with birefringent Maltese cross

Arrhythmias, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and heart failure are some of the important cardiovascular manifestations. The most common valvular lesion is mitral insufficiency. Cardiac arrhythmias may result in transient ischemic attacks and stroke. Renal failure, characterized by proteinuria, isosthenuria, azotemia, and gradual deterioration of renal function, is seen. Renal failure, cardiac disease, or stroke are the major causes of mortality in patients with Fabry disease.

Below is the image of angiokeratomas distributed along the bathing trunk area.

Other options:

Option A- Niemann-Pick disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. The clinical features include a combination of hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, reticular or nodular infiltration in the lungs, and retinal cherry-red spots.

Option B- Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of β-hexosaminidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides, preferentially in the central nervous system. Affected children present with seizures, developmental delay, increased startle response, macrocephaly, and cherry-red spots in the eye. 

Option D- Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It has an autosomal recessive mode of inheritance. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the reticuloendothelial system. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells, a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance resulting from the presence of intracytoplasmic substrate inclusions. The intelligence of the child is normal.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman doing heavy work,  asks for your advice regarding the additional energy requirement while breastfeeding her 8-month-old child. What is the total calorie requirement per day in her case?
questions.solution:
The total calorie requirement per day for the woman is 3240 Kcal/day.

In the given scenario, the basal energy requirement for a woman doing heavy work is 2720 Kcal/day. When the woman is lactating the additional requirements per day are:

  • Lactation for 0-6 months = + 600 Kcal/day
  • Lactation for 7-12 months = + 520 Kcal/day

In this scenario, a heavy working woman is breastfeeding her 8 month old child, therefore an additional 520Kcal/day is required to the basal requirement of 2720 Kcal/day. This adds up to 3240 Kcal/day.

questions.text:
An alcoholic patient is diagnosed with liver cirrhosis. He is a candidate for liver transplantation. He had minimal ascites without any signs of encephalopathy. The laboratory findings are given below. What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score and class for the given patient?

Serum bilirubin - 2.8 mg/dL

Serum albumin - 2.5 g/dL

International normalised ratio (INR) - 2
questions.solution:
The Child-Turcotte-Pugh score for the above patient is 10 and the class he belongs to is class C.

The Child-Pugh score is a predictor of mortality and survival rates postoperatively on cirrhotic patients. The variables taken into account for the calculation of the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score include serum bilirubin, albumin, prothrombin time/INR and clinical signs suggestive of the presence of ascites and encephalopathy. 

Points for serum bilirubin- 2.8 mg/dL is 2.

Points for serum albumin- 2.5 g/dL is 3.

Points for international normalized ratio (INR) 2 is 2.

Points for minimal ascites is 2.

Points for no signs of encephalopathy is 1.

Therefore, the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score for the total points is (2+3+2+2+1)= 10.

The Child-Turcotte-Pugh class is as follows:

Class A: 5-6 points

Class B: 7-9 points

Class C: 10-15 points

Overall surgical mortality rates have been demonstrated to be 10% in Class A patients, 30% in Class B patients and 75-80% in Class C patients.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated for possible thrombophilia since she has had two episodes of deep vein thrombosis. She also has a history of three pregnancies that terminated in spontaneous abortion. On investigation, the activated partial thromboplastin time was prolonged, and the anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody was positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA). 

APLA is characterized by recurrent thrombosis due to the formation of autoantibodies. It generally affects women. APLA should be considered in those under the age of 55 with recurrent thrombosis. The presence of at least one clinical and laboratory criterion is required for diagnosis. 

Clinical criteria: 

  • Vascular thrombosis with one or more episodes of thrombosis (arterial, venous, or small vessel) in any organ
  • Pregnancy morbidity
    1. With the unexplained death of a morphologically normal fetus after 10 weeks
    2. Premature birth of a morphologically normal fetus before 34th week due to preeclampsia, eclampsia, or placental insufficiency
    3. Three or more unexplained spontaneous abortions before the 10th week.

Laboratory criteria: 

  • Positive lupus anticoagulant (LA)
  • Positive anticardiolipin (aCL)
  • Positive anti-beta2GPI antibodies.

Treatment involves lifelong warfarin therapy titrated to a goal INR of 2.5-3.5. Aspirin may also be added at a dose of 80 mg. 

Other options: 

Option B - Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute condition characterized by widespread intravascular fibrin formation in response to activation of the coagulation cascade. It is not associated with LA. In addition, this patient has a chronic history of recurrent DVT and pregnancy loss. Elevated levels of fibrin degradation products are sensitive for diagnosing DIC

Option C - Trousseau syndrome, also known as migratory thrombophlebitis, is a form of systemic hypercoagulability that arises from the paraneoplastic syndrome because of procoagulant factors. There would be multiple venous thromboses that appear, disappear, and reappear in another location. 

Option D - Factor VIII deficiency is seen in hemophilia. It is a bleeding disorder and is not characterized by recurrent thrombosis. It is associated with recurrent bleeding into soft tissues, joints (hemarthrosis), and muscles as a result of trauma or spontaneous mechanism. Lab values show prolonged aPTT.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Laboratory reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the erythematous rash with islands of sparing suggests dengue fever.

Dengue is an acute febrile illness caused by the dengue virus that is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. 

It presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The initial rash in dengue may appear as flushing erythema of the face in the first 2 days of symptoms. A second rash occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and appears maculopapular or morbilliform. Sometimes, lesions may coalesce and appear as 'white islands in a red sea' due to generalized erythema with petechiae and islands of sparing.

The alternative name for dengue, "breakbone fever", comes from the associated muscle and joint pains.

During the critical phase, the temperature reduces and there is progressive leukopenia and thrombocytopenia. This is followed by plasma leakage. An increasing hematocrit can help identify this phase. 

Dengue may be complicated by dengue hemorrhagic fever and shock. This occurs due to sensitizing antibodies from the previous infection. 

There are four serotypes of the dengue virus. Infection with one serotype provides lasting immunity to that same serotype and transient immunity to the other serotypes. 

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS 1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The treatment of dengue is supportive with hydration taking top priority. Antipyretic agents like paracetamol can be used. If there is severe thrombocytopenia (<10,000) then platelets should be transfused. 

Dengue shock can be treated with blood transfusion. 

Other options: 

Option B - Malaria is a parasitic infection caused by the Plasmodium species transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito. It is characterized by many nonspecific symptoms, including but not limited to tachycardia, tachypnea, chills, malaise, fatigue, diaphoresis (sweating), and headache. The fever of malaria is characterized by periodicity depending on the infective Plasmodium species. The fever returns every other day for P. vivax, ovale, and falciparum, and every three days for P. malariae. 

Option C - Typhoid is a gastrointestinal infection caused by Salmonella typhi. It is characterized by gradual onset headache, malaise, step ladder pyrexia, palpable spleen, and rose spots on the skin. The following image depicts rose spots in enteric fever. 

 

Option D - Yellow fever is a viral infection also transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. It is characterized by fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, jaundice, albuminuria, and hemorrhagic manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to produce the following adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given image shows gum hyperplasia, which is an adverse effect most likely produced by cyclosporine.

Other drugs that cause gum hyperplasia are:

  • Phenytoin
  • Calcium channel blockers

Cyclosporine is an immunomodulator that binds with the cyclophilin protein, and this complex inhibits the calcineurin activity. It decreases T-cell activation and is useful in T-cell-mediated transplant rejection. It is useful in autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, uveitis, Behcet's disease, atopic dermatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, nephrotic syndrome, etc. The major adverse effects are as follows:

  • Hirsutism
  • Gum hyperplasia
  • Nephrotoxicity
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Altered mental status, seizures

Other options:

Option A: Carbamazepine is an antiepileptic agent used in the treatment of generalised tonic-clonic seizures, focal seizures, trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgias, bipolar disorder, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The main adverse events are hepatotoxicity, dilutional hyponatremia, hypersensitivity reactions, aplastic anaemia, and agranulocytosis.

Option B: Tacrolimus is a macrolide antibiotic that binds to FKBP-12 protein (similar to cyclophilin) and inhibits calcineurin activity. It is indicated in the prophylaxis of solid-organ allograft rejection. Some of the adverse effects include nephrotoxicity, neurotoxicity, hypertension, and hyperglycemia.

Option D: Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic agent used in focal and generalised tonic-clonic seizures and Lennox Gestaut syndrome. The adverse effects include Stevens-Johnson syndrome, dizziness, ataxia, and double vision.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with a diabetic foot. The plan is to amputate the foot at the level of A-B as shown below. What is the amputation at this level called?
questions.solution:
This level of amputation is called Syme's amputation.

Amputation at the level distal tibia and fibula 0.6 cm proximal to the periphery of the ankle joint passing through the dome of the ankle. It is the most satisfactory functional level in the lower extremity when the outcome is good. The most common causes of an unsatisfactory Syme stump are posterior migration of the heel pad and skin slough resulting from overly vigorous trimming of “dog ears” or a compromised posterior tibial artery. The chief objection to this amputation is cosmetic.

Sarmiento modification of Syme technique is transection of the tibia and fibula approximately 1.3 cm proximal to the ankle joint and excision of the medial and lateral malleoli.

questions.text: Which of the following structures are not a content of broad ligament of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Fimbriae of the fallopian tube are not a content of broad ligament. The fallopian tube proper is a content of the broad ligament.

The broad ligament of the uterus is a double-layer fold of the peritoneum that attaches the lateral portions of the uterus to the lateral pelvic wall on either side. It consists of anterior and posterior leaves that separate to enclose viscera and blood vessels. The broad ligament is divided into:

  • Mesometrium - this is the largest portion related to the uterus
  • Mesosalpinx - represents the mesentery of the fallopian tubes
  • Mesovarium - connects the anterior part of the ovaries to the broad ligament.

The anatomical boundaries of the broad ligament are as follows:

  • Superiorly - round ligaments;
  • Posteriorly - infundibulopelvic ligaments
  • Inferiorly - cardinal and uterosacral ligaments. 

The broad ligament and the round ligament serve as secondary supports of the uterus.

Clinical significance:

  • Formation of the vesicouterine pouch between the bladder and the anterior part of the uterus.
  • Formation of the rectouterine pouch between the rectum and the posterior part of the uterus. This is also known as the pouch of Douglas or posterior pelvic cul-de-sac. It forms the most dependent part when a woman is sitting or standing. Thus, accumulation of fluid occurs in various pathologies which can be aspirated and studied by performing a culdocentesis. 
  • A potential site for endometriosis
  • Malignant leiomyosarcomas and lipoleiomyomas can arise from the broad ligament.
Epoophoron and paroophoron are vestigial structures of the Wolffian body present in the broad ligament

The infundibulopelvic ligament is that portion of the broad ligament that extends from the infundibulum of the fallopian tube to the lateral pelvic wall. It encloses the ovarian vessels, lymphatics, and nerves of the ovary. Hence, ovarian vessels are a content of the broad ligament.

questions.text: While performing cardiac catheterization, a cardiac biopsy was obtained in a young male patient aged 27 years, who recently developed heart failure. The image below shows a congo-red stained specimen, observed directly (A) and under polarized light (B). Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows a congo-red stained cardiac biopsy specimen with (A) focal positive staining of amorphous extracellular material, and (B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light, diagnostic of amyloidosis.

The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry. 

Amyloidosis is a disease characterized by the extracellular deposition of insoluble protein fibrils. Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. Proteins that are misfolded are normally eliminated. In amyloidosis, there is an accumulation of misfolded proteins in the extracellular space.

Amyloid diseases are classified depending on whether they are systemic or localized, acquired or inherited, and their clinical patterns. 

  • AL is the most common form of amyloidosis and is termed primary systemic amyloidosis. It occurs due to a plasma cell or B cell disorder. 
  • ATTY occurs due to mutations in transthyretin and is termed familial amyloidosis. 
  • AA involves amyloid A, an acute phase reactant and is termed secondary amyloidosis. It is usually associated with chronic inflammatory conditions.
  • AB2M amyloidosis occurs due to the accumulation of misfolded B2 microglobulin in patients with chronic renal disease. 

Many of the systemic features of the types of amyloidosis are overlapping. Thus, clinical diagnosis is not sufficient for treatment. In addition, the treatment of amyloidosis is type-specific. Thus, immunohistochemistry should be done to confirm the type of amyloidosis. Once it has been confirmed, then appropriate, type-specific treatment can be begun. 

Other options: 

Option A: Orthotropic liver transplantation is used to treat ATTR amyloidosis. Immunohistochemical staining must be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Option B: Treatment of the underlying inflammatory disease or infectious is done in AA amyloidosis. 

Option D: Oral melphalan and prednisone is given in AL amyloidosis to reduce the plasma cell burden.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought with bilateral cheek swelling,  pain, tenderness, and fever for the last two days. Which of the following is not a complication of this infection?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a parotid swelling with fever is suggestive of mumps infection. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is not a complication of this disease. SSPE is caused by a measles infection.

Mumps is an infection caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It causes non-suppurative inflammation and growth of the parotid glands. 

The mode of infection is inhalation or contact through the conjunctiva. The virus infects the respiratory tract leading to replication and dissemination through the cervical lymph nodes and bloodstream. The incubation period is about 12-25 days

Mumps infection usually presents with unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling. Unilateral disease usually progresses to bilateral involvement. It is accompanied by fever, local pain and tenderness but the skin over the gland is not warm or erythematous. It is usually self-limiting and resolves within a week. However, the involvement of other organs is detrimental and leads to severe complications.

Complications of mumps infection: 

  1. Epidymo-orchitis (Option A) is characterized by swollen, intensely painful testicles. This is usually associated with fever and chills. This may lead to testicular atrophy and decreased sperm counts. 
  2. Meningoencephalitis (Option B) or meningitis can occur. This is usually aseptic and is characterized by pleocytosis on cerebrospinal fluid examination. This may lead to deafness as a complication. 
  3. Acute pancreatitis (Option C) can occur. This generally resolves with conservative treatment. 
  4. Arthritis may occur with monoarticular or polyarticular involvement. 
  5. Myocardial involvement: Transient ECG changes are seen. Rapidly progressive myocarditis can occur.

A typical case of mumps needs no laboratory confirmation, but in atypical cases and complications, diagnosis may be established by virus isolation and serological tests.

Prophylaxis of mumps is done through the administration of an effective live virus vaccine containing the Jeryl-Lynn strain of the virus. The vaccine is given as a single subcutaneous injection, alone or in combination with the measles and rubella vaccines (Measles - Mumps - Rubella vaccine: MMR vaccine)
