questions.text: A 6-year-old child with ventricular septal defect is posted for corrective surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for induction in this procedure?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a child undergoing cardiac surgery, sevoflurane is the inhalational agent of choice for induction.

Halothane and sevoflurane are non-pungent and are less likely to irritate the airway or cause breath-holding or laryngospasm during induction. Hence, halothane and sevoflurane are most suited for use in induction among pediatric patients.

Sevoflurane is less frequently associated with significant myocardial depression, bradycardia, and arrhythmias which are seen with halothane. Hence, sevoflurane is preferred over halothane, especially in all cardiovascular surgeries in the pediatric age group.

Halothane sensitizes the heart to catecholamines, therefore careful reduction in the epinephrine dose in local anesthetic solutions must be followed. 

Following induction, isoflurane and sevoflurane are the most commonly used inhalation agents for maintenance. 

Desflurane and isoflurane are pungent compounds that irritate the airway and may lead to increased airway resistance, breath-holding, and laryngospasm which make them a poor choice for induction.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old girl is brought to the clinic for evaluation of fatigue. She is noted to have pallor. Hemoglobin electrophoresis shows HbA of 91%, HbA2 of 8%, and HbF of 1%. Peripheral smear shows findings as below. RDW is normal. Which of the following is likely to be true for this patient's condition?

RDW - Red cell distribution width
questions.solution:
This patient with pallor, microcytic hypochromic anemia with target cells on peripheral smear, haemoglobin electrophoresis revealing elevated HbA2 (normal: 2.2 to 2.8%), and a normal RDW is likely to have a beta-thalassemia minor. Thalassemia occurs due to disorders in globin synthesis. 

Thalassemia occurs due to mutations in globin gene expression. The mutations can affect the alpha and beta subunits, leading to variable presentation and severity depending on which gene is affected.

Patients with β thalassemia major present with severe anemia and hepatosplenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis. Marrow hyperplasia in the skill can lead to prominence of cheekbones and other bony prominences (chipmunk facies) and crewcut appearance, as shown below. 

These patients require regular blood transfusions and are at risk of developing secondary hemochromatosis. Iron chelators are given to prevent this. However, the prognosis is guarded, and the only curative treatment is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Patients with β thalassemia minor are mostly asymptomatic or may have mild anemia.

A complete blood count will show low hemoglobin and mean corpuscular volume (MCV), indicating microcytic hypochromic anemia. Mentzer index (MCV/red cell count) will be less than 13. The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic cells, anisopoikilocytosis, increased reticulocyte count, and target cells. 

Iron studies are performed to differentiate between thalassemia and iron deficiency anemia. Thalassemia has normal or increased serum iron and transferrin saturation. Iron deficiency anemia has decreased serum iron and transferrin saturation. Red cell distribution width (RDW) is generally normal in thalassemia and increased in iron deficiency. 

Hemoglobin electrophoresis measures the type of hemoglobin present in cells. Normally, Hemoglobin A (HbA) is 95-98%, Hemoglobin A2 (HbA2) is 2-3%, and Hemoglobin F (HbF) is less than 2%. Patients with β thalassemia minor usually have HbA2 between 4-8%, HbA >90%, and a small amount of HbF. Patients with transfusion-dependent β thalassemia have <5% HbA1, while HbF is 90-100%. 

Other options:

Option A: A low transferrin saturation is seen in iron deficiency anemia.

Option C: Mentzer index of more than 13 is seen in iron deficiency anemia. 

Option D: Bite cells are seen in the peripheral smear of patients with glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase(G6PD) deficiency.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of excessive fatigue and palpitations. On examination, severe pallor and pedal edema are present with an oxygen saturation of 89%, and there is evidence of impending heart failure. Her hemoglobin is 5.9 g/dL. Which among the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The best treatment option for this patient is packed cell transfusion.

The treatment of choice for anemia with hemoglobin between 5-7 g/dL at <34 weeks period of gestation with hypoxia and impending signs of heart failure like pedal edema is packed cell transfusion. Only packed cell transfusions are carried out and about 80-100 mL of blood is infused at a time and repeated only after 24 hours. 

The following precautions are taken prior to blood transfusions:

  • Administration of antihistaminics intramuscularly
  • Administration of diuretics intramuscularly at least 2 hours prior to transfusion to produce negative fluid balance
  • Adjustment of the drip rate to 10 drops/minute
  • Observation of the pulse, respiration, and basal lung crepitations

The complications of blood transfusions include premature labor, increased chances of worsening cardiac failure, and transfusion reactions.

Following are the RCOG guidelines for initiating blood transfusion during pregnancy:

  • Antepartum period
    1. Pregnancy <34 weeks:
      1. Hb <5 g/dL with or without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Hb 5-7 g/dL – in presence of impending heart failure
    2. Pregnancy >34 weeks:
      1. Hb <7 g/dL even without signs of cardiac failure or hypoxia
      2. Severe anemia with decompensation
    3. Anemia not due to hematinic deficiency:
      1. Hemoglobinopathy or bone marrow failure syndromes
      2. Consult hematologist
    4. Acute hemorrhage:
      1. Always indicated if Hb <6 g/dL
      2. If the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable due to ongoing hemorrhage
  • Intrapartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. The decision of blood transfusion depends on medical history or symptoms
  • Postpartum period
    1. Hb <7 g/dL 
    2. Anemia with signs of shock/acute hemorrhage with signs of hemodynamic instability

Other options given are parenteral formulations of iron therapy that are not indicated according to the criteria given above. Parenteral iron therapy is indicated in the following conditions:

  •  Contraindications of oral therapy such as severe gastrointestinal side effects of taking oral iron (nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, teeth staining, epigastric distress)
  •  Non-cooperative patient 
  •  Cases that are seen for the first time during the last 8–10 weeks with severe anemia.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency room and was diagnosed with an arrhythmia. The duty doctor tried to manage it by performing a carotid sinus massage. A normal pacemaker potential curve is shown in the image below. Identify the change expected to be seen in this curve after carotid sinus massage.
questions.solution:
The change expected to be seen in this patient after carotid sinus massage is a decrease in the slope of phase 4 of the pacemaker potential curve.

Carotid sinus massage is a vagal maneuver that is used to treat arrhythmias by activating the baroreceptor mechanism. The carotid sinus contains baroreceptors that get activated on physical manipulation. This mechanism, via the nucleus tractus solitarius, sends parasympathetic vagal efferents to the heart.

Phases of pacemaker potential:

  • Phase 0- Upstroke. It is due to the influx of Ca2+ ions by the opening of voltage-gated L-type channels.
  • Phase 3- Downstroke. It is due to the efflux of K+ leading to repolarization.
  • Phase 4- Prepotential. Because of ongoing K+ efflux, hyperpolarization sets in. This makes the channel more permeable to Na+ ions and since these Na+ channels are activated during hyperpolarization they are referred to as funny currents (Ih/If). They form the first half of the pre-potential. The second half of prepotential is completed by the opening of the voltage-gated T-type Ca2+ channel.

In the clinical scenario, due to vagal stimulation, the parasympathetic cholinergic fibers to the SAN are stimulated. This leads to a decreased slope of phase 4. This occurs by two mechanisms-

  1. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated→ slowed depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ decreased slope. 
  2. Vagal stimuli→ acetylcholine released→ M2 receptor stimulated → decreased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)→ decreased firing of T-type Ca2+ channel → decreased slope.

On the other hand, the response to sympathetic stimuli is that of an increased slope of the pacemaker potential. This effect is mediated by two mechanisms-

  1. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → β1 receptor → increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) → rapid opening of L-type Ca2+ channels → increased slope. 
  2. Sympathetic stimuli → norepinephrine released → increases the depolarising effect of funny Na+ (If) channel→ increased slope.

questions.text: Identify the sensory nerve supply for the given histological specimen of tongue.
questions.solution:
The given histological specimen shows a dome-shaped structure lined by stratified squamous epithelium suggestive of the circumvallate papilla of the tongue which is located at the junction of the anterior 2/3 and posterior 1/3 of the tongue. Sensory and gustatory innervation to the circumvallate papilla is by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

Circumvallate papillae are 8-12 in number which is large cylindrical structures. They form a V-shaped row just in front of the sulcus terminalis. Usually, the entire papillae are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. Taste buds are present in the lateral wall of these papillae which surrounds the papillae circumferentially.

Other papillae of the tongue: 

Fungiform papillae are large, rounded, and red in color and are mainly present on the lingual margins and also on the dorsal surface of the tongue. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. They are supplied by the facial nerve.

Filiform papillae are minute cylindrical or conical projections that are mainly present on the dorsal part of the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. The filiform papillae do not contain taste buds. They are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. They are supplied by the facial nerve.

Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges that are present bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text: Which among the following is a cell cycle independent anti-cancer drug?
questions.solution:
Cisplatin is a cell cycle independent anti-cancer drug.

Its mode of action has been linked to its ability to crosslink with the purine bases on the DNA, interfering with DNA repair mechanisms, causing DNA damage, and subsequently inducing apoptosis in cancer cells.

It is used in the treatment of testicular, bladder, ovary, and lung carcinomas. However, there are incidences of drug resistance and numerous undesirable side effects such as:

  • Severe kidney injury
  • Hearing loss especially in younger patients 
  • Decrease immunity to infections
  • Marked emesis
  • Electrolyte disturbances like hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia
  • Allergic reactions

Hence, other platinum-containing anti-cancer drugs such as carboplatin, oxaliplatin have been used.

Other options:

Option B- Vinblastin is an M phase-specific anti-cancer drug. Vinca alkaloids bind β-tubulin and inhibit its polymerization into microtubules → prevents mitotic spindle formation.

Option C- Cladribine is an S phase-specific anti-cancer drug. It is incorporated into DNA where it produces DNA strand breaks and depletion of NAD and ATP, leading to apoptosis. Also, it is a potent inhibitor of ribonucleotide reductase.

Option D- Topotecan is an S phase-specific anticancer drug. It inhibits topoisomerase 1 and prevents DNA unwinding and replication.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with incontinence of urine for 4 days. He had a history of memory loss for 6 months and has been diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. Which drug can be given for the incontinence of urine in this patient?
questions.solution:
Trospium is used for incontinence of urine in this patient.

Trospium is a non-selective muscarinic receptor antagonist with a quaternary amine compound. Due to the quaternary amine, trospium cannot cross the blood-brain barrier thus minimizing the central nervous system side effects. 

The cholinergic receptors present in the urinary bladder are of subtype M3> M2. Stimulation of these receptors causes contraction of the bladder muscles. Therefore, drugs that block these receptors cause relaxation of the muscles and therefore are used in the management of overactive bladder. Important drugs used in the management of overactive bladder mainly act on M3 receptors. They are:

  • Tolterodine, fesoterodine (prodrug of tolterodine)
  • Oxybutynin
  • Darifenacin
  • Solifenacin
  • Trospium
  • Mirabegron- a ß3 adrenergic receptor agonist

Trospium is the only parasympatholytic used for overactive bladder that is eliminated majorly by the kidney. Therefore, dose reduction has to be done in impaired renal function.

Adverse effects of all muscarinic antagonists include xerostomia, decreased sweating, thirst, mydriasis and blurring of vision, palpitations, ileus, and urinary retention. CNS effects include restlessness, hallucinations, and delirium.  

Other options:

Option A) Oxybutynin is a  slightly M3 selective muscarinic antagonist which reduces detrusor tone and spasms. It can be used in overactive bladder, postoperative bladder spasms. They are available in oral, intravenous, and patch formulations

Option C) Tolterodine is a M3 selective muscuranic antagonist and is the active form of the prodrug fesoteradine. It is used in overactive bladder. It is metabolized by the CYP3A4 enzyme, therefore its dose should be reduced in CYP3A4 inhibitors.

Option D) Darifenacin is an M3 selective muscarinic antagonist and its dose may have to be reduced in patients taking CYP inhibitor drugs

 Note: All options are drugs belonging to the class of muscarinic receptor antagonists.

questions.text: Which of the following neural mechanism is not involved in synaptic plasticity and learning?
questions.solution:
Sensitization is a neural mechanism involved in synaptic plasticity and learning (not desensitization).

Neural basis of synaptic plasticity and learning

  • Post-tetanic Potentiation
    • Production of enhanced postsynaptic potential, which occurs after a brief tetanizing train of stimuli in the presynaptic neuron
    • This enhancement lasts up to 60 seconds.
  • Habituation
    • A simple form of learning in which neutral stimulus is repeated many times until the subject becomes habituated to the stimulus and ignores it
    • A classic example of non-associative learning (e.g., learning a fact by heart)
  • Sensitization: The opposite of habituation
  • Long-term Potentiation (LTP)
    • A rapidly developing persistent enhancement of the post-synaptic potential response to presynaptic stimulation, after rapidly repeated stimulation of presynaptic neuron
    • Characteristically observed in the hippocampus
  • Long-term Depression
    • Is the opposite of LTP
    • Characterized by a decrease in synaptic strength
    • Produced by slower stimulation of presynaptic neuron
    • May be involved in the neural mechanism by which learning occurs in the cerebellum

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with a history of atrial fibrillation presented with acute, severe abdominal pain with nausea and vomiting. She had one episode of bloody stools. Examination reveals hypoactive bowel sounds and mild abdominal distension. Which of the following investigations is likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of atrial fibrillation, severe abdominal pain, bloody stools, and hypoactive bowel sounds, is likely to have acute mesenteric ischemia. The investigation likely to confirm the diagnosis is CT angiography.

Acute mesenteric ischemia occurs when there is an imbalance between splanchnic perfusion and intestinal metabolic demand. The three causes of mesenteric ischemia are:

  • Arterio-occlusive ischemia
  • Nonocclusive ischemia
  • Mesenteric venous thrombosis. 

This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which is likely the source of the embolus that led to intestinal ischemia. Other risk factors for arterio-occlusive ischemia are recent myocardial infarction, valvular heart disease, and recent cardiac catheterisation. 

The intestines have widespread collateral formation to reduce the effects of ischemia. However, two areas - Griffith's point (splenic flexure) and Sudeck's point (sigmoid flexure) are areas with decreased blood flow. These areas are the meeting point for collateral vessels and, thus, are most at risk for intestinal ischemia. 

Acute mesenteric ischemia usually presents with severe, acute abdominal pain that is out of proportion to the abdominal examination. There may also be nausea, vomiting, transient diarrhoea, anorexia, and bloody stools. There may also be mild abdominal distension and hypoactive bowel sounds. 

The gold standard for diagnosis is CT angiography. If it is acute, angiography can be done during the laparotomy as it is an emergency condition. Treatment involves resection of the dead bowel and restoring blood flow. 

Other options: 

Option A - Abdominal X-ray will reveal gas under the diaphragm in case of hollow viscous perforation. However, this finding is non-specific and can occur in any abdominal viscus perforation. 

Option C - Cardiac enzymes will be elevated in myocardial infarction. This patient has mesenteric ischemia. 

Option D - An electrocardiogram may help rule out acute myocardial infarction and for diagnosing atrial fibrillation in this case. It would not confirm a diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia.

questions.text: What is the name of the finding in the image of a patient with dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
The name of the finding in the image of a patient with dermatomyositis is the V sign. 

Dermatomyositis is characterized by symmetrical involvement of the muscles, commonly affecting the proximal muscles more than the distal muscles. Multiple dermatological manifestations also accompany it:

  • Shawl sign (Option B)- rashes in a sun-exposed area. This is present on the back of the neck and shoulders. 
  • V sign - rashes that occur in sun-exposed areas. They are present on the anterior neck and chest 
  • Heliotrope rash (Option D) is erythema and discolouration of the eyelids with periorbital oedema.
  • Gottron's sign (Option A) is an erythematous rash on the elbows, knees, ankles, and knuckles on the extensor surfaces.
  • Gottron's papules are raised with erythematous rashes over the knuckles. 
  • Edema of face and limbs
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Vasculopathic ulcers
  • Mechanic's hands in antisynthetase syndrome
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

Other manifestations of dermatomyositis include dysphagia, interstitial lung disease, bronchopneumonia, alveolitis, and myocarditis. 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies. Electromyography will reveal features of myopathy. Histology will show perifascicular atrophy, and immunohistochemical staining will reveal myxovirus resistance protein A, a sensitive and specific marker. 

Treatment of dermatomyositis is immunotherapy with high-dose glucocorticoids as the first line. Methotrexate can be started as the second line if the patient presents with severe weakness, other organ system involvement, or those with a risk of steroid complications like patients with diabetes, osteoporosis, or postmenopausal women. Otherwise, second-line agents are only started in patients who do not show improvement after 2-4 months of treatment with prednisone or those who cannot be maintained on a low dose. Triple therapy with intravenous immunoglobulin or rituximab may be required.

questions.text: A male patient was posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that passes through Alcock's canal and is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve.

Alcock's canal or pudendal canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

  • Internal pudendal artery
  • Internal pudendal vein
  • Pudendal nerve

The pudendal nerve originates from the ventral rami of S2, S3, and S4 of the sacral plexus. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor. 

In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve, and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

In females, the pudendal nerve supplies sensory branches to the lower of the vagina. Therefore, in vaginal surgeries, anesthesia can be infiltrated near the ischial spine by a needle passed through the vaginal wall and then guided by a finger.

The image given below shows the contents and boundaries of the ischioanal fossa.


Other options:

Option A: Obturator nerve is formed by ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4 of the lumbar plexus. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve is formed by the ventral rami of L1, and L2 of the lumbar plexus. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches.

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed by the L2 and L3 of the lumbar plexus. It runs on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

Lumbar plexus is formed by the divisions of the first four lumbar nerves (L1-L4) and from contributions of the subcostal nerve (T12), which is the last thoracic nerve.

questions.text: An autopsy is being conducted on a person who was diagnosed with normal pressure hydrocephalus. An axial dissection of the brain reveals one of the ventricles that is enlarged in this disease. Enlargement of the anterior horn of this ventricle causes compression of which of the following structures laterally?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an axial section of the lateral ventricle seen from posterior to anterior. The lateral relation of the anterior horn is the caudate nucleus. Enlargement of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle causes compression of the caudate nucleus laterally.

The clinical symptoms of normal-pressure hydrocephalus are characteristic of the classic triad of cognitive dysfunction, urinary symptoms, and a wide-based gait (wet, wacky, and wobbly). Additionally, depressed affect and UMN signs in lower limbs may be seen.
The diagnosis is established by a CT that shows a marked enlargement of ventricles and the Miller Fisher test that shows improvement in gait following a lumbar tap. Treatment generally involves ventriculoperitoneal shunting.

The lateral ventricle can be divided into the body and 3 horns—anterior, posterior, and inferior.

The locations of the parts: 

  • Body: Frontal and parietal lobe
  • Anterior horn: Frontal lobe
  • Posterior horn: Occipital lobe
  • Inferior horn: Temporal lobe

Anterior horn:

Extent: from the genu of the corpus callosum till the interventricular foramen

Relations: 

  • Anteriorly: Genu and rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Roof: Anterior part of the body of the corpus callosum 
  • Floor and lateral wall: Caudate nucleus
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum and anterior column of fornix

Body or Central part:

Extent: from the interventricular foramen till the splenium of the corpus callosum

Relations:

  • Roof: Body of the corpus callosum
  • Medial wall: Septum pellucidum 
  • Floor (from lateral to medial): Caudate nucleus, stria terminalis, thalamostriate vein, thalamus, choroid plexus, and body of the fornix

Posterior horn: 

Extent: from the splenium till the occipital pole

Relations:

  • Roof and lateral wall: tapetum of corpus callosum
  • Medial wall: Forceps major and calcar avis (calcarine sulcus)

Inferior horn: the largest compartment

Extent: till 2.5 cm from the temporal pole

Relations:

  • Roof: tapetum of corpus callosum and tail of caudate nucleus
  • Floor (lateral to medial): Collateral eminence (produced by collateral fissure, hippocampus)

Note: There is no lateral wall for the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: You have conducted a case-control study for which you calculate the cross-product ratio to be 0.5. What would you infer from this?

choices.text: The factor can be considered as a risk factor
The factor cannot be considered either as a protective or a risk factor
The factor may be considered as a protective factor

questions.solution:
A cross-product ratio, also known as the odds ratio, of 0.5 indicates that exposure is associated with lower odds of outcome and may be a protective factor for the disease.

The odds ratio (OR) or cross-product ratio is derived from a case-control study. It is a key parameter used to assess the strength of association between the risk factor and outcome. It is a measure of effect. It means it measures the effect of exposure to a risk factor on the risk of developing a disease. Relative risk and attributable risk are the other measures of effect. 
 
OR < 1 indicates that exposure to the factor is associated with lower odds of the outcome. It implies that the factor may be considered a protective factor for the disease. 
 
Other options:
 
Option A: The prevalence cannot be calculated using the cross-product ratio. It is defined as the total number of cases (both old and new) in a population at a given point in time or over a period of time. It is given by the following formula:
Prevalence = Incidence x mean duration
 
Option B: OR > 1 indicates that exposure to the factor is associated with higher odds of the outcome. This means that the factor may be a risk factor for the disease. 
 
Option C: OR = 1 means that exposure does not affect the odds of the outcome. It indicates that a person with the disease is no more likely to have been exposed to the risk factor than is a person without the disease. It is not related to the disease and cannot be considered either as a protective or a risk factor. 

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A child was brought with complaints of high fever and cough. On blood culture, the causative organism was found to be Haemophilus influenzae. Which of the following is not true regarding the bacteria?

choices.text: It requires growth factors V and X
It is a spore forming bacillus

questions.solution:
Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that is non-motile and non-spore-forming. 

When present in the sputum, H. influenzae appears as a coccobacillus, but in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), it appears as a filamentous bacillus. 

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X (Option A) that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

When H. influenzae is cultured on the same plate as Staphylococcus aureus. The closer the colonies of H. influenzae are to S. aureus, the larger the growth. This is termed satellitism (Option B). This occurs because factor V is released by the hemolytic action of S. aureus. 

The image below shows satellitism.

Hemophilus influenzae has a capsular polysaccharide (Option D) which is a major antigenic determinant. Capsular typing is done to identify strains. Importantly, the type b capsular polysaccharide has a polyribosyl ribitol phosphate antigen (PRP). PRP is targeted during immunization. 

H. influenzae can cause meningitis, laryngo-epiglottitis, pneumonia, bronchitis, and suppurative lesions like arthritis, endocarditis, and pericarditis. 

Cefotaxime or ceftazidime is the drug of choice for the treatment of Haemophilus meningitis. H.influenzae produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics like ampicillin.

H. influenza can be prevented by immunization with the Hib vaccine. The vaccine is produced based on the type b capsular polysaccharide. The capsule is composed of polyribosyl ribitol phosphate which can induce IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies. Those that do not have a capsule are not candidates for vaccine prevention. Apart from H. influenza type b, the non-typeable strains are those that produce the clinical infections presently.

questions.text: An eight-year-old girl presents with a red and pruritic rash on the sun-exposed areas of the body along with a history of wide-based, unsteady gait. On examination, serum electrolytes are normal and urine is positive for neutral amino acids. The pattern of inheritance of the disease is given in the image below.  What is the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra-like symptoms with autosomal recessive inheritance as shown in the image is suggestive of Hartnup disease. It is due to a tryptophan transport defect.

Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan due to a mutation of the SLC6A19 gene on Chromosome 5. This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra-like symptoms.

Clinical features include intermittent, reversible episodes affecting the skin and nervous system that are aggravated by sunlight, febrile illness, stress and nutritional deficiency. Skin manifestations present after sun exposure and include erythematous, scaly patches, similar to pellagra. Neurologic manifestations include ataxia(wide-based unsteady gait), tremors, mood disorder, depression, convulsions, and psychosis.

Diagnosis is made by demonstrating the presence of neutral amino acids in the urine, distinguishing it from pellagra. Indican can also be present in the urine, produced as a by-product of tryptophan metabolism. 

Treatment involves supplementation with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet.  

Other options :

Option B: Uroporphyrinogen I synthase defect is seen in acute intermittent porphyria, which is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. It presents with abdominal pain and neuropsychiatric symptoms. There will be elevated aminolevulinic acid and porphobilinogen in the urine and plasma.

Option C: Methylcobalamin formation defect results in methylmalonic acidemia, which follows autosomal recessive inheritance. The clinical manifestations would include vomiting, dehydration, failure to thrive, lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures. 

Option D: Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency results in tyrosinemia type II or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Patients present with corneal inflammation, painful palmoplantar hyperkeratosis, and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female patient with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presented with a high fever and decreased urinary output for 3 days. On examination, she has altered sensorium and renal angle tenderness. She is tachycardic with a blood pressure of 90/40 mm Hg. Her total leucocyte count is 19,000 cells/mm3. Which of the following pending results is most important for prognosis?
questions.solution:
Lactate is the most important parameter for prognosis.

The likely diagnosis in this patient with altered sensorium, fever, hypotension, tachycardia in association with pyelonephritis (renal angle tenderness, decreased urinary output) is septic shock. Her quick Sequential Organ Failure Assessment (qSOFA) score is 2. Septic shock is defined as persisting hypotension requiring vasopressors to maintain a mean arterial pressure of 65mmHg or higher and a serum lactate level of more than >2.0 mmol/L despite adequate volume resuscitation. 

Lactate is normally produced in small amounts by the body. However, in conditions where there is massive cellular hypoxia, lactate is produced as a result of anaerobic metabolism.

Recent studies have shown that serial lactate measurement is useful in determining response to treatment and evaluation.

Increased lactate levels are associated with increased mortality in sepsis. However, it should not be used alone to diagnose sepsis. 

Initial laboratory tests to be done in undifferentiated shock

  • Lactate
  • Renal function tests
  • Liver function tests
  • Cardiac enzymes
  • Complete blood count with differential
  • PT, PTT, and INR
  • Urinalysis and urine sediment
  • Arterial blood gas
  • ECG

Other options: 

Creatinine (Option B) and sodium and potassium (Option D) are used along with other parameters in Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation (APACHE) and  (SOFA) to predict mortality. However, renal function tests alone are not sufficient in determining prognosis. 

Option C - The infectious organism identified in blood culture would not help determine prognosis. Studies have shown that there is no statistically significant difference between the prognosis of culture-positive and culture-negative patients with septic shock.

questions.text: A newborn child was noted to have a congenital anomaly as shown in the image below. All of the following  statements are true about this condition except:

choices.text: Closure of abdominal wall should be done within the first year
Bilateral inguinal hernia is seen in males

questions.solution:
The congenital anomaly seen in the above image is exstrophy of the bladder (ectopia vesicae). It is associated with epispadias, not hypospadias.

Bladder exstrophy refers to herniation of the urinary bladder through an anterior abdominal wall defect. The bladder is open and exposed on the outside of the abdomen. The male to female ratio is 4:1. Chronic exposure of the bladder to the external environment can lead to adenocarcinoma of the bladder. 

The clinical features of bladder exstrophy include:

  • Separation of the pubic bones with non-united symphysis pubis
  • Epispadias
  • In males: Broad and short penis and bilateral inguinal hernia 
  • In females: Bifid clitoris 

Management involves a staged surgical reconstruction of the bladder and genitalia. Closure of the abdominal and bladder wall is done in the first year of life. This often requires an iliac osteotomy to relax the tension on the bladder and repair the abdominal wall during wound-healing.

Later, reconstruction of the bladder neck, sphincters, epispadias, and other genital defects is done.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male patient who is an athlete presents with pruritus of the groin. The findings of examination of the groin are shown in the image given below. He is diagnosed with a fungal infection. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing dry, erythematous, and a circumferential lesion in the groin are suggestive of tinea cruris. The most probable causative organism among the given options for tinea cruris is Trichophyton rubrum. 

Tinea cruris, or jock itch, refers to an infection that can involve the genital, pubic, perineal, and perianal skin. It is usually caused by dermatophytes like Trichophyton rubrum or Epidermophyton floccosum. 

T. rubrum belongs to the dermatophyte group. Dermatophytes are classified as microsporum, trichophyton, and epidermophyton. They are hyaline, filamentous fungi that enzymatically digest the keratin. Dermatophytes cause infection of the keratin-containing structures. These include the skin, hair, and nails. 

Infections caused by dermatophytes include the following: 

  • Tinea barbae - beard "barber's itch" 
  • Tinea corporis - affecting the body 
  • Tinea imbricata - a type of tinea corporis that exists in the tropical climate
  • Tinea capitis - scalp 
  • Tinea cruris - groin "jock itch"
  • Tinea pedis - foot "athlete's foot"
  • Tinea manuum - hand
  • Tinea unguium - nails 

The examination will reveal erythematous, pruritic, circular, scaly patches.  

Diagnosis of dermatophyte infection is done with Wood's lamp, which will reveal fluorescence. KOH preparation will reveal branching hyaline septate hyphae. Sabouraud dextrose agar (SDA) is used to culture dermatophytes. 

Topical azoles like miconazole, clotrimazole, or terbinafine are used to treat dermatophyte infections. 

Other options: 

Option A - Exophiala werneckii causes tinea nigra, an infection of the stratum corneum in the areas of the palm, leading to dark macules. 

Option C - Malassezia furfur causes pityriasis versicolor, also known as tinea versicolor. This fungus causes infection of the stratum corneum, leading to discolored or depigmented macules over the thorax, abdomen, and upper limbs. 

Option D - Trichosporon beigelii causes white piedra, infection of the hair. It is characterized by firm, irregular nodules on the hair shaft.

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with high-grade fever, and lower abdominal pain. She gives a history of spontaneous abortion at home 2 weeks back. She did not consult any doctor after this. A provisional diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is made. Which of the following features is least expected to be seen in PID developing after abortion?
questions.solution:
In PID developing after abortions, the formation of a distended fallopian tube is unlikely.

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) refers to the infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract until the ovaries. Most of the PIDs are due to ascending or blood-borne infection, hence the lesion is often bilateral. The anatomical proximity of the ovaries to the tubes invariably leads to its involvement as well. 

The most common etiological agent leading to post-abortal PID is Chlamydia trachomatis. In such cases, infection is spread through the cervical lymphatics to the broad ligament. As a result, the fallopian tube is affected from the outside and the mucosa is affected last. The wall of the tube is thickened with minimal distension. Mucosal involvement in later stages leads to blockage of the fallopian tube by multiple adhesions.

In PID occurring due to ascending infections, the mucous membrane is affected first. It becomes oedematous and infiltrated with leucocytes and plasma cells. The exudate so formed is discharged into the lumen of the tube. This causes the tube to distend, usually at the ampullary end. The inflamed and ulcerated mucosa eventually causes adhesions and tubal blockage or narrowing of the lumen. This leads to infertility or ectopic pregnancy.

In earlier stages of the disease, the inflammatory exudate pours out of the open fimbrial end to form a pelvic abscess. Eventually, the fimbrial end gets sealed and pus accumulates within the lumen leading to the formation of a distended retort-shaped fallopian tube called a pyosalpinx. 

The pyosalpinx may respond to antibiotics, and the pus contained therein becomes sterile within 6 weeks of the initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as a chronic pyosalpinx or hydrosalpinx.

Acute PID usually presents as bilateral pain abdomen, high-grade fever, vomiting, dehydration, menstrual irregularities, and in cases of pelvic abscess, it may present as severe diarrhea due to rectal irritation.

Management includes rest, rehydration, analgesics, and antibiotics based on culture sensitivity. Antibiotics commonly used are cefoxitin, azithromycin, ofloxacin, levofloxacin, and clindamycin. RCOG guideline recommends a single dose of IM ceftriaxone 250 mg followed by oral doxycycline 100 mg twice daily with metronidazole 400 mg twice daily for 14 days as outpatient treatment. Ceftriaxone IM followed by azithromycin 1 g per week for 2 weeks is an alternative.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, G2A1, presents with heavy vaginal bleeding with cramp-like abdominal pain at 18 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterine size corresponds to the period of gestation and  active vaginal bleeding is noted with an open internal os. USG reveals absent fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and examination findings of active vaginal bleeding and open internal os, with the uterine size corresponding to the period of gestation, is suggestive of inevitable abortion.

Inevitable abortion is a type of abortion where the abortive process has progressed to a state where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Clinical features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding as compared to threatened abortion.
  • Aggravated lower abdominal colicky pain
  • Uterine size corresponds to or may be smaller than the period of gestation
  • On examination, dilated internal os through which the products of conception are visualized and felt but has not begun to expel out ( unlike incomplete abortion )
  • USG examination shows absent fetal cardiac activity.

Risk factors:

  • Preterm premature rupture of membranes 
  • Amniocentesis
  • Prior second-trimester delivery
  • Tobacco use
  • Fetal surgery.

Management:

  • IV Methergine is indicated if there is excessive bleeding when the cervix is dilated and uterine size is. <12 weeks.
  • Before 12 weeks:
    • Dilatation and evacuation followed by curettage
    • Alternatively, suction and evacuation.
  • After 12 weeks:
    • Oxytocin drip, 10 units in 500mL of NS at 40-60 drips per minute
    • The separated placenta is removed by ovum forceps and digital separation is indicated if the placenta is not separated.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with recurrent episodes of breathlessness, wheeze, and chest tightness. Auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral wheeze. Sputum microscopy reveals the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the sputum microscopy showing Charcot–Leyden crystals (arrows in below image), lakes of mucus, and numerous eosinophils, are diagnostic of bronchial asthma.

Asthma is characterized by reversible bronchoconstriction caused by airway hyperresponsiveness to a variety of stimuli. Atopic asthma is caused by a TH2 and IgE-mediated immunologic reaction to environmental allergens (type-1 hypersensitivity reaction). Triggers for non-atopic asthma are less clear but include viral infections and inhaled air pollutants.

Genetic susceptibility for developing asthma:

  • Chromosome 5q - site of the susceptibility locus for asthma
  • IL-13 gene polymorphisms (on 5q chromosome) - most consistent associations with asthma or allergic disease
  • IL-4 receptor gene variants - associated with atopy, elevated total serum IgE, and asthma

The sputum of patients with bronchial asthma shows:

  • Charcot–Leyden crystals - made of an eosinophilic membrane protein called galectin 10
  • Curschmann spirals - spirals of mucus plugs from subepithelial mucous gland ducts or bronchioles
  • Creola bodies - desquamated epithelial cells
  • Numerous eosinophils

Note: The hygiene hypothesis was previously used to explain the development of asthma and other hypersensitivity disorders.

questions.text: While conducting animal studies, a scientist is experimenting with different properties of drugs acting on the ANS. He identifies a drug that inhibits the rate-limiting step in acetylcholine synthesis in nerve terminals. What is this drug?
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting step in acetylcholine synthesis is the active uptake of choline into the nerve terminal, which is inhibited by hemicholinum.

Option A: Choline is the precursor of acetylcholine and is taken up from the synaptic cleft into the nerve terminal.

Option C: Acetylcholine esterase is involved in the breakdown of acetylcholine after it is released into the synaptic cleft.

Option D: Botulinum toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from nerve terminals.

questions.text: A new vaccine that was in the clinical trial phase of efficacy confirmation for COVID-19 has been approved for marketing by the FDA. The following statements about the post-marketing surveillance phase of the clinical trial are true, except that ______.

choices.text: The main aim of this phase is to identify adverse events, compliance, and drug interactions.
It is a randomized controlled type of trial.
It involves thousands to lakhs of participants.
There is no fixed duration for completion of this phase.

questions.solution:
The postmarketing surveillance (Phase IV) of the clinical trial is an open-label type and not a randomized controlled type of trial. 

Phase IV- Postmarketing surveillance of clinical trials is started when the phase III trial is completed and a new drug application (NDA) is approved by the FDA. The approved drug is prescribed to patients all around the world. Patients treated in the normal course form the study population therefore numbers are larger.

Uncommon/ idiosyncratic adverse effects, occurring after long-term use, unsuspected drug interactions, and compliance are detected at this stage.

The participants/ patients in this phase are not controlled or randomized to a study and control population; hence, it is not a randomized control trial (RCT). It is an open-label trial as all the patients who receive the drug are aware of the intake of drugs and not blinded. There is no fixed duration as to when this phase ends.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with recent onset of photosensitivity and development of vesicles and bullae on the sun-exposed areas of his skin as shown below. A urine analysis showed the presence of elevated levels of uroporphyrin I and normal red cell uroporphyrin. Identify the false statement regarding the patient's illness.

UROD- Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase

choices.text: Low dose hydroxychloroquine is used in management
Associated with increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda. The false statement regarding the patient's illness is that the hepatic iron stores are normal. The hepatic iron stores will be increased in this condition.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is the most common type of porphyria and presents with cutaneous and hepatic features. It is caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. Mutations of the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) gene are present in the familial type PCT.

The accumulated porphyrins are transported to the skin and act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin friability, milia, and bullae on the sun-exposed skin of the dorsal aspect of the hands, forearms, face, legs, and feet. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

The porphyrins accumulate in the liver and are excreted in urine and bile. Hepatic iron stores are increased as PCT is an iron-related disorder. Liver dysfunction is common in these patients and the risk of developing hepatocellular carcinoma is increased. 

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

Management includes:

  • Repeated phlebotomies to deplete hepatic iron stores. Iron administration can lead to a recurrence of the disease.
  • Low dose hydroxychloroquine which forms complexes and removes the excess porphyrins from the liver.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of depression presents with suicidal ideation. On further questioning, he reveals that he has had a previous suicide attempt and no family support.  Which of the following is not an indication for hospitalization?

choices.text: Absence of a strong social support system

questions.solution:
The ability to discuss safety planning is not an indication for hospitalization in this patient.

Indications for hospitalization for suicide prevention include the following: 

  • Suicidal plan of action
  • Inability to discuss safety planning
  • Absence of a strong social support system
  • History of impulsive behavior
  • Psychotic patient 
  • Precautions were taken to evade discovery
  • Severe agitation, poor judgment, and refusal to accept help

A suicide attempt is a psychiatric emergency. While suicide is hard to predict, the patient may unintentionally provide clues to the same. Some high-risk factors for suicide are male sex, age above 45, unemployment, multiple attempts at suicide, and social isolation. Most people who have committed or attempted suicide have an underlying mental disorder, of which depression and schizophrenia are the most common.

During hospitalization, objects that can be used for self-harm should be removed. Anti-depressants or antipsychotics are used depending on the underlying condition. Individual therapy, group therapy, and family therapy are other useful measures.

Suicide attempts and thoughts are more common in women, but the rate of committing suicide is more in men. Suicide rates increase with age and are rare before puberty. 

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a lump in the right breast. On clinical examination, there was no lymphadenopathy and the surgeon decided to do the following procedure shown in the image. What is the recommended site of injection for the radioisotope-labeled albumin for doing this procedure?

choices.text: Subcutaneously in axilla and around lump

questions.solution:
The following image shows a sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma camera and the recommended site of injection of radioisotope-labelled albumin is the subdermal plexus around the nipple.

Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Sentinel lymph node is the first draining lymph node. This procedure is done only on node-negative tumors.

  • Technique: methylene blue dye or radioisotope (technetium)-labelled albumin is injected in subdermal plexus around the nipple. The sentinel node is identified as a blue node or as a radioactive node using a gamma camera.
  • The frozen section biopsy is sent to the pathologist for the identification of cancer cells. If the biopsy is positive for cancer cells, then axillary dissection is simultaneously performed.
  • The combination of blue dye and technetium-labelled colloid has been reported to improve the detection of sentinel lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient was brought to the emergency room in a state of altered sensorium, irritability, and aggression. His relatives give a history of a headache earlier that day, for which the patient had taken a paracetamol tablet. On further investigation, he was found to have a deficiency of citrin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is type II citrullinemia.

Type II citrullinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the deficiency of citrin due to mutations in the SLC25A13 gene. Citrin is a membrane transport protein in the urea cycle that facilitates the transfer of aspartate from mitochondria to the cytoplasm.

Patients usually present between 20 and 50 years of age, with neuropsychiatric symptoms like altered mental status, confusion, seizures, flapping tremors, irritability, or even a coma-like state resulting from hepatic encephalopathy. There are recurrent episodes of hyperammonemia which are usually precipitated by triggers like surgery, drugs (like acetaminophen), alcohol consumption, and high sugar intake. The patient will also have a history of aversion to carbohydrate-rich foods like rice, bread, and potato.

During an acute attack, elevated levels of ammonia, citrulline, and arginine are observed with low or normal levels of glutamine. Levels of galactose-1-phosphate in the RBCs are also increased. Demonstration of the gene mutation is useful for confirmation of the diagnosis.

It is managed with a diet that is rich in fats and proteins and low in carbohydrates with supplements of medium-chain triglycerides, arginine, and pyruvate. Liver transplantation helps to prevent the progression of symptoms.

Note: Deficiency of any of the urea cycle enzymes would result in hyperammonemia

Other options:

Option A: Type I citrullinemia is a urea cycle disorder caused by a deficiency of argininosuccinate synthase, which catalyzes the synthesis of argininosuccinate from citrulline and aspartate; Patients have a history of protein aversion, lethargy progressing to coma, and liver failure.

Option C: Hartnup disease is caused due to a defective intestinal transport of the essential amino acids such as tryptophan and niacin. Clinical features include pellagra like rash and neurologic manifestations such as cerebellar ataxia and delirium.

Option D: Type I hyperammonemia is also a urea cycle disorder caused due to a deficiency of the enzyme carbamoyl phosphate synthase-I, which is essential for the condensation of CO2, ammonia, and ATP to form carbamoyl phosphate. Clinical features include irritability, vomiting, lethargy (especially a few days after birth).

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: An autopsy of a 65-year old man who passed away from complications due to myocardial infarction was conducted. The histopathological examination of the infarcted area of the heart revealed contraction band necrosis, nuclear pyknosis, and hypereosinophilia. After how much time will these findings occur after a myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
The histopathological findings of contraction band necrosis, nuclear pyknosis, and hypereosinophilia  are seen 12-24 hours after myocardial infarction.

Pathological contraction bands, also known as Zenker's necrosis, are a type of necrosis pattern found in the myocardium. Histologically, the pattern seen is hyper contraction and lysis of small groups of myocardial cells. Contraction bands are seen surrounding an acute myocardial infarction.

Other causes of contraction bands are:

  • Coronary occlusion
  • Resuscitation attempts
  • Drowning
  • Burning
  • Hypothermia.

Other changes that occur ar 12-24 hours are the gross appearance of dark mottling and microscopic features such as ongoing coagulative necrosis, and early neutrophilic infiltrate.

Other options:

Option A - Histopathological changes occurring by 7-10 days are well-developed phagocytosis of dead cells and the presence of granulation tissue at margins. On gross examination, it appears maximally yellow-tan and soft, with depressed red-tan margins.

Option B -Histopathological changes occurring by 10-14 days are well-established granulation tissue with new blood vessels and collagen deposition. On gross examination, it appears as red-gray depressed infarct borders.

Option C -Histopathological changes occurring by 4-12 hours are early coagulative necrosis, edema, and hemorrhage. On gross examination, there is occasional dark mottling.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient, with a history of liver cirrhosis, has deteriorated into hepatic encephalopathy. He is shifted to the intensive care unit and is started on lactulose and neomycin to ameliorate hepatic encephalopathy. He develops MRSA pneumonia while he is on neomycin and lactulose. Which of the following drugs cannot be given for the treatment of MRSA pneumonia in this scenario?

(MRSA- methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus)
questions.solution:
Vancomycin is the drug that cannot be given for MRSA pneumonia in this scenario.

Neomycin is an aminoglycoside that has the highest nephrotoxic effect among aminoglycosides. Vancomycin also has a dose-related nephrotoxic effect. Therefore, administering neomycin and vancomycin together can lead to exaggerated nephrotoxicity.

Neomycin binds to the 30s ribosomal subunit and leads to misreading and premature termination of mRNA translation thus interfering in the protein synthesis. It is usually used in hepatic encephalopathy along with lactulose as it suppresses coliform flora thus decreasing ammonia production. It is also used preoperatively in bowel preparation for elective bowel surgery. The main adverse effects of neomycin are nephrotoxicity and it has the highest neuromuscular blockade capacity among aminoglycosides. So it is contraindicated in myasthenia gravis.

Vancomycin belongs to the glycopeptide group. It has a high affinity to the D-alanyl-D-alanine of the cell wall and inhibits cell wall synthesis in susceptible organisms. Vancomycin is the mainstay treatment for MRSA infections, oral drug of choice for pseudomembranous colitis, penicillin-resistant streptococcal infections and enterococci endocarditis. Rapid intravenous infusion results in an infusion reaction called 'red man syndrome'. It also has dose-related nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity.

Other options:

Option A- Tigecycline belongs to the tetracycline group and inhibits the protein synthesis in microorganisms by binding reversibly to the 30s ribosomal subunit. Tigecycline and doxycycline are eliminated by nonrenal mechanisms and does not require dose adjustment in renal failure. It is effective against MRSA, VRSA(vancomycin-resistant S.aureus), enterococci, and many other gram-positive and negative organisms. 

Option B- Streptogramins involving a combination of quinupristin and dalfopristin are reserved for use in MRSA and vancomycin-resistant E.faecium. They act by binding to the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibiting protein synthesis. The main adverse effects are infusion reactions like pain and phlebitis, arthralgia and myalgia.

Option D- Linezolid belongs to the oxazolidinones group that acts by binding to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits the protein synthesis. It is used in the treatment of skin and soft tissue infections(by MRSA), MRSA respiratory infections and vancomycin-resistant E.faecium infections. The main adverse effects are myelosuppression, peripheral neuropathy, optic neuritis, and lactic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

questions.text: A 36-year-old P2L2 woman visits the OPD requesting sterilization surgery.  Of the many methods available, the doctor suggests the procedure described in the image given below. Identify this method of tubal sterilization.
questions.solution:
The method of tubal sterilization shown in the image is the Uchida technique.

In this method, the serosa over the mid segment of the fallopian tube is stripped off exposing the muscular layer. The exposed part is ligated and excised. The proximal end is buried in the broad ligament and the distal end is left open outside the mesosalpinx. An advantage of this method is that the minimal excision of the tube provides scope for tuboplasty in the future.

An image showing the Uchida technique is given below.


Option A - Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.


Option B - Pomeroy procedure is the most popular technique of tubal sterilization. In this method, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.


Option D - Madlener procedure is a simple procedure but is associated with high rates of failure. In this procedure, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. A loop is made, and is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture as shown below.


Other methods of sterilization:

  • Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:
    • Kroener's technique: It refers to the excision of fimbriae (fimbriectomy). 
    • Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.
    • Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected where it is attached to uterus.
  • Laparoscopic techniques:
    • Using Falope ring, Hulka clip, and Filshie clip.
  • Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, which is confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of progressively worsening menstrual pain that is now causing her distress for most of the month. She finds no relief from contraceptive pills. She underwent laparotomy and an ovarian cyst was excised which is shown in the image below. Which among the following is not a risk factor for this condition?

DES - Diethyl stilbesterol
questions.solution:
The image shows a chocolate cyst which is diagnostic of endometriosis. Early menopause is not a risk factor.

Chocolate cysts of the ovaries represent the most important manifestation of endometriosis. Gross examination shows thickening of the tunica albuginea, and well-marked vascular red adhesions on the undersurface of the ovary. The inner surface of the cyst wall is vascular and contains areas of dark brown tissue as shown in the image. The chocolate cyst lies between the ovary and the lateral pelvic wall

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (glands and stroma) outside the uterus. It is an estrogen-dependent disease primarily affecting women of the reproductive age group. The most common site of occurrence is the ovary followed by the pouch of Douglas.

 The risk factors for the development of endometriosis are - 

  • Family history
  • Nulliparity
  • Prolonged exposure to endogenous estrogen
    • Early menarche and
    • Late menopause
  • Estrogen therapy
  • In utero exposure to Diethyl stilbesterol (DES)
  • Obstruction to menstrual flow
  • Shorter menstrual cycles
  • White and Asian race

The protective factors for endometriosis are -

  • Multiparity
  • Extended intervals of lactation
  • Late menarche 
  • Increased consumption of long-chain omega-3 fatty acids
  • Black and Hispanic race

The various theories that explain the development of endometriosis are:

  1. Sampson's theory of retrograde menstruation or Implantation theory attributes the development of endometriosis to reflux menstrual endometrium via the fallopian tubes and its subsequent implantation and growth on the pelvic peritoneum and nearby structures.
  2. Meyer and Ivanhoff's coelomic metaplasia theory attributes the development of endometriosis to metaplastic changes in embryonic cell rests of embryonic mesothelium, which are capable to respond to hormonal stimuli.
  3. Halban's metastatic theory explains the presence of endometriosis in far-off sites like the lung, pleura, endocardium, and extremities. It attributes the development of endometriosis to the embolization of menstrual fragments via vascular or lymphatic channels.
  4. The hormonal theory states that the development of endometriosis depends mainly on estrogen. Progesterone causes atrophy of endometrioses.
  5. The immunological theory states that impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

Clinical presentations of endometriosis are - 

  • Chocolate cysts as described above
  • Red-colored papular and vesicular lesions filled with hemorrhagic fluid over the pelvic peritoneum, pouch of Douglas, and uterosacral ligaments.
  • Dysmenorrhoea is the most common symptom. It commonly presents before the onset of menses, gradually builds up until the flow begins, and decreases thereafter. Deeper lesions cause more pain than superficial ones.
  • Backache is also a common symptom.
  • Lower abdominal pain of varying intensity
  • Dyspareunia
  • Infertility
  • Menorrhagia
  • Chronic pelvic pain syndrome
Laparoscopy is the gold standard in the diagnosis of endometriosis. Transvaginal ultrasound reveals an echo-free cyst or clumps of high-density echoes suggestive of clots. Colour doppler shows a diffuse increase in vascularity. An elevated CA-125 level is suggestive of endometriosis. 

Treatment of endometriosis:

Medical management:

Mnemonic to remember drugs used: GOLD GAP

  • G: GnRH analogs
  • O: Oral contraceptive pills
  • L: Letrozole
  • D: Danazol
  • G: Gestrinone
  • A: Antiprogesterone-Mifepristone
  • P: Progesterones orally or as Mirena IUCD

Surgical management:

  • Conservative surgery: Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser.
  • Combined medical and surgical therapy
  • Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA)
  • Radical surgery: Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy.

Related Pearl: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

  • Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.
  • Rectovaginal endometriosis.
  • Ovarian endometriosis.
  • Chocolate cyst of the ovary.
  • Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.
  • Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

  • Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.
  • Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.
  • Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).
    • Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.
    • Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: A male patient presents with episodic vertigo associated with vomiting, aural fullness, difficulty in hearing, and tinnitus. He does not notice any variation in symptoms with the position. If otoscopic findings are normal, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is Meniere's disease based on the clinical features given.

Meniere's disease arises due to the distension of the endolymphatic system. This occurs due to increased production or decreased drainage of endolymph. 

It usually affects males between the ages of 35 to 60. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is generally a unilateral condition. The symptoms appear in clusters with remission periods lasting from weeks to years. Nystagmus may also be seen during acute attacks. Tumarkin's otolithic crisis is a variant where affected individuals experience sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness.

Rinne's test is positive and Weber's test shows lateralization to the better ear, suggestive of sensorineural hearing loss. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) also shows sensorineural hearing loss. Initially, the lower frequencies are affected resulting in a 'rising' curve. As the disease progresses, higher frequencies are affected leading to a 'flat' or 'falling' curve. 

General treatment measures include reassurance, smoking cessation, and dietary restriction of salt, coffee, tea, and alcohol. An excessive amount of water intake is also discouraged.

Acute attacks can be treated with bed rest and vestibular sedatives like dimenhydrinate, promethazine theoclate, or prochlorperazine. Chronic cases are managed with vasodilators (betahistine) and diuretics. Repeated intratympanic injection of gentamicin can help 60-80% of patients. 

Surgical procedures can be done if medical management fails. These include decompression of the endolymphatic sac, endolymphatic shunt operation, sacculotomy (Fick's operation), and intermittent low-pressure pulse therapy. Labyrinthectomy is done only when the cochlear function cannot be salvaged.

Other options: 

Option A: Vestibular neuronitis is characterized by sudden onset vertigo lasting from a few days to a few weeks. It is self-limiting and thought to be caused by a viral infection. There is no hearing loss. 

Option B: Suppurative labyrinthitis often occurs secondary to serous labyrinthitis, due to bacterial invasion of the inner ear. It presents with nausea, vomiting, spontaneous nystagmus, and total hearing loss. Affected individuals also suffer from vertigo which resolves in a few weeks.

Option C: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is characterized by vertigo when the patient places their head in a critical position. It occurs due to debris present in the semicircular canals. It is not associated with hearing loss and can be treated with Epley's maneuver.

Related Pearl: Meniere’s disease vs. Otosclerosis

Meniere’s Disease

Otosclerosis

Middle age (F>>M)

Bilateral

Conductive Hearing loss

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:

 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient complained of fever with abdominal pain in the lower left quadrant. A CT scan was advised which showed sigmoid diverticulitis with a large, walled-off pelvic abscess. All of the following management options are included except:
questions.solution:
Proximal end colostomy is not a management option for sigmoid diverticulitis with a large, walled-off pelvic abscess

Diverticulitis is the inflammation of the colonic diverticula. The sigmoid colon is the most common site for colonic diverticulitis. They usually present with left lower abdominal quadrant pain, fever, nausea, anorexia, urinary urgency. Abdominal distension with focal tenderness is seen if the perforation is contained. Diffuse peritonitis with rebound tenderness and guarding is suggestive of perforation with widespread contamination.

Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is now the standard investigation for evaluation of acute diverticulitis. Complications of diverticulitis are characterized by abscess, fistula, obstruction, or free perforation.

Hinchey's grading of diverticulitis:

  • Stage I- Small pericolic or mesenteric abscess
  • Stage II- Large, walled-off pelvic abscess
  • Stage III- Generalized purulent peritonitis
  • Stage IV- Generalized fecal peritonitis

Management:

Hinchey's stages I and II are usually managed primarily by antibiotics and percutaneous drainage of the abscess. If this is successful and the abscess resolves, then an elective colectomy with primary anastomosis is done.

Hinchey's stages III and IV are usually surgical emergencies with signs of generalized peritonitis and sepsis (fever, tachycardia, hypotension). After resuscitative measures, they require immediate surgical exploration where Hartmann's procedure is done. This involves segmental resection of the diseased colon and a proximal end-colostomy with the closure of the distal rectal stump. Primary anastomosis is usually not preferred in these stages due to contamination of the field.
