questions.text: An adolescent male with recurrent abdominal pain was diagnosed with tropical chronic pancreatitis. All of the following statements are true regarding this condition except:

choices.text: Can be due to excess consumption of tapioca
Alcohol plays a role in the etiology
Dilatation of pancreatic ducts due to intraductal stones

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true regarding tropical chronic pancreatitis except alcohol consumption plays a role in the etiology of tropical chronic pancreatitis. 

Tropical chronic pancreatitis

It usually affects the younger generation in poor socioeconomic strata. Cassava (tapioca) ingestion as a staple diet is implicated as a causative factor due to derivatives of cyanide which require sulfur-containing amino acids for detoxification. These amino acids are not present in lower socioeconomic or malnourished individuals. Alcohol consumption is not one of the etiologies of tropical chronic pancreatitis.

The pancreas appears firm and nodular macroscopically. The ducts are dilated. There is extensive periductal fibrosis associated with intraductal calcium carbonate stones of different sizes and shapes. These stones may resemble a staghorn. Microscopically, intralobular, interlobular, and periductal fibrosis are the predominant feature. 

There is a high incidence of pancreatic cancer in these patients. The patient usually has type 1 diabetes mellites (fibrocalculous pancreatic diabetes). 

Treatment:

Medical management is the mainstay of treatment. It involves exocrine pancreatic enzyme supplementation, insulin for diabetes mellitus, and the management of malnutrition. Surgery is indicated in intractable pain and in dilated ducts with stones. The procedure of choice is the removal of stones, with a side-to-side pancreaticojejunostomy to a Roux loop.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

Related Pearl: Pancreas - Most Commons

M/C cause of acute pancreatitis: Gallstones

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis: Alcohol

M/C cause of chronic pancreatitis in children: Cystic fibrosis

M/C cause of pancreatic calcification: Alcohol

M/C congenital variant: Pancreas divisum

M/C site of thrombosis in chronic pancreatitis: Splenic vein

questions.text: A diabetic female patient on isoniazid and rifampicin for tuberculosis developed deep vein thrombosis. She was started on warfarin, but there was no elevation in prothrombin time. The next step should be?
questions.solution:
The next step should be using low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

The anticoagulant effect of warfarin is assessed by the measurement of prothrombin time (PT). Failure of elevation of PT indicates the decreased effect of warfarin. If we increase the dose of warfarin, it will take 5 days to prevent DVT. For immediate action, heparin or LMWH has to be started.

LMWH has more inhibitory activity on factor Xa than on factor IIa due to the conformational changes in antithrombin caused by the short molecules of LMWH. This conformational change the rate of factor Xa inhibition. LMWH has little effect on platelets. Heparin, LMWH, or fondaparinux are used in the treatment of deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, unstable angina, or acute myocardial infarction. Some of the examples of LMWH preparations are enoxaparin and dalteparin. The major adverse effect is bleeding and there is a low incidence of thrombocytopenia.

Other options:

Option A- Effect of warfarin starts in 4-5 days. Therefore, heparin or LMWH has to be started for immediate effect.

Option B- Acenocoumarin is also an oral anticoagulant. Its metabolism is also subjected to induction by rifampicin.

Option C- Rifampicin is an enzyme inducer and can decrease the effect of warfarin. Rifampicin is the most effective drug for tuberculosis and should not be replaced.

questions.text: In a study involving 200 patients with hypertension, a normal distribution curve was obtained. The mean blood pressure was 200 mmHg and the standard deviation was 20 mmHg. What is the range in which the BP of about 136 patients would fall?​
questions.solution:
The blood pressure range is 180-220 mmHg.

A normal distribution curve follows the 68-95-99 rule which implies:

  • 68% of the values lie within 1 standard deviation from the mean.
  • 95% of the values lie within 2 standard deviations from the mean.
  • 99.7% of the values lie within 3 standard deviations from the mean.

In the given question, 136 patients out of a total of 200 patients represent 68%.

Therefore, subtract and add 1SD from the mean to get the range for 68% of the values.

Which is, Mean - 1SD to Mean + 1SD

In the question, the mean is given as 200 mmHg, and 1SD is given as 20 mmHg.

Substituting the values,

The BP range is 200-20 to 200+20 = 180 to 220 mmHg.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with an atrioventricular (AV) heart block. Name the vein which accompanies the artery supplying the AV node.
questions.solution:
The middle cardiac vein accompanies the posterior interventricular artery which provides arterial supply to the AV node.

The middle cardiac vein begins at the cardiac apex and runs in the posterior interventricular groove and merges with the coronary sinus near its atrial end. Thus it accompanies the posterior interventricular artery in the groove.

Other options:

Option B: Great cardiac vein originates at the cardiac apex. It runs anteriorly in the anterior interventricular groove and ends in the coronary sinus at its origin. It accompanies anterior interventricular and circumflex arteries. 

Option C: Oblique vein of left atrium descends obliquely on the posterior aspect of the left atrium and joins the coronary sinus.

Option D: Inferior vein of left ventricle lies on the diaphragmatic surface of the left ventricle, a little left of the middle cardiac vein. It ends by joining the coronary sinus or occasionally the great cardiac vein.

The image below shows the venous drainage of the heart.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presented with headache and vomiting for 7 days and an episode of a tonic-clonic seizure. He had intermittent bloody stools for the past 6 months. He has a family history of colon carcinoma. An MRI of his brain is given below. Colonoscopy and biopsy revealed numerous adenomatous polyps in the rectum and the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has numerous adenomatous polyps and a brain tumour as seen in the MRI. Hence the most likely diagnosis is Turcot's syndrome. It is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).

Turcot's syndrome is characterised by malignant tumours of the central nervous system in association with FAP

Familial adenomatous polyposis (option A) is an autosomal dominant condition and is caused due to the mutation in the APC gene located on chromosome 5.

Clinically, patients develop hundreds to thousands of adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum. More than 100 colonic adenomas are diagnostic of FAP. Some patients may also develop duodenal adenomas. The lifetime risk of developing colorectal carcinoma in these patients is 100%.

The treatment of the FAP includes total proctocolectomy with ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (IPAA)

Gardner's syndrome (option C) is an autosomal dominant variant of FAP. In addition to colonic polyps the patients will have osteomas of the mandible or skull, epidermal cysts and soft tissue tumours like desmoid tumours

In Peutz-Jegher's syndrome, (option D) there is pigmentation of the mouth and lips and multiple hamartomatous polyps in the small and large intestines. It is an autosomal dominant disease.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

Related Pearl: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

  • Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100
  • Gastric and duodenal polyps are present
  • Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma
  • Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.
  • Epidermoid cysts
  • Desmoid tumors in the abdomen
  • Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia
  • Brain tumors
  • Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with respiratory insufficiency. A decision is made to perform a procedure using the instrument shown below. Which of the following is not a function of this procedure?
questions.solution:
The image shows a tracheostomy tube. Tracheostomy does not increase dead space by 30-50%. It decreases dead space and reduces airway resistance. 

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: An 18-year-old student presents for ophthalmic evaluation due to the findings shown in the below image. The patient is very tall, with long limbs and long, slender, spiderlike fingers. Slit-lamp examination in this patient reveals bilateral ectopia lentis. What is the usual site of lens subluxation in the given condition?
questions.solution:
The patient with blue sclera as shown in the image along with long limbs, tall height, and slender fingers with ectopia lentis is likely to have Marfan's syndrome. In Marfan's syndrome, ectopia lentis is usually superotemporal.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition. It involves a mutation in the fibrillin 1 gene (FBN1). It has classic cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal abnormalities. 

The most common ocular change in Marfan syndrome is bilateral ectopia lentis, seen in 80% of patients. Ectopia lentis is a hereditary or acquired displacement of the lens from its normal position. It may be partially or fully displaced. In Marfan syndrome, it is usually a superotemporal subluxation. The zonules are intact so accommodation is not affected. However, in severe cases, the lens may also dislocate into the anterior chamber or the vitreous. 

Other causes of ectopia lentis are as follows: 

Acquired: 

  • Trauma
  • Pseudoexfoliation
  • Inflammation
  • Hypermature cataract
  • Large eye due to myopia or buphthalmos
  • Anterior uveal tumors

Without systemic associations: 

  • Familial ectopia lentis
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae
  • Aniridia

With systemic associations:

  • Marfan syndrome
  • Homocystinuria - inferonasal
  • Weill-Marchesani syndrome - inferior subluxation

Other ocular manifestations of Marfan syndrome are glaucoma due to angle anomaly, lattice retinal degeneration and detachment, hypoplasia of the dilator pupillae. 

The most characteristic cardiac abnormality is aortic root dilation, which leads to regurgitation, aneurysmal dilation, and dissection, which is a cause of mortality. Mitral valve prolapse can also occur. There is also excessive linear growth of long bones leading to long extremities in proportion to the trunk. They also have joint laxity and scoliosis. 

Blue sclera is also seen in osteogenesis imperfecta, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan's syndrome, and pseudoxanthoma elasticum.

questions.text:
A 50-year old patient comes to the surgical outpatient department with complaints of epigastric pain, weight loss, vomiting, diabetes, and jaundice. An ERCP was performed which showed dilatation of the main pancreatic duct, with a classic fish-mouth appearance of the ampulla. Which of the following statements is false about the diagnosis?

ERCP - Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMNs). The false statement is that KRAS mutations are characteristic in IPMNs.

IPMNs are cystic neoplasms of the pancreas. They are premalignant neoplasms (Option A). They are characteristically more common in men (Option C) and occur in the pancreatic head (Option D). They are mucin-producing tumors of large ducts in the pancreas. The absence of dense "ovarian" stroma and involvement of the pancreatic duct help differentiate IPMNs from mucinous cystic neoplasms

Oncogenic mutations that are seen are:

  • Oncogenic mutations of GNAS encoding the GSα subunit are characteristic.
  • K-RAS is the most common in approximately 80% of cases
  • Loss of function mutations of RNF43 in 50% of cases

It presents with epigastric discomfort, pain, nausea, and vomiting, weight loss, diabetes, jaundice, and fistulae. 

Histopathological findings of the head of the pancreas show prominent papillary neoplasm involving the main pancreatic duct. 

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is the investigation of choice. On ERCP, dilatation of the main pancreatic duct or its branches is observed. Diagnostic features like the fish-mouth appearance (gaping ampulla with extrusion of mucin) may be observed.

Other cystic neoplasms of the pancreas are:

  • Serous cystic neoplasms - are common in women. Inactivation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p is most common.
  • Mucinous cystic neoplasms - are common in women. Oncogenic KRAS mutations are seen in half the cases. Characteristic "ovarian" stroma appearance is seen.
  • Solid-pseudopapillary neoplasm - seen in young women. Activating mutations of CTNNB1 (β-catenin) are present.

Related Pearl: Serous cystadenoma of the pancreas

Benign with no chances of malignancy.

Commonly in females (female to male ratio - 2:1), older age group

The site of occurrence of Serous cystadenoma is uniformly distributed across the pancreas.

Gross and microscopic appearance:

  • Microcysts giving a honey-comb appearance
  • Glycogen-rich cells

Computed tomography (CT) findings: Central calcification, with radiating septa giving the sunburst appearance.

Fluid analysis: mucin negative, low serum levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and amylase.

Treatment: Mainly conservative

Resection: If symptomatic or if malignancy is suspected

questions.text: All of the following statements about the stab wounds are true, except ______.

choices.text: Force is along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object
Depth is greater than the length and width of the wound
Fish-tail appearance occur in single edged weapon
Swallow tails occur at angles of the main wound

questions.solution:
Swallow-tails occuring at angles of the main wound is a characteristic of laceration wound (not stab wound).

A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc into the depth of the body. (Option A)

Characteristics of stab wound:

  • Margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. In full penetration of the blade, the hilt mark can be produced by the hilt guard.
  • The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. 
  • The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade.
  • The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface (Option B). The internal depth is usually equal to or less than the length of the blade used to produce it. 
  • The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc.
    • In single-edged weapon- triangular/wedge-shaped with one end sharp and other 2 sides blunt. Splits may occur at the blunt end of the wound at each corner giving a fish-tail appearance. (Option C)
    • In double-edged weapon- elliptical in shape with both sides sharp angles.
    • Screwdriver- a slit-like stab wound 
    • Fork- produces clusters of 2-3 wounds
  • The wound will have a bevelled margin if the object penetrates at an angle, thus indicating the direction of penetration.

Below is the image showing the fish-tail appearance of stab wounds.

Option D- Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails. It is seen in lacerated wounds.

Below is the image showing swallow tails of a lacerated wound.

Related Pearl: Difference between incised, lacerated and stab wound

Trait Incised wound Lacerated wound Stabwound
Manner of production By sharp objects or weapons By blunt  objects or weapons  By pointed sharp or blunt weapons
Site Anywhere Usually over the bony prominences Anywhere, usually chest and abdomen
margins Smooth, even, clean cut and everted Irregular and often undermined Cleancut, parallel edges, lacerated if weapon is blunt pointed
Abrasion and edges Absent Usually present Absent
Bruising No adjacent bruising of soft tissues Bruising of surrounding and underlying tissue rare
shape Linear or spindle shaped Varies usually irregular Linear or irregular
Depth of wound Structures cleanly cut to the depth of the wound Small strands of tissue at the bottom bridge across margins Structures cleanly cut

questions.text: A teenage boy complained of excessive daytime sleepiness for the past 6 months. He says that he is not able to move his legs or arms for 1-2 minutes while waking up in the morning. He also complains that he falls very frequently without being able to get up, as shown in the image. Which histaminergic drug can be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of narcolepsy. Pitolisant is the histaminergic drug that can be given to this patient. 

Pitolisant is an H3 receptor inverse agonist that has been approved for the treatment of narcolepsy. Contraindications for this drug include end-stage renal disease and severe hepatic impairment.

Narcolepsy is a type of hypersomnolence disorder that is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms of:

  1. excessive daytime sleepiness
  2. cataplexy- sudden loss of muscle tone
  3. sleep paralysis- patients report being unable to move their muscles while waking up in the morning, even though they are awake and conscious
  4. hypnogogic hallucinations- vivid auditory or visual perceptions during sleep onset, can occur while awakening also

Narcolepsy is characterized by the sudden onset of REM sleep. Emotional triggers like laughter and anger cause cataplexy.

It has a familial incidence associated with HLA-DR2. These patients are usually deficient in the hypocretin neurotransmitter that stimulates appetite and alertness. 

Modafinil and CNS stimulant drugs like methylphenidate are being used in the treatment of narcolepsy. Recently, H3 receptor inverse agonist drugs have been approved for the treatment.

Other options:

Option B- Diphenhydramine is an H1 receptor antagonist with antimuscarinic activity. It is used in the reversal of extrapyramidal side effects caused by antipsychotics. 

Option C- Cyproheptadine is an H1 receptor antagonist with antiserotonergic activity. The major clinical applications are carcinoid syndrome and cold-induced urticaria. It is also used in the treatment of serotonin syndrome. It also acts as an appetite stimulant.

Option D- Olopatidine is a topical H1 receptor antagonist with additional mast cell stabilizing and anti-inflammatory properties. It is used in allergic conjunctivitis as drop form and in allergic rhinitis as a spray form.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with halitosis and regurgitation of food for the past 7 months. He mentions that he often feels like food is stuck in his throat. A barium swallow was performed and the findings are shown below. Which of the following procedures is used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and barium swallow are suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. The procedure used for the treatment of this condition is Dohlman's procedure.

The pharyngeal pouch or Zenker's diverticulum is a protrusion of the mucosa through Killian's dehiscence a weak area of the posterior pharyngeal wall between the oblique fibres of the thyropharyngeus and the transverse fibres of the cricopharyngeus.

It presents at around 60 years of age and is more common in men than women. The patients usually experience regurgitation of foul-smelling, undigested food, halitosis and recurrent cough. The diagnosis is usually made by a lateral barium swallow.

The treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The endoscopic treatment of Zenker's diverticulum is also called the Dohlman technique. It is a transoral endoscopic approach in which the septum between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size.

Other options:

Option A: Heller myotomy is used for the treatment of achalasia cardia.

Option C: Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy is used to treat infantile pyloric stenosis.

Option D: Nissen's fundoplication is used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and hiatal hernia.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure
